<h1 class="firstHeading mw-first-heading" id="firstHeading"><span class="mw-page-title-main">France</span></h1>
<div class="vector-body" id="bodyContent">
<div class="noprint" id="siteSub">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>
<div id="contentSub"></div>
<div id="contentSub2"></div>
<div id="jump-to-nav"></div>
<a class="mw-jump-link" href="#mw-head">Jump to navigation</a>
<a class="mw-jump-link" href="#searchInput">Jump to search</a>
<div class="mw-body-content mw-content-ltr" dir="ltr" id="mw-content-text" lang="en"><div class="mw-parser-output"><div class="shortdescription nomobile noexcerpt noprint searchaux" style="display:none">Country in Western Europe</div>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1033289096">.mw-parser-output .hatnote{font-style:italic}.mw-parser-output div.hatnote{padding-left:1.6em;margin-bottom:0.5em}.mw-parser-output .hatnote i{font-style:normal}.mw-parser-output .hatnote+link+.hatnote{margin-top:-0.5em}</style><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">For other uses, see <a class="mw-disambig" href="/wiki/France_(disambiguation)" title="France (disambiguation)">France (disambiguation)</a>.</div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">"La France" redirects here. For other uses, see <a class="mw-redirect mw-disambig" href="/wiki/Lafrance_(disambiguation)" title="Lafrance (disambiguation)">Lafrance</a>.</div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">"French Republic" redirects here. For previous republics, see <a class="mw-redirect mw-disambig" href="/wiki/French_Republics_(disambiguation)" title="French Republics (disambiguation)">French Republics</a>.</div>
<p class="mw-empty-elt">

href="/wiki/List_of_countries_and_dependencies_by_population_density" title="List of countries and dependencies by population density">89th</a>)</td></tr><tr class="mergedtoprow"><th class="infobox-label" scope="row"><a href="/wiki/Gross_domestic_product" title="Gross domestic product">GDP</a> <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886047488" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><span class="nobold">(<a href="/wiki/Purchasing_power_parity" title="Purchasing power parity">PPP</a>)</span></th><td class="infobox-data">2022 estimate</td></tr><tr class="mergedrow"><th class="infobox-label" scope="row"><div class="ib-country-fake-li">• Total</div></th><td class="infobox-data"><img alt="Increase" data-file-height="300" data-file-width="300" decoding="async" height="11" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Increase2.svg/11px-Increase2.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Increase2.svg/17px-Increase2.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Increase2.svg/22px-Increase2.svg.png 2x" title="Increase" width="11"/> $3.667 trillion<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IMFWEOFR_15-0"><a href="#cite_note-IMFWEOFR-15">[10]</a></sup> (<a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(PPP)" title="List of countries by GDP (PPP)">10th</a>)</td></tr><tr class="mergedbottomrow"><th class="infobox-label" scope="row"><div class="ib-country-fake-li">• Per capita</div></th><td class="infobox-data"><img alt="Increase" data-file-height="300" data-file-width="300" decoding="async" height="11" //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Increase2.svg/22px-Increase2.svg.png 2x" title="Increase" width="11"/> $56,036<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IMFWEOFR_15-1"><a href="#cite_note-IMFWEOFR-15">[10]</a></sup> (<a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(PPP)_per_capita" title="List of countries by GDP (PPP) per capita">24th</a>)</td></tr><tr class="mergedtoprow"><th class="infobox-label" scope="row"><a href="/wiki/Gross_domestic_product" title="Gross domestic product">GDP</a> <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886047488" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><span class="nobold">(nominal)</span></th><td class="infobox-data">2022 estimate</td></tr><tr class="mergedrow"><th class="infobox-label" scope="row"><div class="ib-country-fake-li">• Total</div></th><td class="infobox-data"><img alt="Increase" data-file-height="300" data-file-width="300" decoding="async" height="11" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Increase2.svg/11px-Increase2.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Increase2.svg/17px-Increase2.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Increase2.svg/22px-Increase2.svg.png 2x" title="Increase" width="11"/> $2.936 trillion<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IMFWEOFR_15-2"><a href="#cite_note-IMFWEOFR-15">[10]</a></sup> (<a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(nominal)" title="List of countries by GDP (nominal)">7th</a>)</td></tr><tr class="mergedbottomrow"><th class="infobox-label" scope="row"><div class="ib-country-fake-li">• Per capita</div></th><td class="infobox-data"><img alt="Increase" data-file-height="300" data-file-width="300" decoding="async" title="Increase" width="11"/> $44,747<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IMFWEOFR_15-3"><a href="#cite_note-IMFWEOFR-15">[10]</a></sup> (<a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(nominal)_per_capita" title="List of countries by GDP (nominal) per capita">28th</a>)</td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row"><a href="/wiki/Gini_coefficient" title="Gini coefficient">Gini</a> <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886047488" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><span class="nobold">(2020)</span></th><td class="infobox-data"><img alt="Negative increase" data-file-height="300" data-file-width="300" decoding="async" height="11" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/Increase_Negative.svg/11px-Increase_Negative.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/Increase_Negative.svg/17px-Increase_Negative.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/Increase_Negative.svg/22px-Increase_Negative.svg.png 2x" title="Negative increase" width="11"/> 29.3<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-eurogini_16-0"><a href="#cite_note-eurogini-16">[11]</a></sup><br/><span class="nowrap"><span style="color:forestgreen">low</span></span></td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row"><a href="/wiki/Human_Development_Index" title="Human Development Index">HDI</a> <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886047488" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><span class="nobold">(2021)</span></th><td class="infobox-data"><img alt="Increase" data-file-height="300" data-file-width="300" decoding="async" height="11" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Increase2.svg/11px-Increase2.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Increase2.svg/17px-Increase2.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Increase2.svg/22px-Increase2.svg.png 2x" title="Increase" width="11"/> 0.903<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UNHDR_17-0"><a href="#cite_note-UNHDR-17">[12]</a></sup><br/><span class="nowrap"><span style="color:darkgreen">very high</span></span> · <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_Human_Development_Index" title="List of countries by Human Development Index">28th</a></td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row">Currency</th><td class="infobox-data"><div class="plainlist"><ul><li><a href="/wiki/Euro" title="Euro">Euro</a> (<a href="/wiki/Euro_sign" title="Euro sign">€</a>) (<a href="/wiki/ISO_4217" title="ISO 4217">EUR</a>)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-six_18-0"><a href="#cite_note-six-18">[VI]</a></sup></li><li><a href="/wiki/CFP_franc" title="CFP franc">CFP franc</a> (XPF)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-seven_19-0"><a href="#cite_note-seven-19">[VII]</a></sup></li></ul></div></td></tr><tr class="mergedtoprow"><th class="infobox-label" scope="row">Time zone</th><td class="infobox-data"><span class="nowrap"><a href="/wiki/Coordinated_Universal_Time" title="Coordinated Universal Time">UTC</a>+1</span> (<a href="/wiki/Central_European_Time" title="Central European Time">Central European Time</a>)</td></tr><tr class="mergedrow"><th class="infobox-label" scope="row"><div class="ib-country-fake-li">• Summer (<a href="/wiki/Daylight_saving_time" title="Daylight saving time">DST</a>)</div></th><td class="infobox-data"><span class="nowrap"><a href="/wiki/Coordinated_Universal_Time" title="Coordinated Universal Time">UTC</a>+2</span> (<a href="/wiki/Central_European_Summer_Time" title="Central European Summer Time">Central European Summer Time</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-eight_22-0"><a href="#cite_note-eight-22">[IX]</a></sup>)</td></tr><tr class="mergedbottomrow"><th class="infobox-label" scope="row"></th><td class="infobox-data">Note: Various other time zones are observed in overseas France.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nine_20-0"><a href="#cite_note-nine-20">[VIII]</a></sup><br/> Although France is in the <a href="/wiki/Coordinated_Universal_Time" title="Coordinated Universal Time">UTC</a> (Z) (<a href="/wiki/Western_European_Time" title="Western European Time">Western European Time</a>) zone, <a href="/wiki/UTC%2B01:00" title="UTC+01:00">UTC+01:00</a> (<a href="/wiki/Central_European_Time" title="Central European Time">Central European Time</a>) was enforced as the standard time since 25 February 1940, upon <a href="/wiki/German_military_administration_in_occupied_France_during_World_War_II" title="German military administration in occupied France during World War II">German occupation in WW2</a>, with a +0:50:39 offset (and +1:50:39 during <a href="/wiki/Daylight_saving_time" title="Daylight saving time">DST</a>) from Paris <a href="/wiki/Local_mean_time" title="Local mean time">LMT</a> (UTC+0:09:21).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-21"><a href="#cite_note-21">[13]</a></sup></td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row">Date format</th><td class="infobox-data">dd/mm/yyyy (<a href="/wiki/Anno_Domini" title="Anno Domini">AD</a>)</td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row"><a href="/wiki/Left-_and_right-hand_traffic" title="Left- and right-hand traffic">Driving side</a></th><td class="infobox-data">right</td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row"><a href="/wiki/Telephone_numbers_in_France" title="Telephone numbers in France">Calling code</a></th><td class="infobox-data"><a href="/wiki/Telephone_numbers_in_France" title="Telephone numbers in France">+33</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-eleven_23-0"><a href="#cite_note-eleven-23">[X]</a></sup></td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row"><a href="/wiki/ISO_3166" title="ISO 3166">ISO 3166 code</a></th><td class="infobox-data"><a href="/wiki/ISO_3166-2:FR" title="ISO 3166-2:FR">FR</a></td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row"><a href="/wiki/Country_code_top-level_domain" title="Country code top-level domain">Internet TLD</a></th><td class="infobox-data"><a href="/wiki/.fr" title=".fr">.fr</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ten_24-0"><a href="#cite_note-ten-24">[XI]</a></sup></td></tr><tr><td class="infobox-full-data" colspan="2"><div class="ib-country-fn">Source gives area of metropolitan France as 551,500 km<sup>2</sup> (212,900 sq mi) and lists overseas regions separately, whose areas sum to 89,179 km<sup>2</sup> (34,432 sq mi). Adding these give the total shown here for the entire French Republic. The CIA reports the total as 643,801 km<sup>2</sup> (248,573 sq mi).</div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><b>France</b> (<small>French: </small><span class="IPA" lang="fr-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/French" title="Help:IPA/French">[fʁɑ̃s]</a></span> <span class="nowrap" style="font-size:85%"><span class="unicode haudio"><span class="fn"><a href="/wiki/Special:FilePath/LL-Q150_(fra)-Fhala.K-France.wav" title="Listen"><img alt="Listen" data-file-height="20" data-file-width="20" decoding="async" height="11" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/11px-Loudspeaker.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/17px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/22px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 2x" width="11"/></a></span></span></span>), officially the <b>French Republic</b> (French: <i lang="fr">République française</i>),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-formal_country_name_25-0"><a href="#cite_note-formal_country_name-25">[14]</a></sup> is a <a href="/wiki/List_of_transcontinental_countries" title="List of transcontinental countries">transcontinental country</a> predominantly located in <a href="/wiki/Western_Europe" title="Western Europe">Western Europe</a> and spanning <a href="/wiki/Overseas_France" title="Overseas France">overseas regions and territories</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Americas" title="Americas">Americas</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Atlantic_Ocean" title="Atlantic Ocean">Atlantic</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pacific_Ocean" title="Pacific Ocean">Pacific</a> and <a href="/wiki/Indian_Ocean" title="Indian Ocean">Indian Oceans</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-twelve_26-0"><a href="#cite_note-twelve-26">[XII]</a></sup> Its <a href="/wiki/Metropolitan_France" title="Metropolitan France">metropolitan area</a> extends from the <a href="/wiki/Rhine" title="Rhine">Rhine</a> to the <a href="/wiki/Atlantic_Ocean" title="Atlantic Ocean">Atlantic Ocean</a> and from the <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_Sea" title="Mediterranean Sea">Mediterranean Sea</a> to the <a href="/wiki/English_Channel" title="English Channel">English Channel</a> and the <a href="/wiki/North_Sea" title="North Sea">North Sea</a>; overseas territories include <a href="/wiki/French_Guiana" title="French Guiana">French Guiana</a> in <a href="/wiki/South_America" title="South America">South America</a>, <a href="/wiki/Saint_Pierre_and_Miquelon" title="Saint Pierre and Miquelon">Saint Pierre and Miquelon</a> in the North Atlantic, the <a href="/wiki/French_West_Indies" title="French West Indies">French West Indies</a>, and many islands in <a href="/wiki/Oceania" title="Oceania">Oceania</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Indian_Ocean" title="Indian Ocean">Indian Ocean</a>. Due to its several coastal territories, France has the largest <a href="/wiki/Exclusive_economic_zone" title="Exclusive economic zone">exclusive economic zone</a> in the world. France borders <a href="/wiki/Belgium" title="Belgium">Belgium</a>, <a href="/wiki/Luxembourg" title="Luxembourg">Luxembourg</a>, <a href="/wiki/Germany" title="Germany">Germany</a>, <a href="/wiki/Switzerland" title="Switzerland">Switzerland</a>, <a href="/wiki/Monaco" title="Monaco">Monaco</a>, <a href="/wiki/Italy" title="Italy">Italy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Andorra" title="Andorra">Andorra</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Spain" title="Spain">Spain</a> in <a href="/wiki/Continental_Europe" title="Continental Europe">continental Europe</a>, as well as the <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_the_Netherlands" title="Kingdom of the Netherlands">Netherlands</a>, <a href="/wiki/Suriname" title="Suriname">Suriname</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Brazil" title="Brazil">Brazil</a> in the Americas via its overseas territories in <a href="/wiki/French_Guiana" title="French Guiana">French Guiana</a> and <a href="/wiki/Saint_Martin_(island)" title="Saint Martin (island)">Saint Martin</a>. Its <a href="/wiki/Regions_of_France" title="Regions of France">eighteen integral regions</a> (five of which are overseas) span a combined area of 643,801 km<sup>2</sup> (248,573 sq mi) and close to 68 million people (as of July 2022<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=France&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Field_Listing_::_Area_8-1"><a href="#cite_note-Field_Listing_::_Area-8">[5]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pop_est_13-1"><a href="#cite_note-pop_est-13">[8]</a></sup> France is a <a href="/wiki/Unitary_state" title="Unitary state">unitary</a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Semi-presidential_system" title="Semi-presidential system">semi-presidential</a> <a href="/wiki/Republic" title="Republic">republic</a> with its capital in <a href="/wiki/Paris" title="Paris">Paris</a>, the country's <a href="/wiki/List_of_communes_in_France_with_over_20,000_inhabitants" title="List of communes in France with over 20,000 inhabitants">largest city</a> and main cultural and commercial centre; other major <a href="/wiki/Urban_area_(France)" title="Urban area (France)">urban areas</a> include <a href="/wiki/Marseille" title="Marseille">Marseille</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lyon" title="Lyon">Lyon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Toulouse" title="Toulouse">Toulouse</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lille" title="Lille">Lille</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bordeaux" title="Bordeaux">Bordeaux</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Nice" title="Nice">Nice</a>.
</p><p>Inhabited since the <a href="/wiki/Upper_Paleolithic" title="Upper Paleolithic">Palaeolithic</a> era, the territory of Metropolitan France was settled by <a href="/wiki/List_of_ancient_Celtic_peoples_and_tribes" title="List of ancient Celtic peoples and tribes">Celtic tribes</a> known as <a href="/wiki/Gauls" title="Gauls">Gauls</a> during the <a href="/wiki/Iron_Age" title="Iron Age">Iron Age</a>. <a href="/wiki/Roman_Gaul" title="Roman Gaul">Rome annexed the area</a> in 51 BC, leading to a distinct <a href="/wiki/Gallo-Roman_culture" title="Gallo-Roman culture">Gallo-Roman culture</a> that laid the foundation of the <a href="/wiki/French_language" title="French language">French language</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Germanic_peoples" title="Germanic peoples">Germanic</a> <a href="/wiki/Franks" title="Franks">Franks</a> formed the Kingdom of <a href="/wiki/Francia" title="Francia">Francia</a>, which became the heartland of the <a href="/wiki/Carolingian_Empire" title="Carolingian Empire">Carolingian Empire</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Verdun" title="Treaty of Verdun">Treaty of Verdun</a> of 843 partitioned the empire, with <a href="/wiki/West_Francia" title="West Francia">West Francia</a> becoming the <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_France" title="Kingdom of France">Kingdom of France</a> in 987. In the <a href="/wiki/High_Middle_Ages" title="High Middle Ages">High Middle Ages</a>, France was a powerful but highly decentralised <a href="/wiki/Feudalism" title="Feudalism">feudal</a> kingdom. <a href="/wiki/Philip_II_of_France" title="Philip II of France">Philip II</a> successfully strengthened royal power and <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Bouvines" title="Battle of Bouvines">defeated his rivals</a> to double the size of the <a href="/wiki/Crown_lands_of_France" title="Crown lands of France">crown lands</a>; by the end of his reign, France had emerged as the most powerful state in Europe. From the mid-14th to the mid-15th century, France was plunged into a series of dynastic conflicts involving <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_England" title="Kingdom of England">England</a>, collectively known as the <a href="/wiki/Hundred_Years%27_War" title="Hundred Years' War">Hundred Years' War</a>, and a distinct French identity emerged as a result. The <a href="/wiki/French_Renaissance" title="French Renaissance">French Renaissance</a> saw art and culture flourish, conflict with the <a href="/wiki/House_of_Habsburg" title="House of Habsburg">House of Habsburg</a>, and the establishment of a <a href="/wiki/French_colonial_empire" title="French colonial empire">global colonial empire</a>, which by the 20th century would become the second-largest in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:8_27-0"><a href="#cite_note-:8-27">[15]</a></sup> The second half of the 16th century was dominated by <a href="/wiki/French_Wars_of_Religion" title="French Wars of Religion">religious civil wars</a> between <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church" title="Catholic Church">Catholics</a> and <a href="/wiki/Huguenots" title="Huguenots">Huguenots</a> that severely weakened the country. France again emerged as Europe's dominant power in the 17th century under <a href="/wiki/Louis_XIV" title="Louis XIV">Louis XIV</a> following the <a href="/wiki/Thirty_Years%27_War" title="Thirty Years' War">Thirty Years' War</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-28"><a href="#cite_note-28">[16]</a></sup> Inadequate economic policies, inequitable taxes and frequent wars (notably a defeat in the <a href="/wiki/Seven_Years%27_War" title="Seven Years' War">Seven Years' War</a> and costly <a href="/wiki/France_in_the_American_Revolutionary_War" title="France in the American Revolutionary War">involvement in the American War of Independence</a>), left the kingdom in a precarious economic situation by the end of the 18th century. This precipitated the <a href="/wiki/French_Revolution" title="French Revolution">French Revolution</a> of 1789, which overthrew the <i><span title="French-language text"><i lang="fr"><a href="/wiki/Ancien_R%C3%A9gime" title="Ancien Régime">Ancien Régime</a></i></span></i> and produced the <a href="/wiki/Declaration_of_the_Rights_of_Man_and_of_the_Citizen" title="Declaration of the Rights of Man and of the Citizen">Declaration of the Rights of Man</a>, which expresses the nation's ideals to this day.
</p><p>France reached its political and military zenith in the early 19th century under <a href="/wiki/Napoleon" title="Napoleon">Napoleon</a> Bonaparte, subjugating much of <a href="/wiki/Continental_Europe" title="Continental Europe">continental Europe</a> and establishing the <a href="/wiki/First_French_Empire" title="First French Empire">First French Empire</a>. The <a href="/wiki/French_Revolutionary_Wars" title="French Revolutionary Wars">French Revolutionary</a> and <a href="/wiki/Napoleonic_Wars" title="Napoleonic Wars">Napoleonic Wars</a> shaped the course of European and world history. The collapse of the empire initiated a period of relative decline, in which France endured a tumultuous succession of governments until the founding of the <a href="/wiki/French_Third_Republic" title="French Third Republic">French Third Republic</a> during the <a href="/wiki/Franco-Prussian_War" title="Franco-Prussian War">Franco-Prussian War</a> in 1870. Subsequent decades saw a period of optimism, cultural and scientific flourishing, as well as economic prosperity known as the <i><a href="/wiki/Belle_%C3%89poque" title="Belle Époque">Belle Époque</a></i>. France was one of the <a href="/wiki/Triple_Entente" title="Triple Entente">major participants</a> of <a href="/wiki/World_War_I" title="World War I">World War I</a>, from which it <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Versailles" title="Treaty of Versailles">emerged victorious</a> at great human and economic cost. It was among the <a href="/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_II" title="Allies of World War II">Allied powers</a> of <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a>, but was soon <a href="/wiki/German_military_administration_in_occupied_France_during_World_War_II" title="German military administration in occupied France during World War II">occupied</a> by the <a href="/wiki/Axis_powers" title="Axis powers">Axis</a> in 1940. Following <a href="/wiki/Free_France#Liberation_of_France" title="Free France">liberation</a> in 1944, the short-lived <a href="/wiki/French_Fourth_Republic" title="French Fourth Republic">Fourth Republic</a> was established and later dissolved in the course of the <a href="/wiki/Algerian_War" title="Algerian War">Algerian War</a>. The current <a href="/wiki/French_Fifth_Republic" title="French Fifth Republic">Fifth Republic</a> was formed in 1958 by <a href="/wiki/Charles_de_Gaulle" title="Charles de Gaulle">Charles de Gaulle</a>. Algeria and most French colonies became independent in the 1960s, with the majority retaining <a href="/wiki/Fran%C3%A7afrique" title="Françafrique">close economic and military ties with France</a>.
</p><p>France retains its centuries-long status as a global centre of <a href="/wiki/French_art" title="French art">art</a>, <a href="/wiki/List_of_French_scientists" title="List of French scientists">science</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_French_philosophers" title="List of French philosophers">philosophy</a>. It <a href="/wiki/List_of_World_Heritage_Sites_in_France" title="List of World Heritage Sites in France">hosts</a> the fifth-largest number of UNESCO <a href="/wiki/World_Heritage_Site" title="World Heritage Site">World Heritage Sites</a> and is the world's leading tourist destination, receiving over 89 million foreign <a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_France" title="Tourism in France">visitors</a> in 2018.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-29"><a href="#cite_note-29">[17]</a></sup> France is a <a href="/wiki/Developed_country" title="Developed country">developed country</a> with the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(nominal)" title="List of countries by GDP (nominal)">seventh-largest economy by nominal GDP</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(PPP)" title="List of countries by GDP (PPP)">tenth-largest by PPP</a>; in terms of aggregate household wealth, it ranks fourth in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-30"><a href="#cite_note-30">[18]</a></sup> France performs well in <a href="/wiki/International_rankings_of_France" title="International rankings of France">international rankings</a> of <a href="/wiki/Education_Index" title="Education Index">education</a>, <a href="/wiki/Health_care_in_France" title="Health care in France">health care</a>, <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_life_expectancy" title="List of countries by life expectancy">life expectancy</a> and <a href="/wiki/Human_Development_Index" title="Human Development Index">human development</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-31"><a href="#cite_note-31">[19]</a></sup> It remains a <a href="/wiki/Great_power" title="Great power">great power</a> in global affairs,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-32"><a href="#cite_note-32">[20]</a></sup> being one of the five <a href="/wiki/Permanent_members_of_the_United_Nations_Security_Council" title="Permanent members of the United Nations Security Council">permanent members of the United Nations Security Council</a> and an official <a href="/wiki/List_of_states_with_nuclear_weapons" title="List of states with nuclear weapons">nuclear-weapon state</a>. France is a founding and <a href="/wiki/Big_Four_(Western_Europe)" title="Big Four (Western Europe)">leading</a> <a href="/wiki/Member_state_of_the_European_Union" title="Member state of the European Union">member of the European Union</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Eurozone" title="Eurozone">Eurozone</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-superficy_33-0"><a href="#cite_note-superficy-33">[21]</a></sup> as well as a key member of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Group_of_Seven" title="Group of Seven">Group of Seven</a>, <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">North Atlantic Treaty Organization</a> (NATO), <a href="/wiki/OECD" title="OECD">Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development</a> (OECD) and <a href="/wiki/Organisation_internationale_de_la_Francophonie" title="Organisation internationale de la Francophonie">La Francophonie</a>.
</p>
<div aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading" class="toc" id="toc" role="navigation"><input class="toctogglecheckbox" id="toctogglecheckbox" role="button" style="display:none" type="checkbox"/><div class="toctitle" dir="ltr" lang="en"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Etymology_and_pronunciation">Etymology and pronunciation</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Name_of_France" title="Name of France">Name of France</a></div>
<p>Originally applied to the whole <a href="/wiki/Francia" title="Francia">Frankish Empire</a>, the name <i>France</i> comes from the <a href="/wiki/Latin" title="Latin">Latin</a> <span title="Latin-language text"><i lang="la"><a href="/wiki/Francia" title="Francia">Francia</a></i></span>, or "realm of the <a href="/wiki/Franks" title="Franks">Franks</a>".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-34"><a href="#cite_note-34">[22]</a></sup> Modern France is still named today <span title="Italian-language text"><i lang="it">Francia</i></span> in Italian and Spanish, while <span title="German-language text"><i lang="de">Frankreich</i></span> in German, <span title="Dutch-language text"><i lang="nl">Frankrijk</i></span> in Dutch and <span title="Swedish-language text"><i lang="sv">Frankrike</i></span> in Swedish all mean "Land/realm of the Franks".
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Name_of_the_Franks" title="Name of the Franks">name of the Franks</a> is related to the English word <i>frank</i> ("free"): the latter stems from the <a href="/wiki/Old_French" title="Old French">Old French</a> <i>franc</i> ("free, noble, sincere"), ultimately from <a href="/wiki/Medieval_Latin" title="Medieval Latin">Medieval Latin</a> <i>francus</i> ("free, exempt from service; freeman, Frank"), a generalisation of the tribal name that emerged as a <a href="/wiki/Late_Latin" title="Late Latin">Late Latin</a> borrowing of the reconstructed <a href="/wiki/Frankish_language" title="Frankish language">Frankish</a> <a href="/wiki/Endonym_and_exonym" title="Endonym and exonym">endonym</a> <i>*Frank</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-35"><a href="#cite_note-35">[23]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:0_36-0"><a href="#cite_note-:0-36">[24]</a></sup> It has been suggested that the meaning "free" was adopted because, after the conquest of Gaul, only Franks were free of taxation,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-37"><a href="#cite_note-37">[25]</a></sup> or more generally because they had the status of freemen in contrast to servants or slaves.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:0_36-1"><a href="#cite_note-:0-36">[24]</a></sup>
</p><p>The etymology of <i>*Frank</i> is uncertain. It is traditionally derived from the <a href="/wiki/Proto-Germanic_language" title="Proto-Germanic language">Proto-Germanic</a> word <span title="Proto-Germanic-language text">*<i lang="gem">frankōn</i></span>, which translates as "javelin" or "lance" (the throwing axe of the Franks was known as the <i><a href="/wiki/Francisca" title="Francisca">francisca</a></i>),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-38"><a href="#cite_note-38">[26]</a></sup> although these weapons may have been named because of their use by the Franks, not the other way around.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:0_36-2"><a href="#cite_note-:0-36">[24]</a></sup>
</p><p>In English, 'France' is pronounced <span class="rt-commentedText nowrap"><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt" lang="en-fonipa"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="'f' in 'find'">f</span><span title="'r' in 'rye'">r</span><span title="/æ/: 'a' in 'bad'">æ</span><span title="'n' in 'nigh'">n</span><span title="'s' in 'sigh'">s</span></span>/</a></span></span> <a href="/wiki/Help:Pronunciation_respelling_key" title="Help:Pronunciation respelling key"><i title="English pronunciation respelling"><span style="font-size:90%">FRANSS</span></i></a> in American English and <span class="rt-commentedText nowrap"><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt" lang="en-fonipa"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="'f' in 'find'">f</span><span title="'r' in 'rye'">r</span><span title="/ɑː/: 'a' in 'father'">ɑː</span><span title="'n' in 'nigh'">n</span><span title="'s' in 'sigh'">s</span></span>/</a></span></span> <a href="/wiki/Help:Pronunciation_respelling_key" title="Help:Pronunciation respelling key"><i title="English pronunciation respelling"><span style="font-size:90%">FRAHNSS</span></i></a> or <span class="rt-commentedText nowrap"><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt" lang="en-fonipa"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="'f' in 'find'">f</span><span title="'r' in 'rye'">r</span><span title="/æ/: 'a' in 'bad'">æ</span><span title="'n' in 'nigh'">n</span><span title="'s' in 'sigh'">s</span></span>/</a></span></span> <a href="/wiki/Help:Pronunciation_respelling_key" title="Help:Pronunciation respelling key"><i title="English pronunciation respelling"><span style="font-size:90%">FRANSS</span></i></a> in British English. The pronunciation with <span class="rt-commentedText nowrap"><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt" lang="en-fonipa"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/ɑː/: 'a' in 'father'">ɑː</span></span>/</a></span></span> is mostly confined to accents with the <a href="/wiki/Trap%E2%80%93bath_split" title="Trap–bath split">trap-bath split</a> such as <a href="/wiki/Received_Pronunciation" title="Received Pronunciation">Received Pronunciation</a>, though it can be also heard in some other dialects such as <a href="/wiki/Cardiff_English" title="Cardiff English">Cardiff English</a>, in which <span class="rt-commentedText nowrap"><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt" lang="en-fonipa"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="'f' in 'find'">f</span><span title="'r' in 'rye'">r</span><span title="/ɑː/: 'a' in 'father'">ɑː</span><span title="'n' in 'nigh'">n</span><span title="'s' in 'sigh'">s</span></span>/</a></span></span> is in free variation with <span class="rt-commentedText nowrap"><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt" lang="en-fonipa"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="'f' in 'find'">f</span><span title="'r' in 'rye'">r</span><span title="/æ/: 'a' in 'bad'">æ</span><span title="'n' in 'nigh'">n</span><span title="'s' in 'sigh'">s</span></span>/</a></span></span>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-39"><a href="#cite_note-39">[27]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_France" title="History of France">History of France</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">For a chronological guide, see <a href="/wiki/Timeline_of_French_history" title="Timeline of French history">Timeline of French history</a>.</div>
<h3><span id="Prehistory_.28before_the_6th_century_BC.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Prehistory_(before_the_6th_century_BC)">Prehistory (before the 6th century BC)</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Prehistory_of_France" title="Prehistory of France">Prehistory of France</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Lascaux2.jpg"><img alt="Lascaux cave paintings: a horse from Dordogne facing right brown on white background" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="450" data-file-width="598" decoding="async" height="166" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Lascaux2.jpg/220px-Lascaux2.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Lascaux2.jpg/330px-Lascaux2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Lascaux2.jpg/440px-Lascaux2.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Lascaux2.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>One of the <a href="/wiki/Lascaux" title="Lascaux">Lascaux</a> paintings: a horse – approximately 17,000 BC. Lascaux is famous for its "exceptionally detailed depictions of humans and animals".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-40"><a href="#cite_note-40">[28]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>The oldest traces of human life in what is now France date from approximately 1.8 million years ago.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Jean_Carpentier_1987_p.17_41-0"><a href="#cite_note-Jean_Carpentier_1987_p.17-41">[29]</a></sup> Over the ensuing millennia, <a href="/wiki/Human" title="Human">humans</a> were confronted by a harsh and variable climate, marked by several <a href="/wiki/Glacial_period" title="Glacial period">glacial periods</a>. Early hominids led a <a href="/wiki/Nomad" title="Nomad">nomadic</a> <a href="/wiki/Hunter-gatherer" title="Hunter-gatherer">hunter-gatherer</a> life.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Jean_Carpentier_1987_p.17_41-1"><a href="#cite_note-Jean_Carpentier_1987_p.17-41">[29]</a></sup> France has a large number of decorated caves from the <a href="/wiki/Upper_Paleolithic" title="Upper Paleolithic">upper Palaeolithic</a> era, including one of the most famous and best-preserved, <a href="/wiki/Lascaux" title="Lascaux">Lascaux</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Jean_Carpentier_1987_p.17_41-2"><a href="#cite_note-Jean_Carpentier_1987_p.17-41">[29]</a></sup> (approximately 18,000 BC). At the end of the <a href="/wiki/Last_Glacial_Period" title="Last Glacial Period">last glacial period</a> (10,000 BC), the climate became milder;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Jean_Carpentier_1987_p.17_41-3"><a href="#cite_note-Jean_Carpentier_1987_p.17-41">[29]</a></sup> from approximately 7,000 BC, this part of Western Europe entered the <a href="/wiki/Neolithic" title="Neolithic">Neolithic</a> era and its inhabitants became <a href="/wiki/Sedentism" title="Sedentism">sedentary</a>.
</p><p>After strong demographic and agricultural development between the 4th and 3rd millennia, metallurgy appeared at the end of the 3rd millennium, initially working gold, copper and bronze, as well as later iron.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-42"><a href="#cite_note-42">[30]</a></sup> France has numerous <a href="/wiki/Megalith" title="Megalith">megalithic</a> sites from the Neolithic period, including the exceptionally dense <a href="/wiki/Carnac_stones" title="Carnac stones">Carnac stones</a> site (approximately 3,300 BC).
</p>
<h3><span id="Antiquity_.286th_century_BC.E2.80.935th_century_AD.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Antiquity_(6th_century_BC–5th_century_AD)">Antiquity (6th century BC–5th century AD)</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Gaul" title="Gaul">Gaul</a>, <a href="/wiki/Celts" title="Celts">Celts</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Roman_Gaul" title="Roman Gaul">Roman Gaul</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Siege-alesia-vercingetorix-jules-cesar.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1469" data-file-width="2204" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/93/Siege-alesia-vercingetorix-jules-cesar.jpg/220px-Siege-alesia-vercingetorix-jules-cesar.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/93/Siege-alesia-vercingetorix-jules-cesar.jpg/330px-Siege-alesia-vercingetorix-jules-cesar.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/93/Siege-alesia-vercingetorix-jules-cesar.jpg/440px-Siege-alesia-vercingetorix-jules-cesar.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Siege-alesia-vercingetorix-jules-cesar.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Vercingetorix" title="Vercingetorix">Vercingetorix</a> surrenders to <a href="/wiki/Julius_Caesar" title="Julius Caesar">Caesar</a> during the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Alesia" title="Battle of Alesia">Battle of Alesia</a>. The Gallic defeat in the <a href="/wiki/Gallic_Wars" title="Gallic Wars">Gallic Wars</a> secured the <a href="/wiki/Roman_Republic" title="Roman Republic">Roman</a> conquest of the country.</div></div></div>
<p>In 600 BC, <a href="/wiki/Ionia" title="Ionia">Ionian</a> <a href="/wiki/Greeks_in_pre-Roman_Gaul" title="Greeks in pre-Roman Gaul">Greeks</a> from <a href="/wiki/Phocaea" title="Phocaea">Phocaea</a> founded the <a href="/wiki/Greek_colonisation" title="Greek colonisation">colony</a> of <a href="/wiki/Massalia" title="Massalia">Massalia</a> (present-day <a href="/wiki/Marseille" title="Marseille">Marseille</a>), on the shores of the <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_Sea" title="Mediterranean Sea">Mediterranean Sea</a>. This makes it France's oldest city.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-43"><a href="#cite_note-43">[31]</a></sup> At the same time, some Gallic Celtic tribes penetrated parts of Eastern and Northern France, gradually spreading through the rest of the country between the 5th and 3rd century BC.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-44"><a href="#cite_note-44">[32]</a></sup> The concept of <a href="/wiki/Gaul" title="Gaul">Gaul</a> emerged during this period, corresponding to the territories of Celtic settlement ranging between the <a href="/wiki/Rhine" title="Rhine">Rhine</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Atlantic_Ocean" title="Atlantic Ocean">Atlantic Ocean</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Pyrenees" title="Pyrenees">Pyrenees</a> and the Mediterranean. The borders of modern France roughly correspond to ancient Gaul, which was inhabited by Celtic <i>Gauls</i>. Gaul was then a prosperous country, of which the southernmost part was heavily subject to Greek and Roman cultural and economic influences.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Maison_Carr%C3%A9e_2.jpg"><img alt="Maison Carrée temple in Nemausus Corinthian columns and portico" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1371" data-file-width="2048" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6a/Maison_Carr%C3%A9e_2.jpg/220px-Maison_Carr%C3%A9e_2.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6a/Maison_Carr%C3%A9e_2.jpg/330px-Maison_Carr%C3%A9e_2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6a/Maison_Carr%C3%A9e_2.jpg/440px-Maison_Carr%C3%A9e_2.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Maison_Carr%C3%A9e_2.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Maison_Carr%C3%A9e" title="Maison Carrée">Maison Carrée</a> was a temple of the <a href="/wiki/Gallo-Roman_culture" title="Gallo-Roman culture">Gallo-Roman</a> city of Nemausus (present-day <a href="/wiki/N%C3%AEmes" title="Nîmes">Nîmes</a>) and is one of the best-preserved vestiges of the <a href="/wiki/Roman_Empire" title="Roman Empire">Roman Empire</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>Around 390 BC, the Gallic <a href="/wiki/Tribal_chief" title="Tribal chief">chieftain</a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Brennus_(4th_century_BC)" title="Brennus (4th century BC)">Brennus</a> and his troops made their way to Italy through the <a href="/wiki/Alps" title="Alps">Alps</a>, defeated the Romans in the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_the_Allia" title="Battle of the Allia">Battle of the Allia</a>, and besieged and <a href="/wiki/Ransom" title="Ransom">ransomed</a> Rome.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-45"><a href="#cite_note-45">[33]</a></sup> The Gallic invasion left Rome weakened, and the Gauls continued to harass the region until 345 BC when they entered into a formal peace treaty with Rome.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-46"><a href="#cite_note-46">[34]</a></sup> But the Romans and the Gauls would remain adversaries for the next centuries, and the Gauls would continue to be a threat in <a href="/wiki/Roman_Italy" title="Roman Italy">Italy</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-47"><a href="#cite_note-47">[35]</a></sup>
</p><p>Around 125 BC, the south of Gaul was conquered by the Romans, who called this region <span title="Latin-language text"><i lang="la"><a href="/wiki/Gallia_Narbonensis" title="Gallia Narbonensis">Provincia Nostra</a></i></span> ("Our Province"), which over time evolved into the name <a href="/wiki/Provence" title="Provence">Provence</a> in French.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-48"><a href="#cite_note-48">[36]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Julius_Caesar" title="Julius Caesar">Julius Caesar</a> conquered the remainder of Gaul and overcame a revolt carried out by the Gallic chieftain <a href="/wiki/Vercingetorix" title="Vercingetorix">Vercingetorix</a> in 52 BC.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-49"><a href="#cite_note-49">[37]</a></sup>
</p><p>Gaul was divided by <a href="/wiki/Augustus" title="Augustus">Augustus</a> into Roman provinces.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-c53_50-0"><a href="#cite_note-c53-50">[38]</a></sup> Many cities were founded during the <a href="/wiki/Roman_Gaul" title="Roman Gaul">Gallo-Roman period</a>, including <a href="/wiki/Lugdunum" title="Lugdunum">Lugdunum</a> (present-day <a href="/wiki/Lyon" title="Lyon">Lyon</a>), which is considered the capital of the Gauls.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-c53_50-1"><a href="#cite_note-c53-50">[38]</a></sup> These cities were built in traditional Roman style, with a <a href="/wiki/Roman_Forum" title="Roman Forum">forum</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Roman_theatre_(structure)" title="Roman theatre (structure)">theatre</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Roman_circus" title="Roman circus">circus</a>, an <a href="/wiki/Amphitheatre" title="Amphitheatre">amphitheatre</a> and <a href="/wiki/Spa" title="Spa">thermal baths</a>. The Gauls mixed with Roman settlers and eventually adopted Roman culture and <a href="/wiki/Romance_languages" title="Romance languages">Roman</a> speech (<a href="/wiki/Latin" title="Latin">Latin</a>, from which the French language evolved). The <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_ancient_Rome" title="Religion in ancient Rome">Roman polytheism</a> merged with the <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Celtic_religion" title="Ancient Celtic religion">Gallic paganism</a> into the same <a href="/wiki/Syncretism" title="Syncretism">syncretism</a>.
</p><p>From the 250s to the 280s AD, Roman Gaul suffered a serious crisis with its <a href="/wiki/Limes_(Roman_Empire)" title="Limes (Roman Empire)">fortified borders</a> being attacked on several occasions by <a href="/wiki/Barbarian" title="Barbarian">barbarians</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-c77_51-0"><a href="#cite_note-c77-51">[39]</a></sup> Nevertheless, the situation improved in the first half of the 4th century, which was a period of revival and prosperity for Roman Gaul.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-52"><a href="#cite_note-52">[40]</a></sup> In 312, Emperor <a href="/wiki/Constantine_the_Great" title="Constantine the Great">Constantine I</a> converted to Christianity. Subsequently, Christians, who had been persecuted until then, increased rapidly across the entire Roman Empire.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-53"><a href="#cite_note-53">[41]</a></sup> But, from the beginning of the 5th century, the <a href="/wiki/Migration_Period" title="Migration Period">Barbarian Invasions</a> resumed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-54"><a href="#cite_note-54">[42]</a></sup> Teutonic tribes invaded the region from present-day Germany, the <a href="/wiki/Visigoths" title="Visigoths">Visigoths</a> settling in the southwest, the <a href="/wiki/Burgundians" title="Burgundians">Burgundians</a> along the Rhine River Valley, and the <a href="/wiki/Franks" title="Franks">Franks</a> (from whom the French take their name) in the north.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-55"><a href="#cite_note-55">[43]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="Early_Middle_Ages_.285th.E2.80.9310th_century.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_Middle_Ages_(5th–10th_century)">Early Middle Ages (5th–10th century)</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Francia" title="Francia">Francia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Merovingian_dynasty" title="Merovingian dynasty">Merovingian dynasty</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Carolingian_dynasty" title="Carolingian dynasty">Carolingian dynasty</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/List_of_French_monarchs" title="List of French monarchs">List of French monarchs</a> and <a href="/wiki/France_in_the_Middle_Ages" title="France in the Middle Ages">France in the Middle Ages</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Franks_expansion.gif"><img alt="animated gif showing expansion of Franks across Europe" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="505" data-file-width="790" decoding="async" height="141" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/23/Franks_expansion.gif/220px-Franks_expansion.gif" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/23/Franks_expansion.gif/330px-Franks_expansion.gif 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/23/Franks_expansion.gif/440px-Franks_expansion.gif 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Franks_expansion.gif" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Frankish expansion from 481 to 870</div></div></div>
<p>At the end of the <a href="/wiki/Late_antiquity" title="Late antiquity">Antiquity</a> period, ancient Gaul was divided into several Germanic kingdoms and a remaining Gallo-Roman territory, known as the <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Soissons" title="Kingdom of Soissons">Kingdom of Syagrius</a>. Simultaneously, <a href="/wiki/Celtic_Britons" title="Celtic Britons">Celtic Britons</a>, fleeing the <a href="/wiki/Anglo-Saxon_settlement_of_Britain" title="Anglo-Saxon settlement of Britain">Anglo-Saxon settlement of Britain</a>, settled the western part of <a href="/wiki/Armorica" title="Armorica">Armorica</a>. As a result, the Armorican <a href="/wiki/Peninsula" title="Peninsula">peninsula</a> was renamed <a href="/wiki/Brittany" title="Brittany">Brittany</a>, <a href="/wiki/Celts" title="Celts">Celtic culture</a> was revived and independent <a href="/wiki/Petty_kingdom" title="Petty kingdom">petty kingdoms</a> arose in this region.
</p><p>The first leader to make himself king of all the Franks was <a href="/wiki/Clovis_I" title="Clovis I">Clovis I</a>, who began his reign in 481, routing the last forces of the Roman governors of the province in 486. Clovis claimed that he would be baptised a Christian in the event of his victory against the <a href="/wiki/Visigothic_Kingdom" title="Visigothic Kingdom">Visigoths</a>, which was said to have guaranteed the battle. Clovis <a href="/wiki/Franco-Visigothic_Wars" title="Franco-Visigothic Wars">regained the southwest from the Visigoths</a>, was baptised in 508, and made himself master of what is now western Germany.
</p><p>Clovis I was the first <a href="/wiki/Germanic_peoples" title="Germanic peoples">Germanic</a> conqueror after the fall of the Roman Empire to convert to Catholic Christianity, rather than <a href="/wiki/Arianism" title="Arianism">Arianism</a>; thus France was given the title "Eldest daughter of the Church" (<i>French: <i lang="fr">La fille aînée de l'Église</i></i>) by the papacy,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-56"><a href="#cite_note-56">[44]</a></sup> and French kings would be called "the Most Christian Kings of France" (<i><span title="undetermined-language text"><i lang="und">Rex Christianissimus</i></span></i>).
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Chlodwigs_taufe.jpg"><img alt="painting of Clovis I conversion to Catholicism in 498, a king being baptised in a tub in a cathedral surrounded by bishop and monks" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="4000" data-file-width="2969" decoding="async" height="229" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/Chlodwigs_taufe.jpg/170px-Chlodwigs_taufe.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/Chlodwigs_taufe.jpg/255px-Chlodwigs_taufe.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/Chlodwigs_taufe.jpg/340px-Chlodwigs_taufe.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Chlodwigs_taufe.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>With <a href="/wiki/Clovis_I" title="Clovis I">Clovis</a>'s conversion to Catholicism in 498, the <a href="/wiki/List_of_Frankish_kings" title="List of Frankish kings">Frankish monarchy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Elective_monarchy" title="Elective monarchy">elective</a> and <a href="/wiki/Secular_state" title="Secular state">secular</a> until then, became <a href="/wiki/Hereditary_monarchy" title="Hereditary monarchy">hereditary</a> and of <a href="/wiki/Divine_right_of_kings" title="Divine right of kings">divine right</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>The Franks embraced the Christian <a href="/wiki/Gallo-Roman_culture" title="Gallo-Roman culture">Gallo-Roman culture</a> and ancient Gaul was eventually renamed <i><a href="/wiki/Francia" title="Francia">Francia</a></i> ("Land of the Franks"). The Germanic Franks adopted <a href="/wiki/Romance_languages" title="Romance languages">Romanic languages</a>, except in northern Gaul where Roman settlements were less dense and where <a href="/wiki/Germanic_languages" title="Germanic languages">Germanic languages</a> emerged. Clovis made Paris his capital and established the <a href="/wiki/Merovingian_dynasty" title="Merovingian dynasty">Merovingian dynasty</a>, but his kingdom would not survive his death. The Franks treated land purely as a private possession and divided it among their heirs, so four kingdoms emerged from Clovis's: Paris, <a href="/wiki/Orl%C3%A9ans" title="Orléans">Orléans</a>, <a href="/wiki/Soissons" title="Soissons">Soissons</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Reims" title="Reims">Rheims</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Roi_fain%C3%A9ant" title="Roi fainéant">last Merovingian kings</a> <a href="/wiki/Power_behind_the_throne" title="Power behind the throne">lost power</a> to their <a href="/wiki/Mayor_of_the_palace" title="Mayor of the palace">mayors of the palace</a> (head of household). One mayor of the palace, <a href="/wiki/Charles_Martel" title="Charles Martel">Charles Martel</a>, defeated an <a href="/wiki/Umayyad_invasion_of_Gaul" title="Umayyad invasion of Gaul">Umayyad invasion of Gaul</a> at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Tours" title="Battle of Tours">Battle of Tours</a> (732) and earned respect and power within the Frankish kingdoms. His son, <a href="/wiki/Pepin_the_Short" title="Pepin the Short">Pepin the Short</a>, seized the crown of Francia from the weakened Merovingians and founded the <a href="/wiki/Carolingian_dynasty" title="Carolingian dynasty">Carolingian dynasty</a>. Pepin's son, <a href="/wiki/Charlemagne" title="Charlemagne">Charlemagne</a>, reunited the Frankish kingdoms and built a vast empire across <a href="/wiki/Western_Europe" title="Western Europe">Western</a> and Central Europe.
</p><p>Proclaimed <a href="/wiki/Holy_Roman_Emperor" title="Holy Roman Emperor">Holy Roman Emperor</a> by <a href="/wiki/Pope_Leo_III" title="Pope Leo III">Pope Leo III</a> and thus establishing in earnest the French Government's longtime <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Catholic_Church_in_France" title="History of the Catholic Church in France">historical association</a> with the <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church" title="Catholic Church">Catholic Church</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-georgetown1_57-0"><a href="#cite_note-georgetown1-57">[45]</a></sup> Charlemagne tried to revive the <a href="/wiki/Western_Roman_Empire" title="Western Roman Empire">Western Roman Empire</a> and its cultural grandeur. Charlemagne's son, <a href="/wiki/Louis_the_Pious" title="Louis the Pious">Louis I</a> (Emperor 814–840), kept the empire united; however, this Carolingian Empire would not survive his death. In 843, under the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Verdun" title="Treaty of Verdun">Treaty of Verdun</a>, the empire was divided between Louis' three sons, with <a href="/wiki/East_Francia" title="East Francia">East Francia</a> going to <a href="/wiki/Louis_the_German" title="Louis the German">Louis the German</a>, <a href="/wiki/Middle_Francia" title="Middle Francia">Middle Francia</a> to <a href="/wiki/Lothair_I" title="Lothair I">Lothair I</a>, and <a href="/wiki/West_Francia" title="West Francia">West Francia</a> to <a href="/wiki/Charles_the_Bald" title="Charles the Bald">Charles the Bald</a>. West Francia approximated the area occupied by–and was the precursor to–modern France.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-58"><a href="#cite_note-58">[46]</a></sup>
</p><p>During the 9th and 10th centuries, continually threatened by <a href="/wiki/Viking_expansion" title="Viking expansion">Viking invasions</a>, France became a very decentralised state: the nobility's titles and lands became hereditary, and the authority of the king became more religious than secular and thus was less effective and constantly challenged by powerful noblemen. Thus was established <a href="/wiki/Feudalism" title="Feudalism">feudalism</a> in France. Over time, some of the king's vassals would grow so powerful that they often posed a threat to the king. For example, after the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Hastings" title="Battle of Hastings">Battle of Hastings</a> in 1066, <a href="/wiki/William_the_Conqueror" title="William the Conqueror">William the Conqueror</a> added "King of England" to his titles, becoming both the vassal to (as Duke of <a href="/wiki/Normandy" title="Normandy">Normandy</a>) and the equal of (as king of England) the king of France, creating recurring tensions.
</p>
<h3><span id="High_and_Late_Middle_Ages_.2810th.E2.80.9315th_century.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="High_and_Late_Middle_Ages_(10th–15th_century)">High and Late Middle Ages (10th–15th century)</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_France" title="Kingdom of France">Kingdom of France</a>, <a href="/wiki/Capetian_dynasty" title="Capetian dynasty">Capetian dynasty</a>, <a href="/wiki/House_of_Valois" title="House of Valois">House of Valois</a>, and <a href="/wiki/House_of_Bourbon" title="House of Bourbon">House of Bourbon</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/List_of_French_monarchs" title="List of French monarchs">List of French monarchs</a> and <a href="/wiki/France_in_the_Middle_Ages" title="France in the Middle Ages">France in the Middle Ages</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Joan_of_Arc_miniature_graded.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2700" data-file-width="1812" decoding="async" height="328" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c3/Joan_of_Arc_miniature_graded.jpg/220px-Joan_of_Arc_miniature_graded.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c3/Joan_of_Arc_miniature_graded.jpg/330px-Joan_of_Arc_miniature_graded.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c3/Joan_of_Arc_miniature_graded.jpg/440px-Joan_of_Arc_miniature_graded.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Joan_of_Arc_miniature_graded.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Joan_of_Arc" title="Joan of Arc">Joan of Arc</a> led the <a href="/wiki/French_Army" title="French Army">French Army</a> to several important victories during the <a href="/wiki/Hundred_Years%27_War" title="Hundred Years' War">Hundred Years' War</a> (1337–1453), which paved the way for the final victory.</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:French_borders_from_985_to_1947.gif"><img alt="animated gif showing changes in French borders" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="430" data-file-width="466" decoding="async" height="203" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/French_borders_from_985_to_1947.gif/220px-French_borders_from_985_to_1947.gif" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/French_borders_from_985_to_1947.gif/330px-French_borders_from_985_to_1947.gif 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/French_borders_from_985_to_1947.gif/440px-French_borders_from_985_to_1947.gif 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:French_borders_from_985_to_1947.gif" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Territorial_evolution_of_France" title="Territorial evolution of France">Metropolitan France territorial evolution</a> from 985 to 1947</div></div></div>
<p>The Carolingian dynasty ruled France until 987, when <a href="/wiki/Hugh_Capet" title="Hugh Capet">Hugh Capet</a>, Duke of France and Count of Paris, was crowned <a href="/wiki/List_of_French_monarchs" title="List of French monarchs">King of the Franks</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-59"><a href="#cite_note-59">[47]</a></sup> His descendants—the <a href="/wiki/House_of_Capet" title="House of Capet">Capetians</a>, the <a href="/wiki/House_of_Valois" title="House of Valois">House of Valois</a> and the <a href="/wiki/House_of_Bourbon" title="House of Bourbon">House of Bourbon</a>—progressively unified the country through wars and dynastic inheritance into the Kingdom of France, which was fully declared in 1190 by <a href="/wiki/Philip_II_of_France" title="Philip II of France">Philip II of France</a> (<i>Philippe Auguste</i>). Later kings would expand their directly possessed <a href="/wiki/Crown_lands_of_France" title="Crown lands of France"><i>domaine royal</i></a> to cover over half of modern continental France by the 15th century, including most of the north, centre and west of France. During this process, the royal authority became more and more assertive, centred on a <a href="/wiki/Estates_of_the_realm" title="Estates of the realm">hierarchically conceived society</a> distinguishing <a href="/wiki/French_nobility" title="French nobility">nobility</a>, clergy, and <a href="/wiki/Estates_General_(France)" title="Estates General (France)">commoners</a>.
</p><p>The French nobility played a prominent role in most <a href="/wiki/Crusades" title="Crusades">Crusades</a> to restore Christian access to the <a href="/wiki/Holy_Land" title="Holy Land">Holy Land</a>. French knights made up the bulk of the steady flow of reinforcements throughout the two-hundred-year span of the Crusades, in such a fashion that the Arabs uniformly referred to the crusaders as <i>Franj</i> caring little whether they really came from France.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-google.fr_60-0"><a href="#cite_note-google.fr-60">[48]</a></sup> The French Crusaders also imported the French language into the <a href="/wiki/Levant" title="Levant">Levant</a>, making <a href="/wiki/Old_French" title="Old French">French</a> the base of the <i><a href="/wiki/Lingua_franca" title="Lingua franca">lingua franca</a></i> (lit. "Frankish language") of the <a href="/wiki/Crusader_states" title="Crusader states">Crusader states</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-google.fr_60-1"><a href="#cite_note-google.fr-60">[48]</a></sup> French knights also made up the majority in both the <a href="/wiki/Knights_Hospitaller" title="Knights Hospitaller">Hospital</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Knights_Templar" title="Knights Templar">Temple orders</a>. The latter, in particular, held numerous properties throughout France and by the 13th century were the principal bankers for the French crown, until <a href="/wiki/Philip_IV_of_France" title="Philip IV of France">Philip IV</a> annihilated the order in 1307. The <a href="/wiki/Albigensian_Crusade" title="Albigensian Crusade">Albigensian Crusade</a> was launched in 1209 to eliminate the heretical <a href="/wiki/Catharism" title="Catharism">Cathars</a> in the southwestern area of modern-day France. In the end, the Cathars were exterminated and the autonomous <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Counts_of_Toulouse" title="Counts of Toulouse">County of Toulouse</a> was annexed into the <a href="/wiki/Crown_lands_of_France" title="Crown lands of France">crown lands of France</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-61"><a href="#cite_note-61">[49]</a></sup>
</p><p>From the 11th century, the House of Plantagenet, the rulers of the <a href="/wiki/County_of_Anjou" title="County of Anjou">County of Anjou</a>, succeeded in establishing its dominion over the surrounding provinces of <a href="/wiki/Maine_(province)" title="Maine (province)">Maine</a> and <a href="/wiki/Touraine" title="Touraine">Touraine</a>, then progressively built an "empire" that spanned from England to the <a href="/wiki/Pyrenees" title="Pyrenees">Pyrenees</a> and covering half of modern France. Tensions between the kingdom of France and the <a href="/wiki/Angevin_Empire" title="Angevin Empire">Plantagenet empire</a> would last a hundred years, until Philip II of France conquered, between 1202 and 1214, most of the continental possessions of the empire, leaving England and <a href="/wiki/Aquitaine" title="Aquitaine">Aquitaine</a> to the Plantagenets.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Charles_IV_of_France" title="Charles IV of France">Charles IV the Fair</a> died without an heir in 1328.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-guerard_62-0"><a href="#cite_note-guerard-62">[50]</a></sup> Under <a href="/wiki/Salic_law" title="Salic law">Salic law</a> the crown of France could not pass to a woman nor could the line of kingship pass through the female line.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-guerard_62-1"><a href="#cite_note-guerard-62">[50]</a></sup> Accordingly, the crown passed to Philip of Valois, rather than through the female line to Edward of Plantagenet, who would soon become <a href="/wiki/Edward_III_of_England" title="Edward III of England">Edward III of England</a>. During the reign of <a href="/wiki/Philip_IV_of_France" title="Philip IV of France">Philip of Valois</a>, the French monarchy reached the height of its medieval power.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-guerard_62-2"><a href="#cite_note-guerard-62">[50]</a></sup> However Philip's seat on the throne was contested by Edward III of England in 1337, and England and France entered the off-and-on <a href="/wiki/Hundred_Years%27_War" title="Hundred Years' War">Hundred Years' War</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-63"><a href="#cite_note-63">[51]</a></sup> The exact boundaries changed greatly with time, but landholdings inside France by the English Kings remained extensive for decades. With charismatic leaders, such as <a href="/wiki/Joan_of_Arc" title="Joan of Arc">Joan of Arc</a> and <a href="/wiki/La_Hire" title="La Hire">La Hire</a>, strong French counterattacks won back most English continental territories. Like the rest of Europe, France was struck by the Black Death due to which half of the 17 million population of France died.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-64"><a href="#cite_note-64">[52]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="Early_modern_period_.2815th_century.E2.80.931789.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_modern_period_(15th_century–1789)">Early modern period (15th century–1789)</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/French_Renaissance" title="French Renaissance">French Renaissance</a>, <a href="/wiki/Early_modern_France" title="Early modern France">Early modern France</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Ancien_R%C3%A9gime" title="Ancien Régime">Ancien Régime</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Chateau_de_Chenonceau_2008E.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2800" data-file-width="5208" decoding="async" height="118" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d0/Chateau_de_Chenonceau_2008E.jpg/220px-Chateau_de_Chenonceau_2008E.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d0/Chateau_de_Chenonceau_2008E.jpg/330px-Chateau_de_Chenonceau_2008E.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d0/Chateau_de_Chenonceau_2008E.jpg/440px-Chateau_de_Chenonceau_2008E.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Chateau_de_Chenonceau_2008E.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Ch%C3%A2teau_de_Chenonceau" title="Château de Chenonceau">Château de Chenonceau</a>, nowadays part of a <a href="/wiki/UNESCO" title="UNESCO">UNESCO</a> <a href="/wiki/World_Heritage_Site" title="World Heritage Site">World Heritage Site</a>, was built in the early 16th century.</div></div></div>
<p>The French Renaissance saw a spectacular cultural development and the first standardisation of the French language, which would become the <a href="/wiki/Ordinance_of_Villers-Cotter%C3%AAts" title="Ordinance of Villers-Cotterêts">official language of France</a> and the language of Europe's aristocracy. It also saw a long set of wars, known as the <a href="/wiki/Italian_Wars" title="Italian Wars">Italian Wars</a>, between France and the <a href="/wiki/House_of_Habsburg" title="House of Habsburg">House of Habsburg</a>. French explorers, such as <a href="/wiki/Jacques_Cartier" title="Jacques Cartier">Jacques Cartier</a> or <a href="/wiki/Samuel_de_Champlain" title="Samuel de Champlain">Samuel de Champlain</a>, claimed lands in the Americas for France, paving the way for the expansion of the <a href="/wiki/French_colonial_empire" title="French colonial empire">First French colonial empire</a>. The rise of Protestantism in Europe led France to a civil war known as the <a href="/wiki/French_Wars_of_Religion" title="French Wars of Religion">French Wars of Religion</a>, where, in the most notorious incident, thousands of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Huguenot" title="Huguenot">Huguenots</a> were murdered in the <a href="/wiki/St._Bartholomew%27s_Day_massacre" title="St. Bartholomew's Day massacre">St. Bartholomew's Day massacre</a> of 1572.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-65"><a href="#cite_note-65">[53]</a></sup> The Wars of Religion were ended by <a href="/wiki/Henry_IV_of_France" title="Henry IV of France">Henry IV</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Edict_of_Nantes" title="Edict of Nantes">Edict of Nantes</a>, which granted some freedom of religion to the Huguenots. <a href="/wiki/Habsburg_Spain" title="Habsburg Spain">Spanish</a> troops, the terror of Western Europe,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-66"><a href="#cite_note-66">[54]</a></sup> assisted the Catholic side during the Wars of Religion in 1589–1594, and invaded northern France in 1597; after some skirmishing in the 1620s and 1630s, Spain and France returned to all-out war between 1635 and 1659. <a href="/wiki/Franco-Spanish_War_(1635%E2%80%931659)" title="Franco-Spanish War (1635–1659)">The war</a> cost France 300,000 casualties.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-67"><a href="#cite_note-67">[55]</a></sup>
</p><p>Under <a href="/wiki/Louis_XIII" title="Louis XIII">Louis XIII</a>, the energetic <a href="/wiki/Cardinal_Richelieu" title="Cardinal Richelieu">Cardinal Richelieu</a> promoted the centralisation of the state and reinforced the royal power by disarming domestic power holders in the 1620s. He systematically destroyed castles of defiant lords and denounced the use of private violence (duelling, carrying weapons and maintaining private armies). By the end of the 1620s, Richelieu established "the royal monopoly of force" as the doctrine.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-68"><a href="#cite_note-68">[56]</a></sup> During <a href="/wiki/Louis_XIV" title="Louis XIV">Louis XIV</a>'s minority and the regency of <a href="/wiki/Anne_of_Austria" title="Anne of Austria">Queen Anne</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cardinal_Mazarin" title="Cardinal Mazarin">Cardinal Mazarin</a>, a period of trouble known as the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fronde" title="Fronde">Fronde</a> occurred in France. This rebellion was driven by the great feudal lords and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sovereign_court" title="Sovereign court">sovereign courts</a> as a reaction to the <a href="/wiki/Absolutism_(European_history)" title="Absolutism (European history)">rise of royal absolute power</a> in France.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Louis_XIV_of_France.jpg"><img alt="Louis XIV of France standing in plate armour and blue sash facing left holding baton" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1975" data-file-width="1390" decoding="async" height="242" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5f/Louis_XIV_of_France.jpg/170px-Louis_XIV_of_France.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5f/Louis_XIV_of_France.jpg/255px-Louis_XIV_of_France.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5f/Louis_XIV_of_France.jpg/340px-Louis_XIV_of_France.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Louis_XIV_of_France.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Louis_XIV" title="Louis XIV">Louis XIV</a>, the "Sun King", was the <a href="/wiki/Absolute_monarchy_in_France" title="Absolute monarchy in France">absolute monarch of France</a> and made France the leading European power.</div></div></div>
<p>The monarchy reached its peak during the 17th century and the reign of Louis XIV (1643–1715). By turning powerful feudal lords into <a href="/wiki/Courtier" title="Courtier">courtiers</a> at the <a href="/wiki/Palace_of_Versailles" title="Palace of Versailles">Palace of Versailles</a>, Louis XIV's personal power became unchallenged. Remembered for his numerous wars, he made France the leading European power. France became the <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_France" title="Demographics of France">most populous country in Europe</a> and had tremendous influence over European politics, economy, and culture. French became the most-used language in diplomacy, science, literature and international affairs, and remained so until the 20th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Language_and_Diplomacy_69-0"><a href="#cite_note-Language_and_Diplomacy-69">[57]</a></sup> France obtained many overseas possessions in the Americas, Africa and Asia. Louis XIV also <a href="/wiki/Edict_of_Fontainebleau" title="Edict of Fontainebleau">revoked the Edict of Nantes</a>, forcing thousands of Huguenots into exile.
</p><p>Under the wars of <a href="/wiki/Louis_XV" title="Louis XV">Louis XV</a> (r. 1715–1774), France lost <a href="/wiki/New_France" title="New France">New France</a> and most of its <a href="/wiki/French_India" title="French India">Indian possessions</a> after its defeat in the <a href="/wiki/Seven_Years%27_War" title="Seven Years' War">Seven Years' War</a> (1756–1763). Its <a href="/wiki/Metropolitan_France" title="Metropolitan France">European territory</a> kept growing, however, with notable acquisitions such as <a href="/wiki/Lorraine" title="Lorraine">Lorraine</a> (1766) and <a href="/wiki/Corsica" title="Corsica">Corsica</a> (1770). An unpopular king, Louis XV's weak rule, his ill-advised financial, political and military decisions – as well as the debauchery of his court– discredited the monarchy, which arguably paved the way for the French Revolution 15 years after his death.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-70"><a href="#cite_note-70">[58]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Louis_XVI" title="Louis XVI">Louis XVI</a> (r. 1774–1793), <a href="/wiki/France_in_the_American_Revolutionary_War" title="France in the American Revolutionary War">actively supported the Americans with money, fleets and armies</a>, helping them win <a href="/wiki/American_Revolutionary_War" title="American Revolutionary War">independence from Great Britain</a>. France gained revenge but spent so heavily that the government verged on bankruptcy—a factor that contributed to the French Revolution. Some of the <a href="/wiki/Age_of_Enlightenment" title="Age of Enlightenment">Enlightenment</a> occurred in French intellectual circles, and major scientific breakthroughs and inventions, such as the <a href="/wiki/Antoine_Lavoisier" title="Antoine Lavoisier">discovery of oxygen</a> (1778) and the first <a href="/wiki/Montgolfier_brothers" title="Montgolfier brothers">hot air balloon carrying passengers</a> (1783), were achieved by French scientists. French explorers, such as <a href="/wiki/Louis_Antoine_de_Bougainville" title="Louis Antoine de Bougainville">Bougainville</a> and <a href="/wiki/Jean-Fran%C3%A7ois_de_Galaup,_comte_de_Lap%C3%A9rouse" title="Jean-François de Galaup, comte de Lapérouse">Lapérouse</a>, took part in the <a href="/wiki/European_and_American_voyages_of_scientific_exploration" title="European and American voyages of scientific exploration">voyages of scientific exploration</a> through maritime expeditions around the globe. The Enlightenment philosophy, in which <a href="/wiki/Rationalism" title="Rationalism">reason</a> is advocated as the primary source for <a href="/wiki/Legitimacy_(political)" title="Legitimacy (political)">legitimacy</a>, undermined the power of and support for the monarchy and also was a factor in the French Revolution.
</p>
<h3><span id="Revolutionary_France_.281789.E2.80.931799.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Revolutionary_France_(1789–1799)">Revolutionary France (1789–1799)</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/History_of_France#Revolutionary_France_(1789–1799)" title="History of France">History of France § Revolutionary France (1789–1799)</a>, and <a href="/wiki/French_Revolution" title="French Revolution">French Revolution</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Couder_Stati_generali.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2107" data-file-width="3800" decoding="async" height="122" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/Couder_Stati_generali.jpg/220px-Couder_Stati_generali.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/Couder_Stati_generali.jpg/330px-Couder_Stati_generali.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/Couder_Stati_generali.jpg/440px-Couder_Stati_generali.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Couder_Stati_generali.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><i>Ouverture des États généraux à Versailles, 5 mai 1789</i> by <a href="/wiki/Auguste_Couder" title="Auguste Couder">Auguste Couder</a></div></div></div>
