<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Prise_de_la_Bastille.jpg"><img alt="drawing of the Storming of the Bastille on 14 July 1789, smoke of gunfire enveloping stone castle" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="5877" data-file-width="7877" decoding="async" height="164" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/Prise_de_la_Bastille.jpg/220px-Prise_de_la_Bastille.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/Prise_de_la_Bastille.jpg/330px-Prise_de_la_Bastille.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/Prise_de_la_Bastille.jpg/440px-Prise_de_la_Bastille.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Prise_de_la_Bastille.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Storming_of_the_Bastille" title="Storming of the Bastille">Storming of the Bastille</a> on 14 July 1789 was the most emblematic event of the <a href="/wiki/French_Revolution" title="French Revolution">French Revolution</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>Facing financial troubles, King <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Louis_XVI_of_France" title="Louis XVI of France">Louis XVI</a> summoned the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Estates-General_of_1789" title="Estates-General of 1789">Estates-General</a> (gathering the three <a href="/wiki/Estates_of_the_realm" title="Estates of the realm">Estates of the realm</a>) in May 1789 to propose solutions to his government. As it came to an impasse, the representatives of the <a href="/wiki/Commoner" title="Commoner">Third Estate</a> formed into a <a href="/wiki/National_Assembly_(French_Revolution)" title="National Assembly (French Revolution)">National Assembly</a>, signalling the outbreak of the <a href="/wiki/French_Revolution" title="French Revolution">French Revolution</a>. Fearing that the king would suppress the newly created National Assembly, insurgents <a href="/wiki/Storming_of_the_Bastille" title="Storming of the Bastille">stormed the Bastille</a> on 14 July 1789, a date which would become <a href="/wiki/Bastille_Day" title="Bastille Day">France's National Day</a>.
</p><p>In early August 1789, the <a href="/wiki/National_Constituent_Assembly_(France)" title="National Constituent Assembly (France)">National Constituent Assembly</a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/August_Decrees" title="August Decrees">abolished the privileges</a> of the <a href="/wiki/French_nobility" title="French nobility">nobility</a> such as <a href="/wiki/Serfdom" title="Serfdom">personal serfdom</a> and exclusive hunting rights. Through the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Declaration_of_the_Rights_of_the_Man_and_of_the_Citizen_of_1789" title="Declaration of the Rights of the Man and of the Citizen of 1789">Declaration of the Rights of Man and of the Citizen</a> (27 August 1789) France established fundamental rights for men. The Declaration affirms "the natural and imprescriptible rights of man" to "liberty, property, security and resistance to oppression". Freedom of speech and press were declared, and arbitrary arrests were outlawed. It called for the destruction of aristocratic privileges and proclaimed freedom and equal rights for all men, as well as access to public office based on talent rather than birth. In November 1789, the Assembly decided to nationalise and sell all property of the Catholic Church which had been the largest landowner in the country. In July 1790, a <a href="/wiki/Civil_Constitution_of_the_Clergy" title="Civil Constitution of the Clergy">Civil Constitution of the Clergy</a> reorganised the French Catholic Church, cancelling the authority of the Church to levy taxes, et cetera. This fueled much discontent in parts of France, which would contribute to the civil war breaking out some years later. While King Louis XVI still enjoyed popularity among the population, his disastrous <a href="/wiki/Flight_to_Varennes" title="Flight to Varennes">flight to Varennes</a> (June 1791) seemed to justify rumours he had tied his hopes of political salvation to the prospects of foreign invasion. His credibility was so deeply undermined that the <a href="/wiki/Abolition_of_monarchy" title="Abolition of monarchy">abolition of the monarchy</a> and establishment of a republic became an increasing possibility.
</p><p>In August 1791, the Emperor of <a href="/wiki/Habsburg_monarchy" title="Habsburg monarchy">Austria</a> and the King of <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Prussia" title="Kingdom of Prussia">Prussia</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Declaration_of_Pillnitz" title="Declaration of Pillnitz">Declaration of Pillnitz</a> threatened revolutionary France to intervene by force of arms to restore the French absolute monarchy. In September 1791, the National Constituent Assembly forced King Louis XVI to accept the <a href="/wiki/French_Constitution_of_1791" title="French Constitution of 1791">French Constitution of 1791</a>, thus turning the French absolute monarchy into a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_France_(1791%E2%80%9392)" title="Kingdom of France (1791–92)">constitutional monarchy</a>. In the newly established <a href="/wiki/Legislative_Assembly_(France)" title="Legislative Assembly (France)">Legislative Assembly</a> (October 1791), enmity developed and deepened between a group, later called the '<a href="/wiki/Girondins" title="Girondins">Girondins</a>', who favoured war with <a href="/wiki/Habsburg_monarchy" title="Habsburg monarchy">Austria</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Prussia" title="Kingdom of Prussia">Prussia</a>, and a group later called '<a href="/wiki/The_Mountain" title="The Mountain">Montagnards</a>' or '<a href="/wiki/Jacobin" title="Jacobin">Jacobins</a>', who opposed such a war. A majority in the <a href="/wiki/Legislative_Assembly_(France)" title="Legislative Assembly (France)">Assembly</a> in 1792 however saw a war with Austria and Prussia as a chance to boost the popularity of the revolutionary government and thought that France would win a war against those gathered monarchies. On 20 April 1792, therefore, they <a href="/wiki/French_Revolutionary_Wars" title="French Revolutionary Wars">declared war on Austria</a>.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:242px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Serment_du_Jeu_de_Paume_-_Jacques-Louis_David.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3303" data-file-width="5004" decoding="async" height="158" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Serment_du_Jeu_de_Paume_-_Jacques-Louis_David.jpg/240px-Serment_du_Jeu_de_Paume_-_Jacques-Louis_David.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Serment_du_Jeu_de_Paume_-_Jacques-Louis_David.jpg/360px-Serment_du_Jeu_de_Paume_-_Jacques-Louis_David.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Serment_du_Jeu_de_Paume_-_Jacques-Louis_David.jpg/480px-Serment_du_Jeu_de_Paume_-_Jacques-Louis_David.jpg 2x" width="240"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Serment_du_Jeu_de_Paume_-_Jacques-Louis_David.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/The_Tennis_Court_Oath_(David)" title="The Tennis Court Oath (David)"><i>Le Serment du Jeu de paume</i></a> by <a href="/wiki/Jacques-Louis_David" title="Jacques-Louis David">Jacques-Louis David</a>, 1791</div></div></div>
<p>On 10 August 1792, an angry crowd <a href="/wiki/Insurrection_of_10_August_1792" title="Insurrection of 10 August 1792">threatened the palace of King Louis XVI</a>, who took refuge in the Legislative Assembly.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Shus-5_71-0"><a href="#cite_note-Shus-5-71">[59]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-72"><a href="#cite_note-72">[60]</a></sup> A Prussian Army invaded France later in August 1792. In early September, Parisians, infuriated by <a href="/wiki/French_Revolutionary_Wars" title="French Revolutionary Wars">the Prussian Army capturing Verdun</a> and counter-revolutionary uprisings in the west of France, <a href="/wiki/September_Massacres" title="September Massacres">murdered between 1,000 and 1,500 prisoners</a> by raiding the Parisian prisons. The <a href="/wiki/Legislative_Assembly_(France)" title="Legislative Assembly (France)">Assembly</a> and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Paris_Commune_(French_Revolution)" title="Paris Commune (French Revolution)">Paris City Council</a> seemed unable to stop that bloodshed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Shus-5_71-1"><a href="#cite_note-Shus-5-71">[59]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-73"><a href="#cite_note-73">[61]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/National_Convention" title="National Convention">National Convention</a>, chosen in the first elections under male <a href="/wiki/Universal_suffrage" title="Universal suffrage">universal suffrage</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Shus-5_71-2"><a href="#cite_note-Shus-5-71">[59]</a></sup> on 20 September 1792 succeeded the <a href="/wiki/Legislative_Assembly_(France)" title="Legislative Assembly (France)">Legislative Assembly</a> and on 21 September abolished the monarchy by proclaiming the <a href="/wiki/French_First_Republic" title="French First Republic">French First Republic</a>.
Ex-King Louis XVI was <a href="/wiki/Trial_of_Louis_XVI" title="Trial of Louis XVI">convicted</a> of treason and <a href="/wiki/Execution_of_Louis_XVI" title="Execution of Louis XVI">guillotined in January 1793</a>.
France had declared war on Great Britain and the Dutch Republic in November 1792 and did the same on Spain in March 1793; in the spring of 1793, Austria and Prussia invaded France; in March, France created a "<a href="/wiki/Sister_republic" title="Sister republic">sister republic</a>" in the "<a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Mainz" title="Republic of Mainz">Republic of Mainz</a>", and kept it under control.
</p><p>Also in March 1793, the <a href="/wiki/War_in_the_Vend%C3%A9e" title="War in the Vendée">civil war of the Vendée against Paris</a> started, evoked by both the <a href="/wiki/Civil_Constitution_of_the_Clergy" title="Civil Constitution of the Clergy">Civil Constitution of the Clergy</a> of 1790 and the nationwide army conscription early 1793; elsewhere in France rebellion was brewing too. A factionalist feud in the National Convention, smouldering ever since October 1791, came to a climax with the group of the '<a href="/wiki/Girondins" title="Girondins">Girondins</a>' on 2 June 1793 being forced to resign and leave the convention. The counter-revolution, begun in March 1793 in the Vendée, by July had spread to <a href="/wiki/Brittany_(administrative_region)" title="Brittany (administrative region)">Brittany</a>, Normandy, Bordeaux, Marseilles, Toulon, and Lyon. Paris' Convention government between October and December 1793 with brutal measures managed to subdue most internal uprisings, at the cost of tens of thousands of lives. Some historians consider the civil war to have lasted until 1796 with a toll of possibly 450,000 lives.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-74"><a href="#cite_note-74">[62]</a></sup> By the end of 1793 the allies had been driven from France. France in February 1794 <a href="/wiki/Abolitionism" title="Abolitionism">abolished slavery</a> in its <a href="/wiki/French_colonial_empire" title="French colonial empire">American colonies</a>, but would reintroduce it later.
</p><p>Political disagreements and enmity in the <a href="/wiki/National_Convention" title="National Convention">National Convention</a> between October 1793 and July 1794 reached unprecedented levels, leading to dozens of Convention members being sentenced to death and guillotined. Meanwhile, <a href="/wiki/French_Revolutionary_Wars" title="French Revolutionary Wars">France's external wars</a> in 1794 were going prosperous, for example in Belgium. In 1795, the government seemed to return to indifference towards the desires and needs of the lower classes concerning freedom of (<a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church" title="Catholic Church">Catholic</a>) religion and fair distribution of food. Until 1799, politicians, apart from inventing a new parliamentary system (the '<a href="/wiki/French_Directory" title="French Directory">Directory</a>'), busied themselves with dissuading the people from <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church" title="Catholic Church">Catholicism</a> and from royalism.
</p>
<h3><span id="Napoleon_and_19th_century_.281799.E2.80.931914.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Napoleon_and_19th_century_(1799–1914)">Napoleon and 19th century (1799–1914)</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/History_of_France#Napoleonic_France_(1799–1815)" title="History of France">History of France § Napoleonic France (1799–1815)</a>; <a href="/wiki/History_of_France#Long_19th_century,_1815–1914" title="History of France">History of France § Long 19th century, 1815–1914</a>; <a href="/wiki/First_French_Empire" title="First French Empire">First French Empire</a>; <a href="/wiki/Second_French_Empire" title="Second French Empire">Second French Empire</a>; and <a href="/wiki/French_colonial_empire" title="French colonial empire">French colonial empire</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/France_in_the_19th_century" title="France in the 19th century">France in the 19th century</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/France_in_the_20th_century" title="France in the 20th century">France in the 20th century</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Jacques-Louis_David_-_The_Emperor_Napoleon_in_His_Study_at_the_Tuileries_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg"><img alt="painting of Napoleon in 1806 standing with hand in vest attended by staff and Imperial guard regiment" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="5135" data-file-width="3079" decoding="async" height="367" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/Jacques-Louis_David_-_The_Emperor_Napoleon_in_His_Study_at_the_Tuileries_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg/220px-Jacques-Louis_David_-_The_Emperor_Napoleon_in_His_Study_at_the_Tuileries_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/Jacques-Louis_David_-_The_Emperor_Napoleon_in_His_Study_at_the_Tuileries_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg/330px-Jacques-Louis_David_-_The_Emperor_Napoleon_in_His_Study_at_the_Tuileries_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/Jacques-Louis_David_-_The_Emperor_Napoleon_in_His_Study_at_the_Tuileries_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg/440px-Jacques-Louis_David_-_The_Emperor_Napoleon_in_His_Study_at_the_Tuileries_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Jacques-Louis_David_-_The_Emperor_Napoleon_in_His_Study_at_the_Tuileries_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Napoleon" title="Napoleon">Napoleon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Emperor_of_the_French" title="Emperor of the French">Emperor of the French</a>, built a <a href="/wiki/First_French_Empire" title="First French Empire">vast empire across Europe</a>. His conquests spread the ideals of the French Revolution across much of the continent, such as <a href="/wiki/Popular_sovereignty" title="Popular sovereignty">popular sovereignty</a>, <a href="/wiki/Equality_before_the_law" title="Equality before the law">equality before the law</a>, <a href="/wiki/Republicanism" title="Republicanism">republicanism</a> and administrative reorganisation while his legal reforms <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Code_Napoleon" title="Code Napoleon">had a major impact worldwide</a>. Nationalism, especially in Germany, emerged in reaction against him.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-75"><a href="#cite_note-75">[63]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Napoleon" title="Napoleon">Napoleon Bonaparte</a> <a href="/wiki/Coup_of_18_Brumaire" title="Coup of 18 Brumaire">seized control of the Republic</a> in 1799 becoming <a href="/wiki/French_Consulate" title="French Consulate">First Consul</a> and later <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_the_Year_XII" title="Constitution of the Year XII">Emperor</a> of the <a href="/wiki/First_French_Empire" title="First French Empire">French Empire</a> (1804–1814; 1815). As a continuation of <a href="/wiki/French_Revolutionary_Wars" title="French Revolutionary Wars">the wars</a> sparked by the European monarchies against the French Republic, changing sets of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Coalition_Wars" title="Coalition Wars">European Coalitions</a> declared <a href="/wiki/Napoleonic_Wars" title="Napoleonic Wars">wars</a> on Napoleon's Empire. His armies conquered most of continental Europe with swift victories such as the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Battle_of_Jena-Auerstadt" title="Battle of Jena-Auerstadt">battles of Jena-Auerstadt</a> or <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Austerlitz" title="Battle of Austerlitz">Austerlitz</a>. Members of the <a href="/wiki/House_of_Bonaparte" title="House of Bonaparte">Bonaparte</a> family were appointed as monarchs in some of the newly established kingdoms.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Blanning_76-0"><a href="#cite_note-Blanning-76">[64]</a></sup>
</p><p>These victories led to the worldwide expansion of French revolutionary ideals and reforms, such as the <a href="/wiki/Metric_system" title="Metric system">metric system</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Napoleonic_Code" title="Napoleonic Code">Napoleonic Code</a> and the Declaration of the Rights of Man. In June 1812, Napoleon attacked Russia, reaching Moscow. Thereafter his army disintegrated through supply problems, disease, Russian attacks, and finally winter. After the catastrophic <a href="/wiki/French_invasion_of_Russia" title="French invasion of Russia">Russian campaign</a>, and the ensuing <a href="/wiki/War_of_the_Sixth_Coalition" title="War of the Sixth Coalition">uprising of European monarchies</a> against his rule, Napoleon was defeated and the Bourbon monarchy <a href="/wiki/Bourbon_Restoration_in_France" title="Bourbon Restoration in France">restored</a>. About a million Frenchmen <a href="/wiki/Napoleonic_Wars_casualties" title="Napoleonic Wars casualties">died during the Napoleonic Wars</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Blanning_76-1"><a href="#cite_note-Blanning-76">[64]</a></sup> After his <a href="/wiki/Hundred_Days" title="Hundred Days">brief return</a> from exile, Napoleon was finally defeated in 1815 at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Waterloo" title="Battle of Waterloo">Battle of Waterloo</a>, the monarchy was <a href="/wiki/Bourbon_Restoration_in_France" title="Bourbon Restoration in France">re-established</a> (1815–1830), with new constitutional limitations.
</p><p>The discredited Bourbon dynasty was overthrown by the <a href="/wiki/July_Revolution" title="July Revolution">July Revolution</a> of 1830, which established the constitutional <a href="/wiki/July_Monarchy" title="July Monarchy">July Monarchy</a>. In that year, French troops began the conquest of Algeria, establishing the first colonial presence in Africa since Napoleon's abortive <a href="/wiki/French_campaign_in_Egypt_and_Syria" title="French campaign in Egypt and Syria">invasion of Egypt</a> in 1798. In 1848, general unrest led to the <a href="/wiki/French_Revolution_of_1848" title="French Revolution of 1848">February Revolution</a> and the end of the July Monarchy. The abolition of slavery and introduction of male <a href="/wiki/Universal_suffrage" title="Universal suffrage">universal suffrage</a>, which were briefly enacted during the French Revolution, were re-enacted in 1848. In 1852, the president of the French Republic, <a href="/wiki/Napoleon_III" title="Napoleon III">Louis-Napoléon Bonaparte</a>, Napoleon I's nephew, was proclaimed emperor of the <a href="/wiki/Second_French_Empire" title="Second French Empire">Second Empire</a>, as Napoleon III. He multiplied French interventions abroad, especially in <a href="/wiki/Crimean_War" title="Crimean War">Crimea</a>, in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/French_intervention_in_Mexico" title="French intervention in Mexico">Mexico</a> and <a href="/wiki/Second_Italian_War_of_Independence" title="Second Italian War of Independence">Italy</a> which resulted in the annexation of the <a href="/wiki/Duchy_of_Savoy" title="Duchy of Savoy">Duchy of Savoy</a> and the <a href="/wiki/County_of_Nice" title="County of Nice">County of Nice</a>, then part of the <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Sardinia" title="Kingdom of Sardinia">Kingdom of Sardinia</a>. Napoleon III was unseated following defeat in the <a href="/wiki/Franco-Prussian_War" title="Franco-Prussian War">Franco-Prussian War</a> of 1870 and his regime was replaced by the <a href="/wiki/French_Third_Republic" title="French Third Republic">Third Republic</a>. By 1875, the French conquest of Algeria was complete, and approximately 825,000 Algerians had been killed from famine, disease, and violence.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kiernan2007_77-0"><a href="#cite_note-Kiernan2007-77">[65]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:442px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:French_Empire_evolution.gif"><img alt="animated gif of French colonial territory on world map" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="625" data-file-width="1425" decoding="async" height="193" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/French_Empire_evolution.gif/440px-French_Empire_evolution.gif" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/French_Empire_evolution.gif/660px-French_Empire_evolution.gif 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/French_Empire_evolution.gif/880px-French_Empire_evolution.gif 2x" width="440"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:French_Empire_evolution.gif" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Animated map of the growth and decline of the <a href="/wiki/French_colonial_empire" title="French colonial empire">French colonial empire</a></div></div></div>
<p>France had <a href="/wiki/French_colonial_empire" title="French colonial empire">colonial possessions</a>, in various forms, since the beginning of the 17th century, but in the 19th and 20th centuries, its <a href="/wiki/List_of_largest_empires" title="List of largest empires">global overseas colonial empire</a> extended greatly and became the second-largest in the world behind the <a href="/wiki/British_Empire" title="British Empire">British Empire</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:8_27-1"><a href="#cite_note-:8-27">[15]</a></sup> Including <a href="/wiki/Metropolitan_France" title="Metropolitan France">metropolitan France</a>, the total area of land under French <a href="/wiki/Sovereignty" title="Sovereignty">sovereignty</a> almost reached 13 million square kilometres in the 1920s and 1930s, 8.6% of the world's land. Known as the <i><a href="/wiki/Belle_%C3%89poque" title="Belle Époque">Belle Époque</a></i>, the turn of the century was a period characterised by optimism, regional peace, economic prosperity and technological, scientific and cultural innovations. In 1905, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/State_secularism" title="State secularism">state secularism</a> was <a href="/wiki/1905_French_law_on_the_Separation_of_the_Churches_and_the_State" title="1905 French law on the Separation of the Churches and the State">officially established</a>.
</p>
<h3><span id="Early_to_mid-20th_century_.281914.E2.80.931946.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_to_mid-20th_century_(1914–1946)">Early to mid-20th century (1914–1946)</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/History_of_France_(1900_to_present)" title="History of France (1900 to present)">History of France (1900 to present)</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:El_114_de_infanter%C3%ADa,_en_Par%C3%ADs,_el_14_de_julio_de_1917,_Le%C3%B3n_Gimpel.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="800" data-file-width="1123" decoding="async" height="157" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/El_114_de_infanter%C3%ADa%2C_en_Par%C3%ADs%2C_el_14_de_julio_de_1917%2C_Le%C3%B3n_Gimpel.jpg/220px-El_114_de_infanter%C3%ADa%2C_en_Par%C3%ADs%2C_el_14_de_julio_de_1917%2C_Le%C3%B3n_Gimpel.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/El_114_de_infanter%C3%ADa%2C_en_Par%C3%ADs%2C_el_14_de_julio_de_1917%2C_Le%C3%B3n_Gimpel.jpg/330px-El_114_de_infanter%C3%ADa%2C_en_Par%C3%ADs%2C_el_14_de_julio_de_1917%2C_Le%C3%B3n_Gimpel.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/El_114_de_infanter%C3%ADa%2C_en_Par%C3%ADs%2C_el_14_de_julio_de_1917%2C_Le%C3%B3n_Gimpel.jpg/440px-El_114_de_infanter%C3%ADa%2C_en_Par%C3%ADs%2C_el_14_de_julio_de_1917%2C_Le%C3%B3n_Gimpel.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:El_114_de_infanter%C3%ADa,_en_Par%C3%ADs,_el_14_de_julio_de_1917,_Le%C3%B3n_Gimpel.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>French <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Poilus" title="Poilus">Poilus</a> posing with their war-torn flag in 1917, during World War I</div></div></div>
<p>France was <a href="/wiki/French_entry_into_World_War_I" title="French entry into World War I">invaded by Germany and defended by Great Britain</a> to start World War I in August 1914. A rich industrial area in the northeast was occupied. France and the Allies emerged victorious against the <a href="/wiki/Central_Powers" title="Central Powers">Central Powers</a> at a tremendous human and material cost. World War I left 1.4 million French soldiers dead, 4% of its population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-78"><a href="#cite_note-78">[66]</a></sup> Between 27 and 30% of soldiers conscripted from 1912 to 1915 were killed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-79"><a href="#cite_note-79">[67]</a></sup> The interbellum years were marked by <a href="/wiki/Events_preceding_World_War_II_in_Europe" title="Events preceding World War II in Europe">intense international tensions</a> and a variety of social reforms introduced by the <a href="/wiki/Popular_Front_(France)" title="Popular Front (France)">Popular Front government</a> (<a href="/wiki/Annual_leave" title="Annual leave">annual leave</a>, <a href="/wiki/Eight-hour_day" title="Eight-hour day">eight-hour workdays</a>, <a href="/wiki/Women_in_government" title="Women in government">women in government</a>).
</p><p>In 1940, France was <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_France" title="Battle of France">invaded and quickly defeated</a> by <a href="/wiki/Nazi_Germany" title="Nazi Germany">Nazi Germany</a>. France was divided into a <a href="/wiki/German_military_administration_in_occupied_France_during_World_War_II" title="German military administration in occupied France during World War II">German occupation zone</a> in the north, an <a href="/wiki/Italian_occupation_of_France" title="Italian occupation of France">Italian occupation zone</a> in the southeast and an unoccupied territory, the rest of France, which consisted of the southern French metropolitan territory (two-fifths of pre-war metropolitan France) and the French empire, which included the two protectorates of French Tunisia and French Morocco, and French Algeria; the Vichy government, a newly established authoritarian regime collaborating with Germany, ruled the unoccupied territory. Free France, the government-in-exile led by Charles de Gaulle, was set up in London.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources#What_information_to_include" title="Wikipedia:Citing sources"><span title="A complete citation is needed. (August 2021)">full citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p><p>From 1942 to 1944, about 160,000 French citizens, including around <a href="/wiki/The_Holocaust_in_France" title="The Holocaust in France">75,000 Jews</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-80"><a href="#cite_note-80">[68]</a></sup> were deported to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Extermination_camps" title="Extermination camps">death camps</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Concentration_camps" title="Concentration camps">concentration camps</a> in Germany and occupied Poland.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-81"><a href="#cite_note-81">[69]</a></sup> In September 1943, <a href="/wiki/Corsica" title="Corsica">Corsica</a> was the first French metropolitan territory to liberate itself from the Axis. On 6 June 1944, the <a href="/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_II" title="Allies of World War II">Allies</a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Invasion_of_Normandy" title="Invasion of Normandy">invaded Normandy</a> and in August they <a href="/wiki/Operation_Dragoon" title="Operation Dragoon">invaded Provence</a>. Over the following year the Allies and the <a href="/wiki/French_Resistance" title="French Resistance">French Resistance</a> emerged victorious over the <a href="/wiki/Axis_powers" title="Axis powers">Axis powers</a> and French sovereignty was restored with the establishment of the <a href="/wiki/Provisional_Government_of_the_French_Republic" title="Provisional Government of the French Republic">Provisional Government of the French Republic</a> (GPRF). This interim government, established by de Gaulle, aimed to continue to <a href="/wiki/Western_Allied_invasion_of_Germany" title="Western Allied invasion of Germany">wage war against Germany</a> and to <a href="/wiki/%C3%89puration_l%C3%A9gale" title="Épuration légale">purge collaborators from office</a>. It also made several important reforms (suffrage extended to women, creation of a <a href="/wiki/Social_security_in_France" title="Social security in France">social security</a> system).
</p>
<h3><span id="Contemporary_period_.281946.E2.80.93present.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Contemporary_period_(1946–present)">Contemporary period (1946–present)</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:De_Gaulle-OWI.jpg"><img alt="Charles de Gaulle seated in uniform looking left with folded arms" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3663" data-file-width="2480" decoding="async" height="251" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/De_Gaulle-OWI.jpg/170px-De_Gaulle-OWI.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/De_Gaulle-OWI.jpg/255px-De_Gaulle-OWI.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/De_Gaulle-OWI.jpg/340px-De_Gaulle-OWI.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:De_Gaulle-OWI.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Charles_de_Gaulle" title="Charles de Gaulle">Charles de Gaulle</a> took an active part in many major events of the 20th century: a hero of World War I, leader of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Free_French_Forces" title="Free French Forces">Free French</a> during <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a>, he then became <a href="/wiki/President_of_France" title="President of France">President</a>, where he facilitated decolonisation, maintained France as a major power and overcame the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/May_1968_in_France" title="May 1968 in France">revolt of May 1968</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>The GPRF laid the groundwork for a new constitutional order that resulted in the <a href="/wiki/French_Fourth_Republic" title="French Fourth Republic">Fourth Republic</a> (1946–1958), which saw spectacular economic growth (<i>les <a href="/wiki/Trente_Glorieuses" title="Trente Glorieuses">Trente Glorieuses</a></i>). France was one of the founding members of <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">NATO</a> (1949). France attempted to <a href="/wiki/First_Indochina_War" title="First Indochina War">regain control of French Indochina</a> but was defeated by the <a href="/wiki/Viet_Minh" title="Viet Minh">Viet Minh</a> in 1954 at the climactic <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Dien_Bien_Phu" title="Battle of Dien Bien Phu">Battle of Dien Bien Phu</a>. Only months later, France faced another <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Anti-colonialist" title="Anti-colonialist">anti-colonialist</a> <a href="/wiki/Algerian_War" title="Algerian War">conflict in Algeria</a>, then treated as an integral part of France and home to over one million <a href="/wiki/Pied-Noir" title="Pied-Noir">European settlers</a>. During the conflict, the French systematically used torture and repression, including extrajudicial killings in an effort to keep control of <a href="/wiki/French_Algeria" title="French Algeria">Algeria</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Macqueen2014_82-0"><a href="#cite_note-Macqueen2014-82">[70]</a></sup>
This conflict wracked the country and nearly led to a coup and civil war in France.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-83"><a href="#cite_note-83">[71]</a></sup>
</p><p>During the <a href="/wiki/May_1958_crisis_in_France" title="May 1958 crisis in France">May 1958 crisis</a>, the weak and unstable Fourth Republic gave way to the <a href="/wiki/French_Fifth_Republic" title="French Fifth Republic">Fifth Republic</a>, which included a strengthened Presidency.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-84"><a href="#cite_note-84">[72]</a></sup> In the latter role, Charles de Gaulle managed to keep the country together while taking steps to end the <a href="/wiki/Algerian_War" title="Algerian War">Algerian War</a>. The war was concluded with the <a href="/wiki/%C3%89vian_Accords" title="Évian Accords">Évian Accords</a> in 1962 that led to Algerian independence. Algerian independence came at a high price: it resulted in between half a million and one million deaths and over 2 million internally displaced Algerians.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Springer_85-0"><a href="#cite_note-Springer-85">[73]</a></sup> Around one million <a href="/wiki/Pied-Noir" title="Pied-Noir">Pied-Noirs</a> and <a href="/wiki/Harki" title="Harki">Harkis</a> fled from Algeria to France upon independence.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-google4_86-0"><a href="#cite_note-google4-86">[74]</a></sup> A vestige of the colonial empire are the <a href="/wiki/Overseas_France" title="Overseas France">French overseas departments and territories</a>.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Frankrijk._Theater_Odeon_bezet_door_studenten,_Bestanddeelnr_921-3967.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2455" data-file-width="3667" decoding="async" height="114" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/Frankrijk._Theater_Odeon_bezet_door_studenten%2C_Bestanddeelnr_921-3967.jpg/170px-Frankrijk._Theater_Odeon_bezet_door_studenten%2C_Bestanddeelnr_921-3967.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/Frankrijk._Theater_Odeon_bezet_door_studenten%2C_Bestanddeelnr_921-3967.jpg/255px-Frankrijk._Theater_Odeon_bezet_door_studenten%2C_Bestanddeelnr_921-3967.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/Frankrijk._Theater_Odeon_bezet_door_studenten%2C_Bestanddeelnr_921-3967.jpg/340px-Frankrijk._Theater_Odeon_bezet_door_studenten%2C_Bestanddeelnr_921-3967.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Frankrijk._Theater_Odeon_bezet_door_studenten,_Bestanddeelnr_921-3967.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/May_68" title="May 68">May 68</a> protests, a massive <a href="/wiki/Social_movement" title="Social movement">social movement</a>, would ultimately led to many social changes, such as the right to <a href="/wiki/Abortion" title="Abortion">abortion</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Women_empowerment" title="Women empowerment">women empowerment</a> as well as the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Decriminalisation_of_homosexuality" title="Decriminalisation of homosexuality">decriminalisation of homosexuality</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-87"><a href="#cite_note-87">[75]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>In the context of the <a href="/wiki/Cold_War" title="Cold War">Cold War</a>, De Gaulle pursued a policy of "national independence" towards the <a href="/wiki/Western_Bloc" title="Western Bloc">Western</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Eastern_bloc" title="Eastern bloc">Eastern blocs</a>. To this end, he withdrew from <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">NATO</a>'s military integrated command (while remaining in the NATO alliance itself), launched a <a href="/wiki/Force_de_dissuasion" title="Force de dissuasion">nuclear development programme</a> and made France the <a href="/wiki/France_and_weapons_of_mass_destruction" title="France and weapons of mass destruction">fourth nuclear power</a>. He <a href="/wiki/%C3%89lys%C3%A9e_Treaty" title="Élysée Treaty">restored</a> cordial <a href="/wiki/France%E2%80%93Germany_relations" title="France–Germany relations">Franco-German relations</a> to create a European counterweight between the American and Soviet spheres of influence. However, he opposed any development of a <a href="/wiki/Supranational_union" title="Supranational union">supranational Europe</a>, favouring a Europe of <a href="/wiki/Sovereign_state" title="Sovereign state">sovereign nations</a>. In the wake of the series of worldwide <a href="/wiki/Protests_of_1968" title="Protests of 1968">protests of 1968</a>, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/May_1968_in_France" title="May 1968 in France">revolt of May 1968</a> had an enormous social impact. In France, it was the watershed moment when a conservative moral ideal (religion, patriotism, respect for authority) shifted towards a more liberal moral ideal (<a href="/wiki/Secularism" title="Secularism">secularism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Individualism" title="Individualism">individualism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sexual_revolution" title="Sexual revolution">sexual revolution</a>). Although the revolt was a political failure (as the <a href="/wiki/Gaullism" title="Gaullism">Gaullist</a> party emerged even stronger than before) it announced a split between the French people and de Gaulle who resigned shortly after.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-88"><a href="#cite_note-88">[76]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the post-Gaullist era, France remained one of the most developed <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(nominal)" title="List of countries by GDP (nominal)">economies in the world</a>, but faced several economic crises that resulted in high unemployment rates and increasing public debt. In the late 20th and early 21st centuries France has been at the forefront of the development of a supranational <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a>, notably by signing the <a href="/wiki/Maastricht_Treaty" title="Maastricht Treaty">Maastricht Treaty</a> (which created the European Union) in 1992, establishing the <a href="/wiki/Eurozone" title="Eurozone">Eurozone</a> in 1999 and signing the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Lisbon" title="Treaty of Lisbon">Lisbon Treaty</a> in 2007.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-89"><a href="#cite_note-89">[77]</a></sup> France has also gradually but fully reintegrated into NATO and has since participated in most NATO sponsored wars.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-90"><a href="#cite_note-90">[78]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Marche_r%C3%A9publicaine,_Paris,_11_janvier_2015_(15).jpg"><img alt="Place de la République statue column with large French flag" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1868" data-file-width="2697" decoding="async" height="152" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f0/Marche_r%C3%A9publicaine%2C_Paris%2C_11_janvier_2015_%2815%29.jpg/220px-Marche_r%C3%A9publicaine%2C_Paris%2C_11_janvier_2015_%2815%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f0/Marche_r%C3%A9publicaine%2C_Paris%2C_11_janvier_2015_%2815%29.jpg/330px-Marche_r%C3%A9publicaine%2C_Paris%2C_11_janvier_2015_%2815%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f0/Marche_r%C3%A9publicaine%2C_Paris%2C_11_janvier_2015_%2815%29.jpg/440px-Marche_r%C3%A9publicaine%2C_Paris%2C_11_janvier_2015_%2815%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Marche_r%C3%A9publicaine,_Paris,_11_janvier_2015_(15).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Republican_marches" title="Republican marches">Republican marches</a> were organised across France after the <a href="/wiki/January_2015_%C3%8Ele-de-France_attacks" title="January 2015 Île-de-France attacks">January 2015 attacks</a> perpetrated by <a href="/wiki/Islamism" title="Islamism">Islamist</a> <a href="/wiki/Terrorism" title="Terrorism">terrorists</a>; they became the largest public rallies in French history.</div></div></div>
<p>Since the 19th century, France has received many <a href="/wiki/Immigration_to_France" title="Immigration to France">immigrants</a>. These have been mostly male <a href="/wiki/Foreign_worker" title="Foreign worker">foreign workers</a> from European Catholic countries who generally returned home when not employed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Marie-Christine_Weidmann-Koop_91-0"><a href="#cite_note-Marie-Christine_Weidmann-Koop-91">[79]</a></sup> During the 1970s France faced economic crisis and allowed new immigrants (mostly from the <a href="/wiki/Maghreb" title="Maghreb">Maghreb</a>)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Marie-Christine_Weidmann-Koop_91-1"><a href="#cite_note-Marie-Christine_Weidmann-Koop-91">[79]</a></sup> to permanently <a href="/wiki/Family_reunification" title="Family reunification">settle in France with their families</a> and to acquire French citizenship. It resulted in hundreds of thousands of Muslims (especially in the larger cities) living in subsidised public housing and suffering from very high unemployment rates.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-92"><a href="#cite_note-92">[80]</a></sup> Simultaneously France renounced the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Assimilation_(sociology)" title="Assimilation (sociology)">assimilation</a> of immigrants, where they were expected to adhere to French traditional values and cultural norms. They were encouraged to retain their distinctive cultures and traditions and required merely to <a href="/wiki/Social_integration" title="Social integration">integrate</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-93"><a href="#cite_note-93">[81]</a></sup>
</p><p>Since the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/1995_Paris_M%C3%A9tro_and_RER_bombings" title="1995 Paris Métro and RER bombings">1995 Paris Métro and RER bombings</a>, France has been sporadically targeted by Islamist organisations, notably the <a href="/wiki/January_2015_%C3%8Ele-de-France_attacks" title="January 2015 Île-de-France attacks"><i>Charlie Hebdo</i> attack</a> in January 2015 which provoked the <a href="/wiki/Republican_marches" title="Republican marches">largest public rallies</a> in French history, gathering 4.4 million people,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-94"><a href="#cite_note-94">[82]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/November_2015_Paris_attacks" title="November 2015 Paris attacks">November 2015 Paris attacks</a> which resulted in 130 deaths, the deadliest attack on French soil since <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-95"><a href="#cite_note-95">[83]</a></sup> and the deadliest in the European Union since the <a href="/wiki/2004_Madrid_train_bombings" title="2004 Madrid train bombings">Madrid train bombings in 2004</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-96"><a href="#cite_note-96">[84]</a></sup> as well as the <a href="/wiki/2016_Nice_truck_attack" title="2016 Nice truck attack">2016 Nice truck attack</a>, which caused 87 deaths during <a href="/wiki/Bastille_Day" title="Bastille Day">Bastille Day</a> celebrations. <a href="/wiki/Op%C3%A9ration_Chammal" title="Opération Chammal">Opération Chammal</a>, France's military efforts to contain <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Islamic_State_of_Iraq_and_the_Levant" title="Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant">ISIS</a>, killed over 1,000 ISIS troops between 2014 and 2015.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-97"><a href="#cite_note-97">[85]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Geography">Geography</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_France" title="Geography of France">Geography of France</a></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Location_and_borders">Location and borders</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:242px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:France_cities.png"><img alt="see description" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1796" data-file-width="1797" decoding="async" height="240" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/88/France_cities.png/240px-France_cities.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/88/France_cities.png/360px-France_cities.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/88/France_cities.png/480px-France_cities.png 2x" width="240"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:France_cities.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A relief map of Metropolitan France, showing cities with over 100,000 inhabitants</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:242px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Mont-Blanc_from_Planpraz_station.jpg"><img alt="Panorama of Mont Blanc mountain range above grey clouds under a blue sky" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3312" data-file-width="4416" decoding="async" height="180" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/03/Mont-Blanc_from_Planpraz_station.jpg/240px-Mont-Blanc_from_Planpraz_station.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/03/Mont-Blanc_from_Planpraz_station.jpg/360px-Mont-Blanc_from_Planpraz_station.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/03/Mont-Blanc_from_Planpraz_station.jpg/480px-Mont-Blanc_from_Planpraz_station.jpg 2x" width="240"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Mont-Blanc_from_Planpraz_station.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Mont_Blanc" title="Mont Blanc">Mont Blanc</a>, the highest summit in Western Europe, marks the border with Italy.</div></div></div>
<p>The vast majority of France's territory and population is situated in Western Europe and is called <a href="/wiki/Metropolitan_France" title="Metropolitan France">Metropolitan France</a>, to distinguish it from the country's various overseas polities. It is bordered by the <a href="/wiki/North_Sea" title="North Sea">North Sea</a> in the north, the <a href="/wiki/English_Channel" title="English Channel">English Channel</a> in the northwest, the Atlantic Ocean in the west and the Mediterranean sea in the southeast. Its land borders consist of Belgium and Luxembourg in the northeast, Germany and Switzerland in the east, Italy and Monaco in the southeast, and Andorra and Spain in the south and southwest. Except for the northeast, most of France's land borders are roughly delineated by natural boundaries and geographic features: to the south and southeast, the Pyrenees and the Alps and the Jura, respectively, and to the east, the Rhine river. Due to its shape, France is often referred to as <i><span title="French-language text"><i lang="fr">l'Hexagone</i></span></i> ("The <a href="/wiki/Hexagon" title="Hexagon">Hexagon</a>"). Metropolitan France includes various coastal islands, of which the largest is <a href="/wiki/Corsica" title="Corsica">Corsica</a>. Metropolitan France is situated mostly between latitudes <a href="/wiki/41st_parallel_north" title="41st parallel north">41°</a> and <a href="/wiki/51st_parallel_north" title="51st parallel north">51° N</a>, and longitudes <a href="/wiki/6th_meridian_west" title="6th meridian west">6° W</a> and <a href="/wiki/10th_meridian_east" title="10th meridian east">10° E</a>, on the western edge of Europe, and thus lies within the northern <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Temperateness" title="Temperateness">temperate</a> zone. Its continental part covers about 1000 km from north to south and from east to west.
</p><p>France has several <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Overseas_departments_and_territories_of_France" title="Overseas departments and territories of France">overseas regions</a> across the world, which are organised as follows:
</p>
<ul><li>five have exactly the same status as mainland France's regions and departments:
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/French_Guiana" title="French Guiana">French Guiana</a> in <a href="/wiki/South_America" title="South America">South America</a>;</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Guadeloupe" title="Guadeloupe">Guadeloupe</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Caribbean" title="Caribbean">Caribbean</a>;</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Martinique" title="Martinique">Martinique</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Caribbean" title="Caribbean">Caribbean</a>;</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Mayotte" title="Mayotte">Mayotte</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Indian_Ocean" title="Indian Ocean">Indian Ocean</a>, off the coast of East Africa;</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/R%C3%A9union" title="Réunion">Réunion</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Indian_Ocean" title="Indian Ocean">Indian Ocean</a>, off the coast of East Africa.</li></ul></li>
<li>nine have special legal status distinct from mainland France's regions and departments:
<ul><li>In the Atlantic Ocean: <a href="/wiki/Saint_Pierre_and_Miquelon" title="Saint Pierre and Miquelon">Saint Pierre and Miquelon</a> and, in the Antilles: <a href="/wiki/Collectivity_of_Saint_Martin" title="Collectivity of Saint Martin">Saint Martin</a> and <a href="/wiki/Saint_Barth%C3%A9lemy" title="Saint Barthélemy">Saint Barthélemy</a>.</li>
<li>In the Pacific Ocean: <a href="/wiki/French_Polynesia" title="French Polynesia">French Polynesia</a>, the special collectivity of <a href="/wiki/New_Caledonia" title="New Caledonia">New Caledonia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Wallis_and_Futuna" title="Wallis and Futuna">Wallis and Futuna</a> and <a href="/wiki/Clipperton_Island" title="Clipperton Island">Clipperton Island</a>.</li>
<li>In the Indian Ocean: <a href="/wiki/Kerguelen_Islands" title="Kerguelen Islands">Kerguelen Islands</a>, <a href="/wiki/Crozet_Islands" title="Crozet Islands">Crozet Islands</a>, <a href="/wiki/%C3%8Ele_Saint-Paul" title="Île Saint-Paul">St. Paul</a> and <a href="/wiki/%C3%8Ele_Amsterdam" title="Île Amsterdam">Amsterdam</a> islands, and the <a href="/wiki/Scattered_Islands_in_the_Indian_Ocean" title="Scattered Islands in the Indian Ocean">Scattered Islands in the Indian Ocean</a></li>
<li>In the Antarctic: <a href="/wiki/Ad%C3%A9lie_Land" title="Adélie Land">Adélie Land</a>.</li></ul></li></ul>
<p>France has land borders with Brazil and Suriname via <a href="/wiki/French_Guiana" title="French Guiana">French Guiana</a> and with the Kingdom of the Netherlands through the French portion of <a href="/wiki/Saint_Martin_(island)" title="Saint Martin (island)">Saint Martin</a>.
</p><p>Metropolitan France covers 551,500 square kilometres (212,935 sq mi),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-France_98-0"><a href="#cite_note-France-98">[86]</a></sup> the largest among <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a> members.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-superficy_33-1"><a href="#cite_note-superficy-33">[21]</a></sup> France's total land area, with its overseas departments and territories (excluding <a href="/wiki/Ad%C3%A9lie_Land" title="Adélie Land">Adélie Land</a>), is 643,801 km<sup>2</sup> (248,573 sq mi), 0.45% of the total land area on Earth. France possesses a wide variety of landscapes, from coastal plains in the north and west to mountain ranges of the <a href="/wiki/Alps" title="Alps">Alps</a> in the southeast, the <a href="/wiki/Massif_Central" title="Massif Central">Massif Central</a> in the south central and <a href="/wiki/Pyrenees" title="Pyrenees">Pyrenees</a> in the southwest.
</p><p>Due to its numerous <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Overseas_departments_and_territories_of_France" title="Overseas departments and territories of France">overseas departments and territories</a> scattered across the planet, France possesses the second-largest <a href="/wiki/Exclusive_economic_zone" title="Exclusive economic zone">Exclusive economic zone</a> (EEZ) in the world, covering 11,035,000 km<sup>2</sup> (4,261,000 sq mi), just behind the EEZ of the <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">United States</a>, which covers 11,351,000 km<sup>2</sup> (4,383,000 sq mi), but ahead of the EEZ of Australia, which covers 8,148,250 km<sup>2</sup> (3,146,000 sq mi). Its EEZ covers approximately 8% of the total surface of all the EEZs of the world.
</p>
<h3><span id="Geology.2C_topography_and_hydrography"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Geology,_topography_and_hydrography">Geology, topography and hydrography</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:2013.07.05_roussillon_-_roque_anth%C3%A9ron_172.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3728" data-file-width="5686" decoding="async" height="144" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/2013.07.05_roussillon_-_roque_anth%C3%A9ron_172.JPG/220px-2013.07.05_roussillon_-_roque_anth%C3%A9ron_172.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/2013.07.05_roussillon_-_roque_anth%C3%A9ron_172.JPG/330px-2013.07.05_roussillon_-_roque_anth%C3%A9ron_172.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/2013.07.05_roussillon_-_roque_anth%C3%A9ron_172.JPG/440px-2013.07.05_roussillon_-_roque_anth%C3%A9ron_172.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:2013.07.05_roussillon_-_roque_anth%C3%A9ron_172.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Geological formations near <a href="/wiki/Roussillon,_Vaucluse" title="Roussillon, Vaucluse">Roussillon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vaucluse" title="Vaucluse">Vaucluse</a></div></div></div>
<p>Metropolitan France has a wide variety of topographical sets and natural landscapes. Large parts of the current territory of France were raised during several tectonic episodes like the Hercynian uplift in the Paleozoic Era, during which the <a href="/wiki/Armorican_Massif" title="Armorican Massif">Armorican Massif</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Massif_Central" title="Massif Central">Massif Central</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Morvan" title="Morvan">Morvan</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Vosges" title="Vosges">Vosges</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ardennes" title="Ardennes">Ardennes</a> ranges and the island of <a href="/wiki/Corsica" title="Corsica">Corsica</a> were formed. These massifs delineate several sedimentary basins such as the Aquitaine basin in the southwest and the Paris basin in the north, the latter including several areas of particularly fertile ground such as the silt beds of Beauce and Brie. Various routes of natural passage, such as the Rhône Valley, allow easy communication. The Alpine, Pyrenean and Jura mountains are much younger and have less eroded forms. At 4,810.45 metres (15,782 ft)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-99"><a href="#cite_note-99">[87]</a></sup> above sea level, <a href="/wiki/Mont_Blanc" title="Mont Blanc">Mont Blanc</a>, located in the Alps on the French and Italian border, is the highest point in Western Europe. Although 60% of municipalities are classified as having seismic risks, these risks remain moderate.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Roseli%C3%A8re_de_Pauillac_et_carrelets_sur_l%27estuaire_de_la_Gironde,_France.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1632" data-file-width="2449" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/Roseli%C3%A8re_de_Pauillac_et_carrelets_sur_l%27estuaire_de_la_Gironde%2C_France.jpg/220px-Roseli%C3%A8re_de_Pauillac_et_carrelets_sur_l%27estuaire_de_la_Gironde%2C_France.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/Roseli%C3%A8re_de_Pauillac_et_carrelets_sur_l%27estuaire_de_la_Gironde%2C_France.jpg/330px-Roseli%C3%A8re_de_Pauillac_et_carrelets_sur_l%27estuaire_de_la_Gironde%2C_France.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/Roseli%C3%A8re_de_Pauillac_et_carrelets_sur_l%27estuaire_de_la_Gironde%2C_France.jpg/440px-Roseli%C3%A8re_de_Pauillac_et_carrelets_sur_l%27estuaire_de_la_Gironde%2C_France.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Roseli%C3%A8re_de_Pauillac_et_carrelets_sur_l%27estuaire_de_la_Gironde,_France.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Reed bed on the <a href="/wiki/Gironde_estuary" title="Gironde estuary">Gironde estuary</a>, the largest estuary in Western Europe</div></div></div>
<p>The coastlines offer contrasting landscapes: mountain ranges along the <a href="/wiki/French_Riviera" title="French Riviera">French Riviera</a>, coastal cliffs such as the <a href="/wiki/C%C3%B4te_d%27Alb%C3%A2tre" title="Côte d'Albâtre">Côte d'Albâtre</a>, and wide sandy plains in the <a href="/wiki/Languedoc" title="Languedoc">Languedoc</a>. Corsica lies off the Mediterranean coast. France has an extensive river system consisting of the four major rivers <a href="/wiki/Seine" title="Seine">Seine</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Loire" title="Loire">Loire</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Garonne" title="Garonne">Garonne</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Rh%C3%B4ne" title="Rhône">Rhône</a> and their tributaries, whose combined catchment includes over 62% of the metropolitan territory. The Rhône divides the Massif Central from the Alps and flows into the Mediterranean Sea at the <a href="/wiki/Camargue" title="Camargue">Camargue</a>. The Garonne meets the <a href="/wiki/Dordogne_(river)" title="Dordogne (river)">Dordogne</a> just after Bordeaux, forming the <a href="/wiki/Gironde_estuary" title="Gironde estuary">Gironde estuary</a>, the largest estuary in Western Europe which after approximately 100 kilometres (62 mi) empties into the Atlantic Ocean.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-100"><a href="#cite_note-100">[88]</a></sup> Other water courses drain towards the Meuse and Rhine along the north-eastern borders. France has 11 million square kilometres (4.2<span style="margin-left:0.2em">×<span style="margin-left:0.1em">10</span></span><s style="display:none">^</s><sup>6</sup> sq mi) of marine waters within three oceans under its jurisdiction, of which 97% are overseas.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Environment">Environment</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/List_of_national_parks_of_France" title="List of national parks of France">List of national parks of France</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Regional_natural_parks_of_France" title="Regional natural parks of France">Regional natural parks of France</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:262px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Parcs_naturels_fran%C3%A7ais.svg"><img alt="color map showing Regional natural parks of France" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2347" data-file-width="4920" decoding="async" height="124" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Parcs_naturels_fran%C3%A7ais.svg/260px-Parcs_naturels_fran%C3%A7ais.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Parcs_naturels_fran%C3%A7ais.svg/390px-Parcs_naturels_fran%C3%A7ais.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Parcs_naturels_fran%C3%A7ais.svg/520px-Parcs_naturels_fran%C3%A7ais.svg.png 2x" width="260"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Parcs_naturels_fran%C3%A7ais.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Marine (blue), regional (green) and national (red) parks in France (2019)</div></div></div>
<p>France was one of the first countries to create an environment ministry, in 1971.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-101"><a href="#cite_note-101">[89]</a></sup> Although it is one of the most industrialised countries in the world, France is ranked <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_carbon_dioxide_emissions" title="List of countries by carbon dioxide emissions">only 19th by carbon dioxide emissions</a>, behind less populous nations such as Canada or Australia. This is due to the country's heavy investment in <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_power" title="Nuclear power">nuclear power</a> following the <a href="/wiki/1973_oil_crisis" title="1973 oil crisis">1973 oil crisis</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-102"><a href="#cite_note-102">[90]</a></sup> which now accounts for 75 percent of its electricity production<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-103"><a href="#cite_note-103">[91]</a></sup> and results in less pollution.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-104"><a href="#cite_note-104">[92]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-105"><a href="#cite_note-105">[93]</a></sup> According to the 2020 <a href="/wiki/Environmental_Performance_Index" title="Environmental Performance Index">Environmental Performance Index</a> conducted by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Yale" title="Yale">Yale</a> and <a href="/wiki/Columbia_University" title="Columbia University">Columbia</a>, France was the fifth-most environmentally-conscious country in the world (behind United Kingdom).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-106"><a href="#cite_note-106">[94]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-107"><a href="#cite_note-107">[95]</a></sup>
</p><p>Like all European Union state members, France agreed to cut <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Carbon_emissions" title="Carbon emissions">carbon emissions</a> by at least 20% of 1990 levels by 2020,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-108"><a href="#cite_note-108">[96]</a></sup> compared to the United States plan to reduce emissions by 4% of 1990 levels.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-109"><a href="#cite_note-109">[97]</a></sup> As of 2009<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=France&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, French carbon dioxide emissions per capita were lower than that of China's.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-110"><a href="#cite_note-110">[98]</a></sup> The country was set to impose a <a href="/wiki/Carbon_tax" title="Carbon tax">carbon tax</a> in 2009 at 17 euros per tonne of carbon emitted,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-111"><a href="#cite_note-111">[99]</a></sup> which would have raised 4 billion euros of revenue annually.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-112"><a href="#cite_note-112">[100]</a></sup> However, the plan was abandoned due to fears of burdening French businesses.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-113"><a href="#cite_note-113">[101]</a></sup>
</p><p>Forests account for 31 percent of France's land area—the fourth-highest proportion in Europe—representing an increase of 7 percent since 1990.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-114"><a href="#cite_note-114">[102]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-115"><a href="#cite_note-115">[103]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-116"><a href="#cite_note-116">[104]</a></sup> French forests are some of the most diverse in Europe, comprising more than 140 species of trees.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-117"><a href="#cite_note-117">[105]</a></sup> France had a 2018 <a href="/wiki/Forest_Landscape_Integrity_Index" title="Forest Landscape Integrity Index">Forest Landscape Integrity Index</a> mean score of 4.52/10, ranking it 123rd globally out of 172 countries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FLII-Supplementary_118-0"><a href="#cite_note-FLII-Supplementary-118">[106]</a></sup> There are nine <a href="/wiki/National_park" title="National park">national parks</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-119"><a href="#cite_note-119">[107]</a></sup> and 46 <a href="/wiki/Protected_area" title="Protected area">natural parks</a> in France,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-120"><a href="#cite_note-120">[108]</a></sup> with the government planning to convert 20% of its <a href="/wiki/Exclusive_economic_zone" title="Exclusive economic zone">Exclusive economic zone</a> into a <a href="/wiki/Marine_protected_area" title="Marine protected area">Marine protected area</a> by 2020.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-121"><a href="#cite_note-121">[109]</a></sup> A regional nature park<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-122"><a href="#cite_note-122">[110]</a></sup> (French: <i lang="fr">parc naturel régional</i> or PNR) is a public establishment in France between local authorities and the <a href="/wiki/Government_of_France" title="Government of France">national government</a> covering an inhabited rural area of outstanding beauty, to protect the scenery and heritage as well as setting up sustainable economic development in the area.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-123"><a href="#cite_note-123">[111]</a></sup> A PNR sets goals and guidelines for managed human habitation, sustainable economic development and protection of the natural environment based on each park's unique landscape and heritage. The parks foster ecological research programmes and public education in the natural sciences.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FGTO_124-0"><a href="#cite_note-FGTO-124">[112]</a></sup> As of 2019<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=France&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup> there are 54 PNRs in France.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-125"><a href="#cite_note-125">[113]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Administrative_divisions">Administrative divisions</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Administrative_divisions_of_France" title="Administrative divisions of France">Administrative divisions of France</a></div>
<p>The French Republic is divided into 18 <a href="/wiki/Regions_of_France" title="Regions of France">regions</a> (located in Europe and overseas), five <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Overseas_collectivities_of_France" title="Overseas collectivities of France">overseas collectivities</a>, one <a href="/wiki/Overseas_territory_(France)" title="Overseas territory (France)">overseas territory</a>, one special collectivity – <a href="/wiki/New_Caledonia" title="New Caledonia">New Caledonia</a> and one uninhabited island directly under the authority of the Minister of Overseas France – <a href="/wiki/Clipperton_Island" title="Clipperton Island">Clipperton</a>.
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Regions">Regions</span></h4>
<div class="floatright noresize" role="img" style="width: 400px; padding: 15px; line-height: 1; text-align: center; background-color: #ffffff; position: relative;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:France_base_map_18_regions.png"><img alt="" data-file-height="2048" data-file-width="2215" decoding="async" height="370" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d7/France_base_map_18_regions.png/400px-France_base_map_18_regions.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d7/France_base_map_18_regions.png/600px-France_base_map_18_regions.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d7/France_base_map_18_regions.png/800px-France_base_map_18_regions.png 2x" width="400"/></a> <div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:214px; top:56.4px"><a href="/wiki/Hauts-de-France" title="Hauts-de-France">Hauts-de-<br/>France</a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:142px; top:96px"><a href="/wiki/Normandy_(administrative_region)" title="Normandy (administrative region)">Normandy</a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:216px; top:102px"><a href="/wiki/%C3%8Ele-de-France" title="Île-de-France">Île-de-<br/>France</a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:278px; top:105.6px"><a href="/wiki/Grand_Est" title="Grand Est">Grand Est</a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:261.2px; top:155.6px"><a href="/wiki/Bourgogne-Franche-Comt%C3%A9" title="Bourgogne-Franche-Comté">Bourgogne-<br/>Franche-<br/>Comté</a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:180.8px; top:147.2px"><a href="/wiki/Centre-Val_de_Loire" title="Centre-Val de Loire">Centre-<br/>Val de Loire</a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:126px; top:148px"><a href="/wiki/Pays_de_la_Loire" title="Pays de la Loire">Pays de <br/>la Loire</a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:90px; top:126.4px"><a href="/wiki/Brittany_(administrative_region)" title="Brittany (administrative region)">Brittany</a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:150.8px; top:220px"><a href="/wiki/Nouvelle-Aquitaine" title="Nouvelle-Aquitaine">Nouvelle-<br/>Aquitaine</a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:246px; top:216.8px"><a href="/wiki/Auvergne-Rh%C3%B4ne-Alpes" title="Auvergne-Rhône-Alpes">Auvergne-<br/>Rhône-Alpes</a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:205.2px; top:284px"><a href="/wiki/Occitania_(administrative_region)" title="Occitania (administrative region)">Occitania</a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:290.8px; top:267.2px"><a href="/wiki/Provence-Alpes-C%C3%B4te_d%27Azur" title="Provence-Alpes-Côte d'Azur">Provence-<br/>Alpes-<br/>Côte d'Azur</a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:372px; top:340px"><a href="/wiki/Corsica" title="Corsica">Corsica</a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:18px; top:252px"><a href="/wiki/French_Guiana" title="French Guiana">French Guiana</a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:2px; top:124px"><a href="/wiki/Guadeloupe" title="Guadeloupe">Guadeloupe</a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:2px; top:162.4px"><a href="/wiki/Martinique" title="Martinique">Martinique</a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:270px; top:368px"><a href="/wiki/Mayotte" title="Mayotte">Mayotte</a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:318px; top:368px"><a href="/wiki/R%C3%A9union" title="Réunion">Réunion</a></div><div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:258px; top:36px"><a href="/wiki/Belgium" title="Belgium"><i style="color: #48A3B5">Belgium</i></a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:296.4px; top:65.6px"><a href="/wiki/Luxembourg" title="Luxembourg"><i style="color: #48A3B5">Luxembourg</i></a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:362px; top:83.2px"><a href="/wiki/Germany" title="Germany"><i style="color: #48A3B5">Germany</i></a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:338px; top:172px"><a href="/wiki/Switzerland" title="Switzerland"><i style="color: #48A3B5">Switzerland</i></a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:366px; top:238px"><a href="/wiki/Italy" title="Italy"><i style="color: #48A3B5">Italy</i></a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:94px; top:20px"><a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom" title="United Kingdom"><i style="color: #48A3B5">United Kingdom</i></a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:190px; top:336px"><a href="/wiki/Andorra" title="Andorra"><i style="color: #48A3B5;">Andorra</i></a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:94px; top:324px"><a href="/wiki/Brazil" title="Brazil"><i style="color: #48A3B5;">Brazil</i></a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:0px; top:292px"><a href="/wiki/Suriname" title="Suriname"><i style="color: #48A3B5;">Suriname</i></a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:138px; top:342px"><a href="/wiki/Spain" title="Spain"><i style="color: #48A3B5">Spain</i></a></div><div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:130px; top:56px"><a href="/wiki/English_Channel" title="English Channel"><i style="color: #48A3B5">Channel</i></a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:66px; top:172px"><a href="/wiki/Bay_of_Biscay" title="Bay of Biscay"><i style="color: #48A3B5">Bay of<br/>Biscay</i></a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:366px; top:292px"><a href="/wiki/Ligurian_Sea" title="Ligurian Sea"><i style="color: #48A3B5">Ligurian<br/>Sea</i></a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:264px; top:312px"><a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_Sea" title="Mediterranean Sea"><i style="color: #48A3B5">Mediterranean<br/>Sea</i></a></div>
</div>
<p>Since 2016, France is mainly divided into 18 administrative regions: 13 regions in <a href="/wiki/Metropolitan_France" title="Metropolitan France">metropolitan France</a> (including the territorial collectivity of <a href="/wiki/Corsica" title="Corsica">Corsica</a>),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-126"><a href="#cite_note-126">[114]</a></sup> and five located <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Overseas_region" title="Overseas region">overseas</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-France_98-1"><a href="#cite_note-France-98">[86]</a></sup> The regions are further subdivided into 101 <a href="/wiki/Departments_of_France" title="Departments of France">departments</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-127"><a href="#cite_note-127">[115]</a></sup> which are numbered mainly alphabetically. This number is used in postal codes and was formerly used on <a href="/wiki/Vehicle_registration_plates_of_France" title="Vehicle registration plates of France">French vehicle number plates</a>. Among the 101 departments of France, five (<a href="/wiki/French_Guiana" title="French Guiana">French Guiana</a>, Guadeloupe, <a href="/wiki/Martinique" title="Martinique">Martinique</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mayotte" title="Mayotte">Mayotte</a>, and <a href="/wiki/R%C3%A9union" title="Réunion">Réunion</a>) are in overseas regions (ROMs) that are also simultaneously overseas departments (DOMs), enjoy exactly the same status as metropolitan departments and are an integral part of the European Union.
</p><p>The 101 departments are subdivided into 335 <a href="/wiki/Arrondissements_of_France" title="Arrondissements of France">arrondissements</a>, which are, in turn, subdivided into 2,054 <a href="/wiki/Cantons_of_France" title="Cantons of France">cantons</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-constituencies_128-0"><a href="#cite_note-constituencies-128">[116]</a></sup> These cantons are then divided into 36,658 <a href="/wiki/Communes_of_France" title="Communes of France">communes</a>, which are municipalities with an elected municipal council.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-constituencies_128-1"><a href="#cite_note-constituencies-128">[116]</a></sup> Three communes—Paris, Lyon and Marseille—are subdivided into 45 <a href="/wiki/Municipal_arrondissements_of_France" title="Municipal arrondissements of France">municipal arrondissements</a>.
</p><p>The regions, departments and communes are all known as <a href="/wiki/Territorial_collectivity" title="Territorial collectivity">territorial collectivities</a>, meaning they possess local assemblies as well as an executive. Arrondissements and cantons are merely administrative divisions. However, this was not always the case. Until 1940, the arrondissements were territorial collectivities with an elected assembly, but these were suspended by the <a href="/wiki/Vichy_France" title="Vichy France">Vichy regime</a> and definitely abolished by the <a href="/wiki/French_Fourth_Republic" title="French Fourth Republic">Fourth Republic</a> in 1946.
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Overseas_territories_and_collectivities">Overseas territories and collectivities</span></h4>
<p>In addition to the 18 regions and 101 departments, the French Republic has five <a href="/wiki/Overseas_collectivity" title="Overseas collectivity">overseas collectivities</a> (<a href="/wiki/French_Polynesia" title="French Polynesia">French Polynesia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Saint_Barth%C3%A9lemy" title="Saint Barthélemy">Saint Barthélemy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Collectivity_of_Saint_Martin" title="Collectivity of Saint Martin">Saint Martin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Saint_Pierre_and_Miquelon" title="Saint Pierre and Miquelon">Saint Pierre and Miquelon</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Wallis_and_Futuna" title="Wallis and Futuna">Wallis and Futuna</a>), one <i><a href="/wiki/Sui_generis" title="Sui generis">sui generis</a></i> collectivity (<a href="/wiki/New_Caledonia" title="New Caledonia">New Caledonia</a>), one <a href="/wiki/Overseas_territory_(France)" title="Overseas territory (France)">overseas territory</a> (<a href="/wiki/French_Southern_and_Antarctic_Lands" title="French Southern and Antarctic Lands">French Southern and Antarctic Lands</a>), and one island possession in the Pacific Ocean (<a href="/wiki/Clipperton_Island" title="Clipperton Island">Clipperton Island</a>).
</p><p>Overseas collectivities and territories form part of the French Republic, but do not form part of the European Union or its fiscal area (with the exception of St. Bartelemy, which seceded from Guadeloupe in 2007). The Pacific Collectivities (COMs) of French Polynesia, Wallis and Futuna, and New Caledonia continue to use the <a href="/wiki/CFP_franc" title="CFP franc">CFP franc</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-129"><a href="#cite_note-129">[117]</a></sup> whose value is strictly linked to that of the euro. In contrast, the five overseas regions used the French franc and now use the euro.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-130"><a href="#cite_note-130">[118]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:France-Constituent-Lands.png"><img alt="diagram of the overseas territories of France showing map shapes" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3300" data-file-width="3337" decoding="async" height="218" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/91/France-Constituent-Lands.png/220px-France-Constituent-Lands.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/91/France-Constituent-Lands.png/330px-France-Constituent-Lands.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/91/France-Constituent-Lands.png/440px-France-Constituent-Lands.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:France-Constituent-Lands.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The lands making up the French Republic, shown at the same <a href="/wiki/Scale_(map)" title="Scale (map)">geographic scale</a></div></div></div>
