</th></tr></tbody></table>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Government_and_politics">Government and politics</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Politics_of_France" title="Politics of France">Politics of France</a></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Government">Government</span></h3>
<table class="wikitable" style="text-align:left; float:left; margin-right:9px; margin-left:2px">
<tbody><tr>
<td style="text-align:left"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Emmanuel_Macron_(2019-10-09)_03_(cropped).jpg"><img alt="Emmanuel Macron (2019-10-09) 03 (cropped).jpg" data-file-height="1097" data-file-width="797" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/Emmanuel_Macron_%282019-10-09%29_03_%28cropped%29.jpg/120px-Emmanuel_Macron_%282019-10-09%29_03_%28cropped%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/Emmanuel_Macron_%282019-10-09%29_03_%28cropped%29.jpg/180px-Emmanuel_Macron_%282019-10-09%29_03_%28cropped%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/Emmanuel_Macron_%282019-10-09%29_03_%28cropped%29.jpg/240px-Emmanuel_Macron_%282019-10-09%29_03_%28cropped%29.jpg 2x" width="120"/></a>
</td>
<td style="text-align:left"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Informal_meeting_of_energy_and_transport_ministers_(TTE)._Arrivals,_transport_ministers_Elisabeth_Borne_(37190062412)_(cropped).jpg" title="Informal meeting of energy and transport ministers (TTE). Arrivals, transport ministers Elisabeth Borne (37190062412) (cropped)"><img alt="Informal meeting of energy and transport ministers (TTE). Arrivals, transport ministers Elisabeth Borne (37190062412) (cropped)" data-file-height="870" data-file-width="628" decoding="async" height="166" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/Informal_meeting_of_energy_and_transport_ministers_%28TTE%29._Arrivals%2C_transport_ministers_Elisabeth_Borne_%2837190062412%29_%28cropped%29.jpg/120px-Informal_meeting_of_energy_and_transport_ministers_%28TTE%29._Arrivals%2C_transport_ministers_Elisabeth_Borne_%2837190062412%29_%28cropped%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/Informal_meeting_of_energy_and_transport_ministers_%28TTE%29._Arrivals%2C_transport_ministers_Elisabeth_Borne_%2837190062412%29_%28cropped%29.jpg/180px-Informal_meeting_of_energy_and_transport_ministers_%28TTE%29._Arrivals%2C_transport_ministers_Elisabeth_Borne_%2837190062412%29_%28cropped%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/Informal_meeting_of_energy_and_transport_ministers_%28TTE%29._Arrivals%2C_transport_ministers_Elisabeth_Borne_%2837190062412%29_%28cropped%29.jpg/240px-Informal_meeting_of_energy_and_transport_ministers_%28TTE%29._Arrivals%2C_transport_ministers_Elisabeth_Borne_%2837190062412%29_%28cropped%29.jpg 2x" width="120"/></a>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td style="text-align:center"><a href="/wiki/Emmanuel_Macron" title="Emmanuel Macron">Emmanuel Macron</a><br/><span style="font-size:85%;"><a href="/wiki/President_of_France" title="President of France">President</a></span>
</td>
<td style="text-align:center"><a href="/wiki/%C3%89lisabeth_Borne" title="Élisabeth Borne">Élisabeth Borne</a><br/><span style="font-size:85%;"><a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_France" title="Prime Minister of France">Prime Minister</a></span>
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>France is a <a href="/wiki/Representative_democracy" title="Representative democracy">representative democracy</a> organised as a <a href="/wiki/Unitary_state" title="Unitary state">unitary</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Semi-presidential_system" title="Semi-presidential system">semi-presidential</a> <a href="/wiki/Republic" title="Republic">republic</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-131"><a href="#cite_note-131">[119]</a></sup> As one of the earliest republics of the modern world, democratic traditions and values are deeply rooted in French culture, identity and politics.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:1_132-0"><a href="#cite_note-:1-132">[120]</a></sup> The Constitution of the Fifth Republic was approved by <a href="/wiki/1958_French_constitutional_referendum" title="1958 French constitutional referendum">referendum</a> on 28 September 1958, establishing a framework consisting of executive, legislative and judicial branches.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-133"><a href="#cite_note-133">[121]</a></sup> It sought to address the instability of the Third and Fourth Republics by combining elements of both parliamentary and presidential systems, whilst greatly strengthening the authority of the executive relative to the legislature.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:1_132-1"><a href="#cite_note-:1-132">[120]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Logo_RF.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="415" data-file-width="512" decoding="async" height="178" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/Logo_RF.svg/220px-Logo_RF.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/Logo_RF.svg/330px-Logo_RF.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/Logo_RF.svg/440px-Logo_RF.svg.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Logo_RF.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Official logo of the French Republic</div></div></div>
<p>The executive branch has two leaders. The <a href="/wiki/President_of_France" title="President of France">President of the Republic</a>, currently <a href="/wiki/Emmanuel_Macron" title="Emmanuel Macron">Emmanuel Macron</a>, is the <a href="/wiki/Head_of_state" title="Head of state">head of state</a>, elected directly by universal adult suffrage for a five-year term.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-134"><a href="#cite_note-134">[122]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_France" title="Prime Minister of France">Prime Minister</a>, currently <a href="/wiki/%C3%89lisabeth_Borne" title="Élisabeth Borne">Élisabeth Borne</a>, is the <a href="/wiki/Head_of_government" title="Head of government">head of government</a>, appointed by the President of the Republic to lead the <a href="/wiki/Government_of_France" title="Government of France">Government of France</a>. The President has the power to dissolve Parliament or circumvent it by submitting referendums directly to the people; the President also appoints judges and civil servants, negotiates and ratifies international agreements, as well as serves as commander-in-chief of the Armed Forces. The Prime Minister determines public policy and oversees the civil service, with an emphasis on domestic matters.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-135"><a href="#cite_note-135">[123]</a></sup> In the <a href="/wiki/2022_French_presidential_election" title="2022 French presidential election">2022 presidential election</a> president Macron was re—elected.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-136"><a href="#cite_note-136">[124]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Vote_solennel_loi_mariage_23042013_12.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2848" data-file-width="4288" decoding="async" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Vote_solennel_loi_mariage_23042013_12.jpg/220px-Vote_solennel_loi_mariage_23042013_12.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Vote_solennel_loi_mariage_23042013_12.jpg/330px-Vote_solennel_loi_mariage_23042013_12.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Vote_solennel_loi_mariage_23042013_12.jpg/440px-Vote_solennel_loi_mariage_23042013_12.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Vote_solennel_loi_mariage_23042013_12.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The National Assembly is the lower house of the French Parliament.</div></div></div>
<p>The legislature consists of the <a href="/wiki/French_Parliament" title="French Parliament">French Parliament</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Bicameralism" title="Bicameralism">bicameral</a> body comprising a <a href="/wiki/Lower_house" title="Lower house">lower house</a>, the <a href="/wiki/National_Assembly_(France)" title="National Assembly (France)">National Assembly</a> (<i>Assemblée nationale</i>) and an <a href="/wiki/Upper_house" title="Upper house">upper house</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Senate_(France)" title="Senate (France)">Senate</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-137"><a href="#cite_note-137">[125]</a></sup> Legislators in the National Assembly, known as <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/D%C3%A9put%C3%A9s" title="Députés">députés</a>,</i> represent local constituencies and are directly elected for five-year terms.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-138"><a href="#cite_note-138">[126]</a></sup> The Assembly has the power to dismiss the government by majority vote. Senators are chosen by an electoral college for six-year terms, with half the seats submitted to election every three years.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-139"><a href="#cite_note-139">[127]</a></sup> The Senate's legislative powers are limited; in the event of disagreement between the two chambers, the National Assembly has the final say.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-140"><a href="#cite_note-140">[128]</a></sup> The parliament is responsible for determining the rules and principles concerning most areas of law, political amnesty, and fiscal policy; however, the government may draft the specific details concerning most laws.
</p><p>Until World War II, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Radicalism_(historical)" title="Radicalism (historical)">Radicals</a> were a strong political force in France, embodied by the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Republican,_Radical_and_Radical-Socialist_Party" title="Republican, Radical and Radical-Socialist Party">Republican, Radical and Radical-Socialist Party</a> which was the most important party of the Third Republic. Since World War II, they were marginalised while French politics became characterised by two politically opposed groupings: one left-wing, centred on the <a href="/wiki/French_Section_of_the_Workers%27_International" title="French Section of the Workers' International">French Section of the Workers' International</a> and its successor the <a href="/wiki/Socialist_Party_(France)" title="Socialist Party (France)">Socialist Party</a> (since 1969); and the other right-wing, centred on the <a href="/wiki/Gaullist_Party" title="Gaullist Party">Gaullist Party</a>, whose name changed over time to the <a href="/wiki/Rally_of_the_French_People" title="Rally of the French People">Rally of the French People</a> (1947), the <a href="/wiki/Union_of_Democrats_for_the_Republic" title="Union of Democrats for the Republic">Union of Democrats for the Republic</a> (1958), the <a href="/wiki/Rally_for_the_Republic" title="Rally for the Republic">Rally for the Republic</a> (1976), the <a href="/wiki/Union_for_a_Popular_Movement" title="Union for a Popular Movement">Union for a Popular Movement</a> (2007) and <a href="/wiki/The_Republicans_(France)" title="The Republicans (France)">The Republicans</a> (since 2015). In the 2017 presidential and legislative elections, <a href="/wiki/Radical_centrism" title="Radical centrism">radical centrist</a> party <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/La_R%C3%A9publique_En_Marche!" title="La République En Marche!">La République En Marche!</a> (LREM) became the dominant force, overtaking both Socialists and Republicans. LREM's main opponent in both the 2017 and 2022 elections has been the growing far-right party <a href="/wiki/National_Rally" title="National Rally">National Rally</a>.
</p><p>The electorate is constitutionally empowered to vote on amendments passed by the Parliament and bills submitted by the president. Referendums have played a key role in shaping French politics and even foreign policy; voters have decided on such matters as Algeria's independence, the election of the president by popular vote, the formation of the EU, and the reduction of presidential term limits.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-141"><a href="#cite_note-141">[129]</a></sup> Waning civic participation has been a matter of rigorous public debate, with a majority of the public reportedly supporting mandatory voting as a solution in 2019. However, at least as of 2017, voter turnout was 75 percent during recent elections, higher than the OECD average of 68 percent.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-142"><a href="#cite_note-142">[130]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Law">Law</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Law_of_France" title="Law of France">Law of France</a></div>
<p>France uses a <a href="/wiki/Civil_law_(legal_system)" title="Civil law (legal system)">civil legal</a> system, wherein law arises primarily from written statutes;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-France_98-2"><a href="#cite_note-France-98">[86]</a></sup> judges are not to make law, but merely to interpret it (though the amount of judicial interpretation in certain areas makes it equivalent to <a href="/wiki/Case_law" title="Case law">case law</a> in a <a href="/wiki/Common_law" title="Common law">common law</a> system). Basic principles of the <a href="/wiki/Rule_of_law" title="Rule of law">rule of law</a> were laid in the <a href="/wiki/Napoleonic_Code" title="Napoleonic Code">Napoleonic Code</a> (which was, in turn, largely based on the royal law codified under <a href="/wiki/Louis_XIV" title="Louis XIV">Louis XIV</a>). In agreement with the principles of the Declaration of the Rights of Man and of the Citizen, law should only prohibit actions detrimental to society. As <a href="/wiki/Guy_Canivet" title="Guy Canivet">Guy Canivet</a>, first president of the <a href="/wiki/Court_of_Cassation_(France)" title="Court of Cassation (France)">Court of Cassation</a>, wrote about the management of prisons: "Freedom is the rule, and its restriction is the exception; any restriction of Freedom must be provided for by Law and must follow the principles of necessity and proportionality." That is, Law should lay out prohibitions only if they are needed, and if the inconveniences caused by this restriction do not exceed the inconveniences that the prohibition is supposed to remedy.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Declaration_of_the_Rights_of_Man_and_of_the_Citizen_in_1789.jpg"><img alt="color drawing of the Declaration of the Rights of Man and of the Citizen from 1789" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="4636" data-file-width="3657" decoding="async" height="216" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6c/Declaration_of_the_Rights_of_Man_and_of_the_Citizen_in_1789.jpg/170px-Declaration_of_the_Rights_of_Man_and_of_the_Citizen_in_1789.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6c/Declaration_of_the_Rights_of_Man_and_of_the_Citizen_in_1789.jpg/255px-Declaration_of_the_Rights_of_Man_and_of_the_Citizen_in_1789.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6c/Declaration_of_the_Rights_of_Man_and_of_the_Citizen_in_1789.jpg/340px-Declaration_of_the_Rights_of_Man_and_of_the_Citizen_in_1789.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Declaration_of_the_Rights_of_Man_and_of_the_Citizen_in_1789.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The basic principles that the French Republic must respect are found in the 1789 <a href="/wiki/Declaration_of_the_Rights_of_Man_and_of_the_Citizen" title="Declaration of the Rights of Man and of the Citizen">Declaration of the Rights of Man and of the Citizen</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>French law is divided into two principal areas: <a href="/wiki/Private_law" title="Private law">private law</a> and <a href="/wiki/Public_law" title="Public law">public law</a>. Private law includes, in particular, <a href="/wiki/Civil_law_(common_law)" title="Civil law (common law)">civil law</a> and <a href="/wiki/Criminal_law" title="Criminal law">criminal law</a>. Public law includes, in particular, <a href="/wiki/Administrative_law" title="Administrative law">administrative law</a> and <a href="/wiki/Constitutional_law" title="Constitutional law">constitutional law</a>. However, in practical terms, French law comprises three principal areas of law: civil law, criminal law, and administrative law. Criminal laws can only address the future and not the past (criminal <i><a href="/wiki/Ex_post_facto_law" title="Ex post facto law">ex post facto</a></i> laws are prohibited).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-143"><a href="#cite_note-143">[131]</a></sup> While administrative law is often a subcategory of civil law in many countries, it is completely separated in France and each body of law is headed by a specific supreme court: <a href="/wiki/French_judiciary_courts" title="French judiciary courts">ordinary courts</a> (which handle criminal and civil litigation) are headed by the <a href="/wiki/Court_of_Cassation_(France)" title="Court of Cassation (France)">Court of Cassation</a> and administrative courts are headed by the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Conseil_d%27Etat_(France)" title="Conseil d'Etat (France)">Council of State</a>.
</p><p>To be applicable, every law must be officially published in the <i><a href="/wiki/Journal_officiel_de_la_R%C3%A9publique_fran%C3%A7aise" title="Journal officiel de la République française">Journal officiel de la République française</a></i>.
</p><p>France does not recognise <a href="/wiki/Religious_law" title="Religious law">religious law</a> as a motivation for the enactment of prohibitions; it has long abolished <a href="/wiki/Blasphemy" title="Blasphemy">blasphemy</a> laws and <a href="/wiki/Sodomy_law" title="Sodomy law">sodomy laws</a> (the latter in 1791). However, "offences against <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Decency" title="Decency">public decency</a>" (<i>contraires aux bonnes mœurs</i>) or <a href="/wiki/Breach_of_the_peace" title="Breach of the peace">disturbing public order</a> (<i>trouble à l'ordre public</i>) have been used to repress public expressions of homosexuality or street prostitution. Since 1999, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pacte_civil_de_solidarit%C3%A9" title="Pacte civil de solidarité">civil unions</a> for homosexual couples are permitted, and since 2013, <a href="/wiki/Same-sex_marriage" title="Same-sex marriage">same-sex marriage</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/LGBT_adoption" title="LGBT adoption">LGBT adoption</a> are legal.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-144"><a href="#cite_note-144">[132]</a></sup> Laws prohibiting discriminatory speech in the press are <a href="/wiki/Law_on_the_Freedom_of_the_Press_of_29_July_1881" title="Law on the Freedom of the Press of 29 July 1881">as old as 1881</a>. Some consider <a href="/wiki/Hate_speech_laws_in_France" title="Hate speech laws in France">hate speech laws in France</a> to be too broad or severe, undermining <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_speech" title="Freedom of speech">freedom of speech</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-145"><a href="#cite_note-145">[133]</a></sup>
France has laws against racism and <a href="/wiki/Antisemitism" title="Antisemitism">antisemitism</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-146"><a href="#cite_note-146">[134]</a></sup> while the 1990 <a href="/wiki/Gayssot_Act" title="Gayssot Act">Gayssot Act</a> prohibits <a href="/wiki/Holocaust_denial" title="Holocaust denial">Holocaust denial</a>.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_religion_in_France" title="Freedom of religion in France">Freedom of religion</a> is constitutionally guaranteed by the 1789 <a href="/wiki/Declaration_of_the_Rights_of_Man_and_of_the_Citizen" title="Declaration of the Rights of Man and of the Citizen">Declaration of the Rights of Man and of the Citizen</a>. The <a href="/wiki/1905_French_law_on_the_Separation_of_the_Churches_and_the_State" title="1905 French law on the Separation of the Churches and the State">1905 French law on the Separation of the Churches and the State</a> is the basis for <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/La%C3%AFcit%C3%A9" title="Laïcité">laïcité</a></i> (state secularism): the state does not formally recognise any religion, <a href="/wiki/Concordat_in_Alsace-Moselle" title="Concordat in Alsace-Moselle">except in Alsace-Moselle</a>. Nonetheless, it does recognise religious associations. The Parliament has <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Groups_referred_to_as_cults_in_government_reports#France" title="Groups referred to as cults in government reports">listed many religious movements as dangerous cults</a> since 1995, and has <a href="/wiki/French_law_on_secularity_and_conspicuous_religious_symbols_in_schools" title="French law on secularity and conspicuous religious symbols in schools">banned wearing conspicuous religious symbols in schools</a> since 2004. In 2010, it banned the <a href="/wiki/French_ban_on_face_covering" title="French ban on face covering">wearing of face-covering Islamic veils in public</a>; human rights groups such as <a href="/wiki/Amnesty_International" title="Amnesty International">Amnesty International</a> and <a href="/wiki/Human_Rights_Watch" title="Human Rights Watch">Human Rights Watch</a> described the law as discriminatory towards Muslims.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-147"><a href="#cite_note-147">[135]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-148"><a href="#cite_note-148">[136]</a></sup> However, it is supported by most of the population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-149"><a href="#cite_note-149">[137]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Foreign_relations">Foreign relations</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_France" title="Foreign relations of France">Foreign relations of France</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Map-Francophonie_organisation_fr.svg"><img alt="La Francophonie map (dozens of countries in Africa, Europe, Asia and Latin America are members of this international organisation." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="443" data-file-width="1003" decoding="async" height="97" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/63/Map-Francophonie_organisation_fr.svg/220px-Map-Francophonie_organisation_fr.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/63/Map-Francophonie_organisation_fr.svg/330px-Map-Francophonie_organisation_fr.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/63/Map-Francophonie_organisation_fr.svg/440px-Map-Francophonie_organisation_fr.svg.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Map-Francophonie_organisation_fr.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>88 states and governments are part of <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/La_Francophonie" title="La Francophonie">La Francophonie</a></i>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-150"><a href="#cite_note-150">[138]</a></sup> which promotes values of <a href="/wiki/Democracy" title="Democracy">democracy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Multilingualism" title="Multilingualism">multilingualism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cultural_diversity" title="Cultural diversity">cultural diversity</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-151"><a href="#cite_note-151">[139]</a></sup> France has been a key member of this global organisation since its inception in 1970.</div></div></div>
<p>France is a founding member of the United Nations and serves as one of the <a href="/wiki/Permanent_members_of_the_United_Nations_Security_Council" title="Permanent members of the United Nations Security Council">permanent members of the UN Security Council</a> with veto rights.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-152"><a href="#cite_note-152">[140]</a></sup> In 2015, it was described as "the best networked state in the world" due to its membership in more international institutions than any other country;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-153"><a href="#cite_note-153">[141]</a></sup> these include the G7, <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Organization" title="World Trade Organization">World Trade Organization</a> (WTO),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-154"><a href="#cite_note-154">[142]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Pacific_Community" title="Pacific Community">Pacific Community</a> (SPC)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-155"><a href="#cite_note-155">[143]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Indian_Ocean_Commission" title="Indian Ocean Commission">Indian Ocean Commission</a> (COI).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-156"><a href="#cite_note-156">[144]</a></sup> It is an associate member of the <a href="/wiki/Association_of_Caribbean_States" title="Association of Caribbean States">Association of Caribbean States</a> (ACS)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-157"><a href="#cite_note-157">[145]</a></sup> and a leading member of the <a href="/wiki/Organisation_internationale_de_la_Francophonie" title="Organisation internationale de la Francophonie">Organisation internationale de la Francophonie</a> (OIF) of 84 French-speaking countries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-158"><a href="#cite_note-158">[146]</a></sup>
</p><p>As a significant hub for international relations, France has the <a href="/wiki/List_of_diplomatic_missions_of_France" title="List of diplomatic missions of France">third-largest assembly</a> of <a href="/wiki/Diplomatic_mission" title="Diplomatic mission">diplomatic missions</a>, second only to China and the United States, which are far more populous. It also hosts the headquarters of several <a href="/wiki/International_organization" title="International organization">international organisations</a>, including the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Organisation_for_Economic_Co-operation_and_Development" title="Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development">OECD</a>, <a href="/wiki/UNESCO" title="UNESCO">UNESCO</a>, <a href="/wiki/Interpol" title="Interpol">Interpol</a>, the <a href="/wiki/International_Bureau_of_Weights_and_Measures" title="International Bureau of Weights and Measures">International Bureau of Weights and Measures</a>, and the OIF.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-159"><a href="#cite_note-159">[147]</a></sup>
</p><p>Postwar French foreign policy has been largely shaped by membership of the European Union, of which it was a <a href="/wiki/Inner_Six" title="Inner Six">founding member</a>. Since the <a href="/wiki/%C3%89lys%C3%A9e_Treaty" title="Élysée Treaty">1960s</a>, France has developed close ties with reunified Germany to become the <a href="/wiki/France%E2%80%93Germany_relations" title="France–Germany relations">most influential driving force of the EU</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-160"><a href="#cite_note-160">[148]</a></sup> In the 1960s, France sought to exclude the British from the European unification process,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-161"><a href="#cite_note-161">[149]</a></sup> seeking to build its own standing in continental Europe. However, since 1904, France has maintained an "<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Entente_cordiale" title="Entente cordiale">Entente cordiale</a>" with the United Kingdom, and there has been a strengthening of links between the countries, especially <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Defence_and_Security_Co-operation_Treaty" title="Defence and Security Co-operation Treaty">militarily</a>.
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Inauguration_EYE2014_Parlement_europ%C3%A9en_Strasbourg_9_mai_2014.jpg"><img alt="European Parliament opening in Strasbourg with crowd and many countries' flags on flagpoles" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3840" data-file-width="5760" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/Inauguration_EYE2014_Parlement_europ%C3%A9en_Strasbourg_9_mai_2014.jpg/220px-Inauguration_EYE2014_Parlement_europ%C3%A9en_Strasbourg_9_mai_2014.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/Inauguration_EYE2014_Parlement_europ%C3%A9en_Strasbourg_9_mai_2014.jpg/330px-Inauguration_EYE2014_Parlement_europ%C3%A9en_Strasbourg_9_mai_2014.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/Inauguration_EYE2014_Parlement_europ%C3%A9en_Strasbourg_9_mai_2014.jpg/440px-Inauguration_EYE2014_Parlement_europ%C3%A9en_Strasbourg_9_mai_2014.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Inauguration_EYE2014_Parlement_europ%C3%A9en_Strasbourg_9_mai_2014.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/European_Parliament" title="European Parliament">European Parliament</a> in <a href="/wiki/Strasbourg" title="Strasbourg">Strasbourg</a>, near the border with (Germany). France is a founding member of all EU institutions.</div></div></div>
<p>France is a member of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/North_Atlantic_Treaty_Organisation" title="North Atlantic Treaty Organisation">North Atlantic Treaty Organisation</a> (NATO), but under President de Gaulle excluded itself from the joint military command, in protest of the <a href="/wiki/Special_Relationship" title="Special Relationship">Special Relationship</a> between the United States and Britain, and to preserve the independence of French foreign and security policies. Under Nicolas Sarkozy, France re-joined the NATO joint military command on 4 April 2009.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-162"><a href="#cite_note-162">[150]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-163"><a href="#cite_note-163">[151]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-164"><a href="#cite_note-164">[152]</a></sup>
</p><p>France retains strong political and economic influence in its <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Second_French_colonial_empire" title="Second French colonial empire">former African colonies</a> (<i><a href="/wiki/Fran%C3%A7afrique" title="Françafrique">Françafrique</a></i>)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-165"><a href="#cite_note-165">[153]</a></sup> and has supplied economic aid and troops for peacekeeping missions in Ivory Coast and Chad.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-166"><a href="#cite_note-166">[154]</a></sup> From 2012 to 2021, France and other African states intervened in support of the <a href="/wiki/Mali" title="Mali">Malian</a> government in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Northern_Mali_conflict" title="Northern Mali conflict">Northern Mali conflict</a>.
</p><p>In 2017, France was the world's fourth-largest donor of <a href="/wiki/Development_aid" title="Development aid">development aid</a> in absolute terms, behind the United States, Germany, and the United Kingdom.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-167"><a href="#cite_note-167">[155]</a></sup> This represents 0.43% of its <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/GNP" title="GNP">GNP</a>, the 12th highest among the OECD.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-168"><a href="#cite_note-168">[156]</a></sup> Aid is provided by the governmental <a href="/wiki/French_Development_Agency" title="French Development Agency">French Development Agency</a>, which finances primarily humanitarian projects in <a href="/wiki/Sub-Saharan_Africa" title="Sub-Saharan Africa">sub-Saharan Africa</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-aid_169-0"><a href="#cite_note-aid-169">[157]</a></sup> with an emphasis on "developing infrastructure, access to health care and education, the implementation of appropriate economic policies and the consolidation of the rule of law and democracy".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-aid_169-1"><a href="#cite_note-aid-169">[157]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Military">Military</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/French_Armed_Forces" title="French Armed Forces">French Armed Forces</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:292px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:French_military_images.jpg"><img alt="see description" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1110" data-file-width="1772" decoding="async" height="182" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/French_military_images.jpg/290px-French_military_images.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/French_military_images.jpg/435px-French_military_images.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/French_military_images.jpg/580px-French_military_images.jpg 2x" width="290"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:French_military_images.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Examples of France's military. Clockwise from top left: nuclear aircraft carrier <i><a href="/wiki/French_aircraft_carrier_Charles_de_Gaulle" title="French aircraft carrier Charles de Gaulle">Charles de Gaulle</a></i>; a <a href="/wiki/Dassault_Rafale" title="Dassault Rafale">Dassault Rafale</a> <a href="/wiki/Fighter_aircraft" title="Fighter aircraft">fighter aircraft</a>; French <a href="/wiki/Chasseurs_Alpins" title="Chasseurs Alpins">Chasseurs Alpins</a> patrolling the valleys of Kapisa province in Afghanistan; a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/AMX-56_Leclerc" title="AMX-56 Leclerc">Leclerc tank</a></div></div></div>
<p>The French Armed Forces (<i>Forces armées françaises</i>) are the military and paramilitary forces of France, under the <a href="/wiki/President_of_France" title="President of France">President of the Republic</a> as supreme commander. They consist of the <a href="/wiki/French_Army" title="French Army">French Army</a> (<i>Armée de Terre</i>), <a href="/wiki/French_Navy" title="French Navy">French Navy</a> (<i>Marine Nationale</i>, formerly called <i>Armée de Mer</i>), the <a href="/wiki/French_Air_and_Space_Force" title="French Air and Space Force">French Air and Space Force</a> (<i>Armée de l'Air et de l’Espace</i>), and the Military Police called <a href="/wiki/National_Gendarmerie" title="National Gendarmerie">National Gendarmerie</a> (<i>Gendarmerie nationale</i>), which also fulfils civil police duties in the rural areas of France. Together they are among the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_number_of_troops" title="List of countries by number of troops">largest armed forces</a> in the world and the largest in the EU. According to a 2018 study by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cr%C3%A9dit_Suisse" title="Crédit Suisse">Crédit Suisse</a>, the French Armed Forces are ranked as the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_Military_Strength_Index" title="List of countries by Military Strength Index">world's sixth-most powerful military</a>, and the second most powerful in Europe after <a href="/wiki/Russia" title="Russia">Russia</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CreditSuisse2015_170-0"><a href="#cite_note-CreditSuisse2015-170">[158]</a></sup> France's annual military expenditure in 2018 was US$63.8 billion, or 2.3% <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_military_expenditure_share_of_GDP" title="List of countries by military expenditure share of GDP">of its GDP</a>, making it the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_military_expenditures" title="List of countries by military expenditures">fifth biggest military spender in the world</a> after the United States, China, Saudi Arabia, and India.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-171"><a href="#cite_note-171">[159]</a></sup> There has been no national <a href="/wiki/Conscription" title="Conscription">conscription</a> since 1997.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-172"><a href="#cite_note-172">[160]</a></sup>
</p>
