class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:EMIA_Bastille_Day_2007.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="1866" data-file-width="2800" decoding="async" height="133" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/EMIA_Bastille_Day_2007.jpg/200px-EMIA_Bastille_Day_2007.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/EMIA_Bastille_Day_2007.jpg/300px-EMIA_Bastille_Day_2007.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/EMIA_Bastille_Day_2007.jpg/400px-EMIA_Bastille_Day_2007.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption text-align-center"><a href="/wiki/%C3%89cole_militaire_interarmes" title="École militaire interarmes">Combined Arms School</a></div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:ENSOA_trainees_Bastille_Day_2008.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="1833" data-file-width="2750" decoding="async" height="133" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/ENSOA_trainees_Bastille_Day_2008.jpg/200px-ENSOA_trainees_Bastille_Day_2008.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/ENSOA_trainees_Bastille_Day_2008.jpg/300px-ENSOA_trainees_Bastille_Day_2008.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/ENSOA_trainees_Bastille_Day_2008.jpg/400px-ENSOA_trainees_Bastille_Day_2008.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption text-align-center"><a href="/wiki/National_Active_Non-Commissioned_Officers_School_(France)" title="National Active Non-Commissioned Officers School (France)">National Active Non-Commissioned Officers School</a></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>France has been a <a href="/wiki/List_of_states_with_nuclear_weapons#Five_nuclear-weapon_states_under_the_NPT" title="List of states with nuclear weapons">recognised nuclear state</a> since 1960. France has signed and ratified the <a href="/wiki/Comprehensive_Nuclear-Test-Ban_Treaty" title="Comprehensive Nuclear-Test-Ban Treaty">Comprehensive Nuclear-Test-Ban Treaty</a> (CTBT)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-status_173-0"><a href="#cite_note-status-173">[161]</a></sup> and acceded to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nuclear_Non-Proliferation_Treaty" title="Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty">Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty</a>. The French nuclear force (formerly known as "<i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Force_de_Frappe" title="Force de Frappe">Force de Frappe</a></i>") consists of four <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Triomphant_class_submarine" title="Triomphant class submarine"><i>Triomphant</i></a> class submarines equipped with <a href="/wiki/Submarine-launched_ballistic_missile" title="Submarine-launched ballistic missile">submarine-launched ballistic missiles</a>. In addition to the submarine fleet, it is estimated that France has about 60 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Air-Sol_Moyenne_Port%C3%A9e" title="Air-Sol Moyenne Portée"><i>ASMP</i></a> medium-range <a href="/wiki/Air-to-surface_missile" title="Air-to-surface missile">air-to-ground missiles</a> with <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_weapon" title="Nuclear weapon">nuclear warheads</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-174"><a href="#cite_note-174">[162]</a></sup> of which around 50 are deployed by the Air and Space Force using the <a href="/wiki/Dassault_Mirage_2000N/2000D" title="Dassault Mirage 2000N/2000D">Mirage 2000N</a> long-range nuclear strike aircraft, while around 10 are deployed by the French Navy's <a href="/wiki/Dassault-Breguet_Super_%C3%89tendard" title="Dassault-Breguet Super Étendard">Super Étendard Modernisé (SEM)</a> attack aircraft, which operate from the nuclear-powered <a href="/wiki/Aircraft_carrier" title="Aircraft carrier">aircraft carrier</a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/French_aircraft_carrier_Charles_de_Gaulle_(R91)" title="French aircraft carrier Charles de Gaulle (R91)"><i>Charles de Gaulle</i></a>. The new <a href="/wiki/Dassault_Rafale" title="Dassault Rafale">Rafale F3</a> aircraft will gradually replace all Mirage 2000N and SEM in the nuclear strike role with the improved <i>ASMP-A</i> missile with a nuclear warhead.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (September 2022)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p><p>France has major military industries with one of the largest <a href="/wiki/Aerospace_manufacturer" title="Aerospace manufacturer">aerospace industries</a> in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-175"><a href="#cite_note-175">[163]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-176"><a href="#cite_note-176">[164]</a></sup> Its industries have produced such equipment as the Rafale fighter, the <i>Charles de Gaulle</i> aircraft carrier, the <a href="/wiki/Exocet" title="Exocet">Exocet</a> missile and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/AMX-56_Leclerc" title="AMX-56 Leclerc">Leclerc</a> tank among others. France is actively investing in European joint projects such as the <a href="/wiki/Eurocopter_Tiger" title="Eurocopter Tiger">Eurocopter Tiger</a>, <a href="/wiki/FREMM_multipurpose_frigate" title="FREMM multipurpose frigate">multipurpose frigates</a>, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Unmanned_combat_air_vehicle" title="Unmanned combat air vehicle">UCAV</a> demonstrator <a href="/wiki/Dassault_nEUROn" title="Dassault nEUROn">nEUROn</a> and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Airbus_A400M" title="Airbus A400M">Airbus A400M</a>.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (September 2022)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> France is a major arms seller,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-177"><a href="#cite_note-177">[165]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-178"><a href="#cite_note-178">[166]</a></sup> with most of its arsenal's designs available for the export market, except for the nuclear-powered devices.
</p><p>One French intelligence unit, the <a href="/wiki/Directorate-General_for_External_Security" title="Directorate-General for External Security">Directorate-General for External Security</a> (<i>Direction générale de la sécurité extérieure</i>), is considered to be a component of the Armed Forces under the authority of the Ministry of Defense. The other, the Central Directorate for Interior Intelligence (<i>Direction centrale du renseignement intérieur</i>) is a division of the National Police Force (<i>Direction générale de la Police Nationale</i>).<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (September 2022)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> France's <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cybersecurity" title="Cybersecurity">cybersecurity capabilities</a> are regularly ranked as some of the most robust of any nation of the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-179"><a href="#cite_note-179">[167]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-180"><a href="#cite_note-180">[168]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Government_finance">Government finance</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Taxation_in_France" title="Taxation in France">Taxation in France</a></div>
<p>The Government of France has run a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Budget_deficit" title="Budget deficit">budget deficit</a> each year since the early 1970s. As of 2016<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=France&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, French government debt levels reached 2.2 trillion euros, the equivalent of 96.4% of French GDP.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-181"><a href="#cite_note-181">[169]</a></sup> In late 2012, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Credit_rating_agencies" title="Credit rating agencies">credit rating agencies</a> warned that growing French Government debt levels risked <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_credit_rating" title="List of countries by credit rating">France's AAA credit rating</a>, raising the possibility of a future downgrade and subsequent higher borrowing costs for the French authorities.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-182"><a href="#cite_note-182">[170]</a></sup>
However, in July 2020, during the <a href="/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic" title="COVID-19 pandemic">COVID-19 pandemic</a>, the French government issued 10-years bonds which had negative interest rates, for the first time in its history.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-183"><a href="#cite_note-183">[171]</a></sup> France also possesses in 2020 the <a href="/wiki/Gold_reserve#Officially_reported_holdings" title="Gold reserve">fourth-largest gold reserves</a> in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-184"><a href="#cite_note-184">[172]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">Economy</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_France" title="Economy of France">Economy of France</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:La_D%C3%A9fense_vue_depuis_la_Tour_Eiffel.png"><img alt="La Défense, seen from the Eiffel Tower" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3715" data-file-width="13367" decoding="async" height="83" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/96/La_D%C3%A9fense_vue_depuis_la_Tour_Eiffel.png/300px-La_D%C3%A9fense_vue_depuis_la_Tour_Eiffel.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/96/La_D%C3%A9fense_vue_depuis_la_Tour_Eiffel.png/450px-La_D%C3%A9fense_vue_depuis_la_Tour_Eiffel.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/96/La_D%C3%A9fense_vue_depuis_la_Tour_Eiffel.png/600px-La_D%C3%A9fense_vue_depuis_la_Tour_Eiffel.png 2x" width="300"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:La_D%C3%A9fense_vue_depuis_la_Tour_Eiffel.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/La_D%C3%A9fense" title="La Défense">La Défense</a> (as seen from the <a href="/wiki/Eiffel_Tower" title="Eiffel Tower">Eiffel Tower</a>) was in 2017 ranked by <a href="/wiki/Ernst_%26_Young" title="Ernst &amp; Young">Ernst &amp; Young</a> as the leading <a href="/wiki/Central_business_district" title="Central business district">Central business district</a> in continental Europe, and the fourth in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-185"><a href="#cite_note-185">[173]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>France has a developed, high-income <a href="/wiki/Mixed_economy" title="Mixed economy">mixed economy</a>, characterised by <a href="/wiki/Dirigisme" title="Dirigisme">sizeable government involvement</a>, <a href="/wiki/Economic_diversity" title="Economic diversity">economic diversity</a>, a skilled labour force, and high innovation. For roughly two centuries, the French economy has <a href="/wiki/Angus_Maddison_statistics_of_the_ten_largest_economies_by_GDP_(PPP)" title="Angus Maddison statistics of the ten largest economies by GDP (PPP)">consistently ranked</a> among the ten largest globally; it is currently the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(PPP)" title="List of countries by GDP (PPP)">ninth-largest</a> by <a href="/wiki/Purchasing_power_parity" title="Purchasing power parity">purchasing power parity</a>, the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(nominal)" title="List of countries by GDP (nominal)">seventh-largest</a> by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nominal_GDP" title="Nominal GDP">nominal GDP</a>, and the second-largest in the European Union by both metrics.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-data.worldbank.org_186-0"><a href="#cite_note-data.worldbank.org-186">[174]</a></sup> France is considered an <a href="/wiki/Economic_power" title="Economic power">economic power</a>, with membership in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Group_of_Seven" title="Group of Seven">Group of Seven</a> leading <a href="/wiki/Developed_country" title="Developed country">industrialised countries</a>, the <a href="/wiki/OECD" title="OECD">Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD)</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/G20" title="G20">Group of Twenty</a> largest economies.
</p><p>France's economy is highly diversified; <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Service_sector" title="Service sector">services</a> represent two-thirds of both the workforce and GDP,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-187"><a href="#cite_note-187">[175]</a></sup> while the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Industrial_sector" title="Industrial sector">industrial sector</a> accounts for a fifth of GDP and a similar proportion of employment. France is the third-biggest manufacturing country in Europe, behind Germany and Italy, and ranks eighth in the world by share of global manufacturing output, at 1.9 percent.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-188"><a href="#cite_note-188">[176]</a></sup> Less than 2 percent of GDP is generated by the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Primary_sector" title="Primary sector">primary sector</a>, namely agriculture;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-189"><a href="#cite_note-189">[177]</a></sup> however, France's agricultural sector is among the largest in value and leads the EU in terms of overall production.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-190"><a href="#cite_note-190">[178]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2018, France was the fifth-largest trading nation in the world and the second-largest in Europe, with the value of exports representing over a fifth of GDP.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-wto_191-0"><a href="#cite_note-wto-191">[179]</a></sup> Its membership in the <a href="/wiki/Eurozone" title="Eurozone">Eurozone</a> and the broader <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/European_Single_Market" title="European Single Market">European Single Market</a> facilitate access to capital, goods, services, and skilled labour.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-euroc_192-0"><a href="#cite_note-euroc-192">[180]</a></sup> Despite <a href="/wiki/Protectionism" title="Protectionism">protectionist</a> policies over certain industries, particularly in agriculture, France has generally played a leading role in fostering free trade and commercial integration in Europe in order to enhance its economy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-193"><a href="#cite_note-193">[181]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-194"><a href="#cite_note-194">[182]</a></sup> In 2019, it ranked first in Europe and 13th in the world in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Foreign_Direct_Investment" title="Foreign Direct Investment">foreign direct investment</a>, with European countries and the United States being leading sources.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FDI_195-0"><a href="#cite_note-FDI-195">[183]</a></sup> According to the <a href="/wiki/Bank_of_France" title="Bank of France">Bank of France</a>, the leading recipients of FDI were manufacturing, real estate, finance and insurance.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lloydsbanktrade.com_196-0"><a href="#cite_note-lloydsbanktrade.com-196">[184]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/%C3%8Ele-de-France" title="Île-de-France">Paris region</a> has the highest concentration of multinational firms in Europe.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lloydsbanktrade.com_196-1"><a href="#cite_note-lloydsbanktrade.com-196">[184]</a></sup>
</p><p>Under the doctrine of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dirigiste" title="Dirigiste"><i>Dirigisme</i></a>, the government historically played a major role in the economy; policies such as <a href="/wiki/Indicative_planning" title="Indicative planning">indicative planning</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nationalization" title="Nationalization">nationalisation</a> are credited for contributing to three decades of unprecedented postwar economic growth known as <i><a href="/wiki/Trente_Glorieuses" title="Trente Glorieuses">Trente Glorieuses</a></i>. At its peak in 1982, the public sector accounted for one-fifth of industrial employment and over four-fifths of the credit market. Beginning in the late 20th century, France loosened regulations and state involvement in the economy, with most leading companies now being privately owned; state ownership now dominates only transportation, defence and broadcasting.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-197"><a href="#cite_note-197">[185]</a></sup> Policies aimed at promoting economic dynamism and privatisation have improved France's economic standing globally: it is among the world's 10 most <a href="/wiki/Innovation" title="Innovation">innovative</a> countries in the 2020 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bloomberg_Innovation_Index" title="Bloomberg Innovation Index">Bloomberg Innovation Index</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-198"><a href="#cite_note-198">[186]</a></sup> and the 15th most competitive, according to the 2019 <a href="/wiki/Global_Competitiveness_Report#2019_rankings" title="Global Competitiveness Report">Global Competitiveness Report</a> (up two places from 2018).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-199"><a href="#cite_note-199">[187]</a></sup>
</p><p>According to the IMF, France ranked <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(nominal)_per_capita" title="List of countries by GDP (nominal) per capita">30th in GDP per capita</a>, with roughly $45,000 per inhabitant. It placed 23rd in the <a href="/wiki/Human_Development_Index" title="Human Development Index">Human Development Index</a>, indicating very high human development. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Public_corruption" title="Public corruption">Public corruption</a> is among the lowest in the world, with France consistently ranking among the 30 least corrupt countries since the <a href="/wiki/Corruption_Perceptions_Index" title="Corruption Perceptions Index">Corruption Perceptions Index</a> began in 2012; it placed 22nd in 2021, up one place from the previous year.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HDIFR_200-0"><a href="#cite_note-HDIFR-200">[188]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-201"><a href="#cite_note-201">[189]</a></sup> France is Europe's second-largest spender in <a href="/wiki/Research_and_development" title="Research and development">research and development</a>, at over 2 percent of GDP; globally, it ranks 12th.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-202"><a href="#cite_note-202">[190]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:262px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:French_economy_2016_-_expenditures.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="469" data-file-width="563" decoding="async" height="217" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/French_economy_2016_-_expenditures.png/260px-French_economy_2016_-_expenditures.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/French_economy_2016_-_expenditures.png/390px-French_economy_2016_-_expenditures.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/French_economy_2016_-_expenditures.png/520px-French_economy_2016_-_expenditures.png 2x" width="260"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:French_economy_2016_-_expenditures.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Composition of the French economy (GDP) in 2016 by expenditure type</div></div></div>
<p>Financial services, banking, and insurance are important part of the economy. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/AXA" title="AXA">AXA</a> is the world's second-largest insurance company by total nonbanking assets in 2020.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-203"><a href="#cite_note-203">[191]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-204"><a href="#cite_note-204">[192]</a></sup> As of 2011, the three largest <a href="/wiki/Cooperative_banking" title="Cooperative banking">financial institutions cooperatively owned by their customers</a> were French: <a href="/wiki/Cr%C3%A9dit_Agricole" title="Crédit Agricole">Crédit Agricole</a>, <a href="/wiki/Groupe_Caisse_d%27%C3%89pargne" title="Groupe Caisse d'Épargne">Groupe Caisse D'Epargne</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Groupe_Caisse_d%27%C3%89pargne" title="Groupe Caisse d'Épargne">Groupe Caisse D'Epargne</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-205"><a href="#cite_note-205">[193]</a></sup> According to a 2020 report by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/S%26P_Global_Market_Intelligence" title="S&amp;P Global Market Intelligence">S&amp;P Global Market Intelligenc</a>, France's leading banks, <a href="/wiki/BNP_Paribas" title="BNP Paribas">BNP Paribas</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cr%C3%A9dit_Agricole" title="Crédit Agricole">Crédit Agricole</a>, are among the top world's 10 largest bank by assets, with <a href="/wiki/Soci%C3%A9t%C3%A9_G%C3%A9n%C3%A9rale" title="Société Générale">Société Générale</a> and <a href="/wiki/Groupe_BPCE" title="Groupe BPCE">Groupe BPCE</a> ranking 17th and 19th globally, respectively.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SP_206-0"><a href="#cite_note-SP-206">[194]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Paris stock exchange (French: <i lang="fr">La Bourse de Paris</i>) is one of the oldest in the world, created by <a href="/wiki/Louis_XV" title="Louis XV">Louis XV</a> in 1724.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-207"><a href="#cite_note-207">[195]</a></sup> In 2000, it merged with counterparts in Amsterdam and Brussels to form <a href="/wiki/Euronext" title="Euronext">Euronext</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-banque_208-0"><a href="#cite_note-banque-208">[196]</a></sup> which in 2007 merged with the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/New_York_stock_exchange" title="New York stock exchange">New York stock exchange</a> to form <a href="/wiki/NYSE_Euronext" title="NYSE Euronext">NYSE Euronext</a>, the world's largest stock exchange.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-banque_208-1"><a href="#cite_note-banque-208">[196]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Euronext_Paris" title="Euronext Paris">Euronext Paris</a>, the French branch of NYSE Euronext, is Europe's second-largest stock exchange market, behind the <a href="/wiki/London_Stock_Exchange" title="London Stock Exchange">London Stock Exchange</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Agriculture">Agriculture</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:112px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Glass_of_champagne.jpg"><img alt="Champagne wine in a flute" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2048" data-file-width="1365" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/Glass_of_champagne.jpg/110px-Glass_of_champagne.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/Glass_of_champagne.jpg/165px-Glass_of_champagne.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/Glass_of_champagne.jpg/220px-Glass_of_champagne.jpg 2x" width="110"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Glass_of_champagne.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Champagne" title="Champagne">Champagne</a> is from the <a href="/wiki/Champagne_wine_region" title="Champagne wine region">Champagne region</a> in Northeast France.</div></div></div>
<p>France has historically been one of the world's major agricultural centres and remains a "global agricultural powerhouse".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-agriculture_209-0"><a href="#cite_note-agriculture-209">[197]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-210"><a href="#cite_note-210">[198]</a></sup> Nicknamed "the granary of the old continent",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-211"><a href="#cite_note-211">[199]</a></sup> over half its total land area is <a href="/wiki/Agricultural_land" title="Agricultural land">farmland</a>, of which 45 percent is devoted to permanent field crops such as cereals. The country's diverse climate, extensive arable land, modern farming technology, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Common_agricultural_policy" title="Common agricultural policy">EU subsidies</a> has made it Europe's leading agricultural producer and exporter;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-212"><a href="#cite_note-212">[200]</a></sup> it accounts for one-fifth of the EU's agricultural production, including and over one-third of its <a href="/wiki/Vegetable_oil" title="Vegetable oil">oilseeds</a>, cereals, and wine.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ministère_213-0"><a href="#cite_note-ministère-213">[201]</a></sup> As of 2017, France ranked first in Europe in beef and cereals; second in dairy and aquaculture; and third in poultry, fruits, vegetables, and manufactured chocolate products.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:6_214-0"><a href="#cite_note-:6-214">[202]</a></sup> France has the EU's largest <a href="/wiki/Cattle" title="Cattle">cattle herd</a>, at 18-19 million.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:7_215-0"><a href="#cite_note-:7-215">[203]</a></sup>
</p><p>France is the world's sixth-biggest exporter of agricultural products, generating a trade surplus of over €7.4 billion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:6_214-1"><a href="#cite_note-:6-214">[202]</a></sup> Its primary agricultural exports are wheat, poultry, dairy, beef, pork, and internationally recognised brands, particularly beverages.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:7_215-1"><a href="#cite_note-:7-215">[203]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-216"><a href="#cite_note-216">[204]</a></sup> France is the fifth largest grower of wheat, after China, India, Russia, and the United States, all of which are significantly larger.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:7_215-2"><a href="#cite_note-:7-215">[203]</a></sup> It is the world's top exporter of natural spring water, flax, malt, and potatoes.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:6_214-2"><a href="#cite_note-:6-214">[202]</a></sup> In 2020, France exported over €61 billion in agricultural products, compared to €37 billion in 2000.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-217"><a href="#cite_note-217">[205]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-218"><a href="#cite_note-218">[206]</a></sup>
</p><p>France was an <a href="/wiki/French_wine" title="French wine">early centre of viviculture</a>, dating back to at least the sixth century BCE. It is the world's second largest producer of wine, with many varieties enjoying global renown, such as <a href="/wiki/Champagne" title="Champagne">Champagne</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bordeaux_wine" title="Bordeaux wine">Bordeaux</a>;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:6_214-3"><a href="#cite_note-:6-214">[202]</a></sup> domestic consumption is also high, particularly of <a href="/wiki/Ros%C3%A9" title="Rosé">Rosé</a>. <a href="/wiki/List_of_French_rums" title="List of French rums">France produces rum</a> primarily from overseas territories such as <a href="/wiki/Martinique" title="Martinique">Martinique</a>, Guadeloupe and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/La_R%C3%A9union" title="La Réunion">La Réunion</a>.
</p><p>Relative to other developed countries, agriculture is an important sector of France's economy: 3.8% of the active population is employed in agriculture, whereas the total agri-food industry made up 4.2% of French GDP in 2005.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ministère_213-1"><a href="#cite_note-ministère-213">[201]</a></sup> France remains the largest recipient of EU agricultural subsidies, receiving an annual average of €8 billion from 2007 to 2019.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-219"><a href="#cite_note-219">[207]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-220"><a href="#cite_note-220">[208]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Tourism">Tourism</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_France" title="Tourism in France">Tourism in France</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Tour_Eiffel_Wikimedia_Commons.jpg"><img alt="Tour Eiffel at sunrise from the trocadero" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="5367" data-file-width="2900" decoding="async" height="315" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/Tour_Eiffel_Wikimedia_Commons.jpg/170px-Tour_Eiffel_Wikimedia_Commons.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/Tour_Eiffel_Wikimedia_Commons.jpg/255px-Tour_Eiffel_Wikimedia_Commons.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/Tour_Eiffel_Wikimedia_Commons.jpg/340px-Tour_Eiffel_Wikimedia_Commons.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Tour_Eiffel_Wikimedia_Commons.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Eiffel_Tower" title="Eiffel Tower">Eiffel Tower</a> is the world's most-visited paid monument, an icon of both Paris and France.</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:2015_Jardins_de_Marqueyssac_(1).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="806" data-file-width="1212" decoding="async" height="113" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/2015_Jardins_de_Marqueyssac_%281%29.jpg/170px-2015_Jardins_de_Marqueyssac_%281%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/2015_Jardins_de_Marqueyssac_%281%29.jpg/255px-2015_Jardins_de_Marqueyssac_%281%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/2015_Jardins_de_Marqueyssac_%281%29.jpg/340px-2015_Jardins_de_Marqueyssac_%281%29.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:2015_Jardins_de_Marqueyssac_(1).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Ch%C3%A2teau_de_Marqueyssac" title="Château de Marqueyssac">Château de Marqueyssac</a>, featuring a <a href="/wiki/French_formal_garden" title="French formal garden">French formal garden</a>, is one of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Remarkable_Gardens_of_France" title="Remarkable Gardens of France">Remarkable Gardens of France</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>With 89 million international tourist arrivals in 2018,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tourism.stat_221-0"><a href="#cite_note-tourism.stat-221">[209]</a></sup> France is the world's <a href="/wiki/World_Tourism_rankings" title="World Tourism rankings">top tourist destination</a>, ahead of Spain (83 million) and the United States (80 million). However, it ranks third in tourism-derived income due to shorter duration of visits.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-222"><a href="#cite_note-222">[210]</a></sup> The most popular tourist sites include (annual visitors): <a href="/wiki/Eiffel_Tower" title="Eiffel Tower">Eiffel Tower</a> (6.2 million), <a href="/wiki/Palace_of_Versailles" title="Palace of Versailles">Château de Versailles</a> (2.8 million), <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/National_Museum_of_Natural_History_(France)" title="National Museum of Natural History (France)">Muséum national d'Histoire naturelle</a> (2 million), <a href="/wiki/Pont_du_Gard" title="Pont du Gard">Pont du Gard</a> (1.5 million), <a href="/wiki/Arc_de_Triomphe" title="Arc de Triomphe">Arc de Triomphe</a> (1.2 million), <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mont_Saint-Michel" title="Mont Saint-Michel">Mont Saint-Michel</a> (1 million), <a href="/wiki/Sainte-Chapelle" title="Sainte-Chapelle">Sainte-Chapelle</a> (683,000), <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ch%C3%A2teau_du_Haut-K%C5%93nigsbourg" title="Château du Haut-Kœnigsbourg">Château du Haut-Kœnigsbourg</a> (549,000), <a href="/wiki/Puy_de_D%C3%B4me" title="Puy de Dôme">Puy de Dôme</a> (500,000), <a href="/wiki/Mus%C3%A9e_Picasso" title="Musée Picasso">Musée Picasso</a> (441,000), and <a href="/wiki/Carcassonne" title="Carcassonne">Carcassonne</a> (362,000).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-223"><a href="#cite_note-223">[211]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Paris_region">Paris region</span></h4>
<p>France, especially Paris, has some of the world's largest and most renowned museums, including the <a href="/wiki/Louvre" title="Louvre">Louvre</a>, which is the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_most_visited_art_museums_in_the_world" title="List of most visited art museums in the world">most visited art museum in the world</a> (5.7 million), the <a href="/wiki/Mus%C3%A9e_d%27Orsay" title="Musée d'Orsay">Musée d'Orsay</a> (2.1 million), mostly devoted to <a href="/wiki/Impressionism" title="Impressionism">Impressionism</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Mus%C3%A9e_de_l%27Orangerie" title="Musée de l'Orangerie">Musée de l'Orangerie</a> (1.02 million), which is home to eight large <a href="/wiki/Water_Lilies_(Monet_series)" title="Water Lilies (Monet series)">Water Lily</a> murals by <a href="/wiki/Claude_Monet" title="Claude Monet">Claude Monet</a>, as well as the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Centre_Georges_Pompidou" title="Centre Georges Pompidou">Centre Georges Pompidou</a> (1.2 million), dedicated to <a href="/wiki/Contemporary_art" title="Contemporary art">contemporary art</a>. <a href="/wiki/Disneyland_Paris" title="Disneyland Paris">Disneyland Paris</a> is Europe's most popular theme park, with 15 million combined visitors to the resort's <a href="/wiki/Disneyland_Park_(Paris)" title="Disneyland Park (Paris)">Disneyland Park</a> and <a href="/wiki/Walt_Disney_Studios_Park" title="Walt Disney Studios Park">Walt Disney Studios Park</a> in 2009.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-224"><a href="#cite_note-224">[212]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="French_Riviera">French Riviera</span></h4>
<p>With more than 10 millions tourists a year, the <a href="/wiki/French_Riviera" title="French Riviera">French Riviera</a> (French: <i>Côte d'Azur</i>), in Southeast France, is the second leading tourist destination in the country, after the <a href="/wiki/%C3%8Ele-de-France" title="Île-de-France">Paris region</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-225"><a href="#cite_note-225">[213]</a></sup> It benefits from 300 days of sunshine per year, 115 kilometres (71 mi) of coastline and beaches, 18 golf courses, 14 ski resorts and 3,000 restaurants.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CAEDA_226-0"><a href="#cite_note-CAEDA-226">[214]</a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page / location: 31">: 31 </span></sup> Each year the <i>Côte d'Azur</i> hosts 50% of the world's <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Luxury_yacht" title="Luxury yacht">superyacht</a> fleet.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CAEDA_226-1"><a href="#cite_note-CAEDA-226">[214]</a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page / location: 66">: 66 </span></sup>
</p>
<h4><span id="Ch.C3.A2teaux"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Châteaux">Châteaux</span></h4>
<p>With 6 millions tourists a year, the <a href="/wiki/Ch%C3%A2teaux_of_the_Loire_Valley" title="Châteaux of the Loire Valley">castles of the Loire Valley</a> (French: <i>châteaux</i>) and the <a href="/wiki/Loire_Valley" title="Loire Valley">Loire Valley</a> itself are the third leading tourist destination in France;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-227"><a href="#cite_note-227">[215]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-228"><a href="#cite_note-228">[216]</a></sup> this <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/World_Heritage_site" title="World Heritage site">World Heritage site</a> is noteworthy for its architectural heritage, in its historic towns but in particular its castles, such as the <a href="/wiki/Ch%C3%A2teau" title="Château">Châteaux</a> d'<a href="/wiki/Ch%C3%A2teau_d%27Amboise" title="Château d'Amboise">Amboise</a>, de <a href="/wiki/Ch%C3%A2teau_de_Chambord" title="Château de Chambord">Chambord</a>, d'<a href="/wiki/Ch%C3%A2teau_d%27Uss%C3%A9" title="Château d'Ussé">Ussé</a>, de <a href="/wiki/Ch%C3%A2teau_de_Villandry" title="Château de Villandry">Villandry</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ch%C3%A2teau_de_Chenonceau" title="Château de Chenonceau">Chenonceau</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ch%C3%A2teau_de_Montsoreau" title="Château de Montsoreau">Montsoreau</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Ch%C3%A2teau_de_Chantilly" title="Château de Chantilly">Château de Chantilly</a>, <a href="/wiki/Palace_of_Versailles" title="Palace of Versailles">Versailles</a> and <a href="/wiki/Vaux-le-Vicomte" title="Vaux-le-Vicomte">Vaux-le-Vicomte</a>, all three located near Paris, are also visitor attractions.
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Other_protected_areas">Other protected areas</span></h4>
<p>France has 37 sites inscribed in <a href="/wiki/List_of_World_Heritage_Sites_in_France" title="List of World Heritage Sites in France">UNESCO's World Heritage List</a> and features cities of high cultural interest, beaches and seaside resorts, ski resorts, as well as rural regions that many enjoy for their beauty and tranquillity (<a href="/wiki/Ecotourism" title="Ecotourism">green tourism</a>). Small and picturesque French villages are promoted through the association <i><a href="/wiki/Les_Plus_Beaux_Villages_de_France" title="Les Plus Beaux Villages de France">Les Plus Beaux Villages de France</a></i> (literally "The Most Beautiful Villages of France"). The "<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Remarkable_Gardens_of_France" title="Remarkable Gardens of France">Remarkable Gardens</a>" label is a list of the over 200 gardens classified by the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Culture_(France)" title="Ministry of Culture (France)">Ministry of Culture</a>. This label is intended to protect and promote remarkable gardens and parks. France attracts many religious <a href="/wiki/Christian_pilgrimage" title="Christian pilgrimage">pilgrims</a> on their <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Way_of_St._James" title="Way of St. James">way to St. James</a>, or to <a href="/wiki/Lourdes" title="Lourdes">Lourdes</a>, a town in the <a href="/wiki/Hautes-Pyr%C3%A9n%C3%A9es" title="Hautes-Pyrénées">Hautes-Pyrénées</a> that hosts several million visitors a year.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Energy">Energy</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Energy_in_France" title="Energy in France">Energy in France</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Centrale_EDF_de_Belleville-FR-18-a05.jpg"><img alt="Nuclear power plant in Cattenom, France four large cooling towers expelling white water vapour against a blue sky" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2736" data-file-width="3648" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/Centrale_EDF_de_Belleville-FR-18-a05.jpg/220px-Centrale_EDF_de_Belleville-FR-18-a05.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/Centrale_EDF_de_Belleville-FR-18-a05.jpg/330px-Centrale_EDF_de_Belleville-FR-18-a05.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/Centrale_EDF_de_Belleville-FR-18-a05.jpg/440px-Centrale_EDF_de_Belleville-FR-18-a05.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Centrale_EDF_de_Belleville-FR-18-a05.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Belleville_Nuclear_Power_Plant" title="Belleville Nuclear Power Plant">Belleville Nuclear Power Plant</a>. France derives most of its electricity from <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_power_in_France" title="Nuclear power in France">nuclear power</a>, the highest percentage in the world.</div></div></div>
<p>France is the world's tenth-largest producer of electricity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-229"><a href="#cite_note-229">[217]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/%C3%89lectricit%C3%A9_de_France" title="Électricité de France">Électricité de France</a> (EDF), which is majority-owned by the French government, is the country's main producer and distributor of electricity, and one of the world's largest <a href="/wiki/Electric_utility" title="Electric utility">electric utility companies</a>, ranking third in revenue globally.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-230"><a href="#cite_note-230">[218]</a></sup> In 2018, EDF produced around one-fifth of the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a>'s electricity, primarily from <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_power" title="Nuclear power">nuclear power</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-231"><a href="#cite_note-231">[219]</a></sup> As of 2021, France was the biggest energy exporter in Europe, mostly to the U.K. and Italy,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:3_232-0"><a href="#cite_note-:3-232">[220]</a></sup> and the largest net exporter of electricity in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:3_232-1"><a href="#cite_note-:3-232">[220]</a></sup>
</p><p>Since the <a href="/wiki/1973_oil_crisis" title="1973 oil crisis">1973 oil crisis</a>, France has pursued a strong policy of <a href="/wiki/Energy_security" title="Energy security">energy security</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:3_232-2"><a href="#cite_note-:3-232">[220]</a></sup> namely through <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_power_in_France" title="Nuclear power in France">heavy investment in nuclear energy</a>. It is one of 32 countries with <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_power_plant" title="Nuclear power plant">nuclear power plants</a>, ranking second in the world by the <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_power_by_country" title="Nuclear power by country">number of operational nuclear reactors</a>, at 56.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-233"><a href="#cite_note-233">[221]</a></sup> Consequently, 70% of France's electricity is generated by nuclear power, the highest proportion in the world by a wide margin;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-234"><a href="#cite_note-234">[222]</a></sup> only Slovakia and Ukraine derive a majority of electricity from nuclear power, at roughly 53% and 51%, respectively.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-235"><a href="#cite_note-235">[223]</a></sup> France is considered a world leader in nuclear technology, with reactors and fuel products being major exports.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:3_232-3"><a href="#cite_note-:3-232">[220]</a></sup>
</p><p>Due to its overwhelming reliance on nuclear power, <a href="/wiki/Renewable_energy" title="Renewable energy">renewable energies</a> have seen relatively little growth compared to other Western countries. Nevertheless, between 2008 and 2019, France's production capacity from renewable energies rose consistently and nearly doubled.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:5_236-0"><a href="#cite_note-:5-236">[224]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Hydropower" title="Hydropower">Hydropower</a> is by far the leading source, accounting for over half the country's renewable energy sources<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:4_237-0"><a href="#cite_note-:4-237">[225]</a></sup> and contributing 13% of its electricity,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:5_236-1"><a href="#cite_note-:5-236">[224]</a></sup> the highest proportion in Europe after Norway and Turkey.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:4_237-1"><a href="#cite_note-:4-237">[225]</a></sup> As with nuclear power, most hydroelectric plants, such as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Eguzon_dam" title="Eguzon dam">Eguzon</a>, <a href="/wiki/%C3%89tang_de_Soulcem" title="Étang de Soulcem">Étang de Soulcem</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Lac_de_Vouglans" title="Lac de Vouglans">Lac de Vouglans</a>, are managed by EDF.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:4_237-2"><a href="#cite_note-:4-237">[225]</a></sup> France aims to further expand hydropower into 2040.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:5_236-2"><a href="#cite_note-:5-236">[224]</a></sup>
</p><p>France made minimal but measurable investments in other renewable energy sources. Due to its geography and extensive agricultural land, it has the second-largest wind energy potential in Europe, and by 2017 had ranked eighth globally in installed wind capacity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-238"><a href="#cite_note-238">[226]</a></sup> In terms of solar power, France ranked seventh in the world in 2015 for solar photovoltaic installation capacity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-239"><a href="#cite_note-239">[227]</a></sup> As of 2019, solar power sources generated over 10,570 megawatts of electricity, compared to a little over 1,000 megawatts in 2010.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-240"><a href="#cite_note-240">[228]</a></sup>
</p><p>Because France derives the vast majority of its power from nuclear and renewable sources, close to half its primary energy (48.5%) is derived from low-carbon sources, compared to 26.4% in Europe and 15.7% in the world as a whole.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-241"><a href="#cite_note-241">[229]</a></sup> France is also the smallest emitter of <a href="/wiki/Greenhouse_gas" title="Greenhouse gas">carbon dioxide</a> among the G7.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-242"><a href="#cite_note-242">[230]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Transport">Transport</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Transport_in_France" title="Transport in France">Transport in France</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:SNCF_TGV_Duplex_Viaduc_de_Cize_-_Bolozon.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2907" data-file-width="4361" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/SNCF_TGV_Duplex_Viaduc_de_Cize_-_Bolozon.jpg/220px-SNCF_TGV_Duplex_Viaduc_de_Cize_-_Bolozon.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/SNCF_TGV_Duplex_Viaduc_de_Cize_-_Bolozon.jpg/330px-SNCF_TGV_Duplex_Viaduc_de_Cize_-_Bolozon.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/SNCF_TGV_Duplex_Viaduc_de_Cize_-_Bolozon.jpg/440px-SNCF_TGV_Duplex_Viaduc_de_Cize_-_Bolozon.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:SNCF_TGV_Duplex_Viaduc_de_Cize_-_Bolozon.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A <a href="/wiki/TGV_Duplex" title="TGV Duplex">TGV Duplex</a> crossing the <a href="/wiki/Cize%E2%80%93Bolozon_viaduct" title="Cize–Bolozon viaduct">Cize–Bolozon viaduct</a>. The train can reach a maximum speed of 360 kilometres per hour (220 mph).</div></div></div>
<p>France's <a href="/wiki/Rail_transport_in_France" title="Rail transport in France">railway network</a>, which stretches 29,473 kilometres (18,314 mi) as of 2008,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-243"><a href="#cite_note-243">[231]</a></sup> is the second most extensive in Western Europe after <a href="/wiki/Rail_transport_in_Germany" title="Rail transport in Germany">Germany</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-244"><a href="#cite_note-244">[232]</a></sup> It is operated by the <a href="/wiki/SNCF" title="SNCF">SNCF</a>, and high-speed trains include the <a href="/wiki/Thalys" title="Thalys">Thalys</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Eurostar" title="Eurostar">Eurostar</a> and <a href="/wiki/TGV" title="TGV">TGV</a>, which travels at 320 km/h (199 mph).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-245"><a href="#cite_note-245">[233]</a></sup> The Eurostar, along with the <a href="/wiki/Eurotunnel_Shuttle" title="Eurotunnel Shuttle">Eurotunnel Shuttle</a>, connects with the United Kingdom through the <a href="/wiki/Channel_Tunnel" title="Channel Tunnel">Channel Tunnel</a>. Rail connections exist to all other neighbouring countries in Europe except Andorra. Intra-urban connections are also well developed, with most major cities having <a href="/wiki/Rapid_transit" title="Rapid transit">underground</a> or tramway services complementing bus services.
</p><p>There are approximately 1,027,183 kilometres (638,262 mi) of serviceable roadway in France, ranking it the most extensive network of the European continent.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-246"><a href="#cite_note-246">[234]</a></sup> The Paris region is enveloped with the densest network of roads and highways, which connect it with virtually all parts of the country. French roads also handle substantial international traffic, connecting with cities in neighbouring Belgium, Luxembourg, Germany, Switzerland, Italy, Spain, Andorra and Monaco. There is no annual registration fee or <a href="/wiki/Road_tax" title="Road tax">road tax</a>; however, usage of the mostly privately owned motorways is through tolls except in the vicinity of large communes. The new car market is dominated by domestic brands such as <a href="/wiki/Renault" title="Renault">Renault</a>, <a href="/wiki/Peugeot" title="Peugeot">Peugeot</a> and <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn" title="Citroën">Citroën</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-247"><a href="#cite_note-247">[235]</a></sup> France possesses the <a href="/wiki/Millau_Viaduct" title="Millau Viaduct">Millau Viaduct</a>, the world's tallest bridge,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-248"><a href="#cite_note-248">[236]</a></sup> and has built many important bridges such as the <a href="/wiki/Pont_de_Normandie" title="Pont de Normandie">Pont de Normandie</a>. <a href="/wiki/Diesel_fuel" title="Diesel fuel">Diesel</a> and <a href="/wiki/Gasoline" title="Gasoline">gasoline</a> fuelled cars and lorries cause a large part of the country's <a href="/wiki/Air_pollution" title="Air pollution">air pollution</a> and <a href="/wiki/Greenhouse_gas_emissions" title="Greenhouse gas emissions">greenhouse gas emissions</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-249"><a href="#cite_note-249">[237]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-250"><a href="#cite_note-250">[238]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Air_France_Airbus_A380_landing_at_LAX.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="800" data-file-width="1200" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/Air_France_Airbus_A380_landing_at_LAX.jpg/220px-Air_France_Airbus_A380_landing_at_LAX.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/Air_France_Airbus_A380_landing_at_LAX.jpg/330px-Air_France_Airbus_A380_landing_at_LAX.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/Air_France_Airbus_A380_landing_at_LAX.jpg/440px-Air_France_Airbus_A380_landing_at_LAX.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Air_France_Airbus_A380_landing_at_LAX.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Air_France" title="Air France">Air France</a> is one of the biggest airlines in the world.</div></div></div>
<p>There are 464 <a href="/wiki/List_of_airports_in_France" title="List of airports in France">airports</a> in France.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-France_98-3"><a href="#cite_note-France-98">[86]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Charles_de_Gaulle_Airport" title="Charles de Gaulle Airport">Charles de Gaulle Airport</a>, located in the vicinity of Paris, is the largest and busiest airport in the country, handling the vast majority of popular and commercial traffic and connecting Paris with virtually all major cities across the world. <a href="/wiki/Air_France" title="Air France">Air France</a> is the national carrier airline, although numerous private airline companies provide domestic and international travel services. There are ten major ports in France, the largest of which is in <a href="/wiki/Marseille" title="Marseille">Marseille</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-251"><a href="#cite_note-251">[239]</a></sup> which also is the largest bordering the Mediterranean Sea.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-252"><a href="#cite_note-252">[240]</a></sup>12,261 kilometres (7,619 mi) of waterways traverse France including the <a href="/wiki/Canal_du_Midi" title="Canal du Midi">Canal du Midi</a>, which connects the Mediterranean Sea to the Atlantic Ocean through the <a href="/wiki/Garonne" title="Garonne">Garonne</a> river.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-France_98-4"><a href="#cite_note-France-98">[86]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Science_and_technology">Science and technology</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Science_and_technology_in_France" title="Science and technology in France">Science and technology in France</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_French_inventions_and_discoveries" title="List of French inventions and discoveries">List of French inventions and discoveries</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ariane_5_Le_Bourget_FRA_001.jpg"><img alt="Ariane 5 rocket" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3471" data-file-width="2311" decoding="async" height="255" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/05/Ariane_5_Le_Bourget_FRA_001.jpg/170px-Ariane_5_Le_Bourget_FRA_001.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/05/Ariane_5_Le_Bourget_FRA_001.jpg/255px-Ariane_5_Le_Bourget_FRA_001.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/05/Ariane_5_Le_Bourget_FRA_001.jpg/340px-Ariane_5_Le_Bourget_FRA_001.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ariane_5_Le_Bourget_FRA_001.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>France is in 2020 the biggest national financial contributor to the <a href="/wiki/European_Space_Agency" title="European Space Agency">European Space Agency</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-253"><a href="#cite_note-253">[241]</a></sup> which conceived the <a href="/wiki/Ariane_(rocket_family)" title="Ariane (rocket family)">Ariane rocket family</a>, launched from <a href="/wiki/Guiana_Space_Centre" title="Guiana Space Centre">French Guiana</a> (<a href="/wiki/Ariane_5" title="Ariane 5">Ariane 5</a> pictured).</div></div></div>
<p>Since the <a href="/wiki/Middle_Ages" title="Middle Ages">Middle Ages</a>, France has been a major contributor to scientific and technological achievement. In the early 11th century, the French-born <a href="/wiki/Pope_Sylvester_II" title="Pope Sylvester II">Pope Sylvester II</a> reintroduced the <a href="/wiki/Abacus" title="Abacus">abacus</a> and <a href="/wiki/Armillary_sphere" title="Armillary sphere">armillary sphere</a>, and introduced <a href="/wiki/Arabic_numerals" title="Arabic numerals">Arabic numerals</a> and <a href="/wiki/Clock" title="Clock">clocks</a> to much of Europe.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-254"><a href="#cite_note-254">[242]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/University_of_Paris" title="University of Paris">University of Paris</a>, founded in the mid-12th century, is still one of the most important academic institutions in the Western world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-255"><a href="#cite_note-255">[243]</a></sup> In the 17th century, mathematician <a href="/wiki/Ren%C3%A9_Descartes" title="René Descartes">René Descartes</a> pioneered <a href="/wiki/Rationalism" title="Rationalism">rationalism as a method for acquiring scientific knowledge</a>, while <a href="/wiki/Blaise_Pascal" title="Blaise Pascal">Blaise Pascal</a> became famous for his work on <a href="/wiki/Probability" title="Probability">probability</a> and <a href="/wiki/Fluid_mechanics" title="Fluid mechanics">fluid mechanics</a>; both were key figures of the <a href="/wiki/Scientific_Revolution" title="Scientific Revolution">Scientific Revolution</a>, which blossomed in Europe during this period. The <a href="/wiki/French_Academy_of_Sciences" title="French Academy of Sciences">French Academy of Sciences</a>, founded in the mid-17th century by <a href="/wiki/Louis_XIV" title="Louis XIV">Louis XIV</a> to encourage and protect French <a href="/wiki/Scientific_method" title="Scientific method">scientific research</a>, was one of the earliest <a href="/wiki/Academy_of_sciences" title="Academy of sciences">national scientific institutions</a> in history; it was at the forefront of scientific developments in Europe for the next two centuries.
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Age_of_Enlightenment" title="Age of Enlightenment">Age of Enlightenment</a> was marked by the work of biologist <a href="/wiki/Georges-Louis_Leclerc,_Comte_de_Buffon" title="Georges-Louis Leclerc, Comte de Buffon">Buffon</a>, one of the first naturalists to recognise <a href="/wiki/Ecological_succession" title="Ecological succession">ecological succession</a>, and chemist <a href="/wiki/Antoine_Lavoisier" title="Antoine Lavoisier">Lavoisier</a>, who discovered the role of <a href="/wiki/Oxygen" title="Oxygen">oxygen</a> in <a href="/wiki/Combustion" title="Combustion">combustion</a>. <a href="/wiki/Denis_Diderot" title="Denis Diderot">Diderot</a> and <a href="/wiki/Jean_le_Rond_d%27Alembert" title="Jean le Rond d'Alembert">D'Alembert</a> published the <i><a href="/wiki/Encyclop%C3%A9die" title="Encyclopédie">Encyclopédie</a></i>, which aimed to give the public access to "useful knowledge" that could be applied to everyday life.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-256"><a href="#cite_note-256">[244]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Industrial_Revolution" title="Industrial Revolution">Industrial Revolution</a> of the 19th century saw spectacular scientific developments in France, with <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Augustin_Fresnel" title="Augustin Fresnel">Augustin Fresnel</a> founding modern <a href="/wiki/Optics" title="Optics">optics</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nicolas_L%C3%A9onard_Sadi_Carnot" title="Nicolas Léonard Sadi Carnot">Sadi Carnot</a> laying the foundations of <a href="/wiki/Thermodynamics" title="Thermodynamics">thermodynamics</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Louis_Pasteur" title="Louis Pasteur">Louis Pasteur</a> pioneering of <a href="/wiki/Microbiology" title="Microbiology">microbiology</a>. Other eminent French scientists of the period have their <a href="/wiki/List_of_the_72_names_on_the_Eiffel_Tower" title="List of the 72 names on the Eiffel Tower">names inscribed on the Eiffel Tower</a>.
</p><p>Famous French scientists of the 20th century include the mathematician and physicist <a href="/wiki/Henri_Poincar%C3%A9" title="Henri Poincaré">Henri Poincaré</a>; physicists <a href="/wiki/Henri_Becquerel" title="Henri Becquerel">Henri Becquerel</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pierre_Curie" title="Pierre Curie">Pierre</a> and <a href="/wiki/Marie_Curie" title="Marie Curie">Marie Curie</a>, who remain famous for their work on <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Radioactivity" title="Radioactivity">radioactivity</a>; physicist <a href="/wiki/Paul_Langevin" title="Paul Langevin">Paul Langevin</a>; and virologist <a href="/wiki/Luc_Montagnier" title="Luc Montagnier">Luc Montagnier</a>, co-discoverer of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/HIV_AIDS" title="HIV AIDS">HIV AIDS</a>. <a href="/wiki/Hand_transplantation" title="Hand transplantation">Hand transplantation</a> was developed in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lyon,_France" title="Lyon, France">Lyon</a> in 1998 by an international team that included <a href="/wiki/Jean-Michel_Dubernard" title="Jean-Michel Dubernard">Jean-Michel Dubernard</a>, who afterward performed the first successful double hand transplant.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-dubernard1_257-0"><a href="#cite_note-dubernard1-257">[245]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Remote_surgery" title="Remote surgery">Telesurgery</a> was <a href="/wiki/Lindbergh_operation" title="Lindbergh operation">first performed</a> by French surgeons led by <a href="/wiki/Jacques_Marescaux" title="Jacques Marescaux">Jacques Marescaux</a> on 7 September 2001 across the Atlantic Ocean.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-istmarescaux_258-0"><a href="#cite_note-istmarescaux-258">[246]</a></sup> A <a href="/wiki/Face_transplant" title="Face transplant">face transplant</a> was first done on 27 November 2005 by Dr. <a href="/wiki/Bernard_Devauchelle" title="Bernard Devauchelle">Bernard Devauchelle</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-259"><a href="#cite_note-259">[247]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-260"><a href="#cite_note-260">[248]</a></sup>
</p><p>France was the <a href="/wiki/Force_de_dissuasion" title="Force de dissuasion">fourth country to achieve nuclear capability</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-261"><a href="#cite_note-261">[249]</a></sup> and has the <a href="/wiki/List_of_states_with_nuclear_weapons" title="List of states with nuclear weapons">third largest nuclear weapons arsenal</a> in the world;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-262"><a href="#cite_note-262">[250]</a></sup> it is also a leader in <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_power_in_France" title="Nuclear power in France">civilian nuclear technology</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-263"><a href="#cite_note-263">[251]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-264"><a href="#cite_note-264">[252]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-265"><a href="#cite_note-265">[253]</a></sup> France was the third nation, after the Soviet Union and the United States, to launch its <a href="/wiki/Diamant" title="Diamant">own space satellite</a>, and the first to establish a commercial <a href="/wiki/Launch_service_provider" title="Launch service provider">launch service provider</a>, <a href="/wiki/Arianespace" title="Arianespace">Arianespace</a>. The French <a href="/wiki/List_of_government_space_agencies" title="List of government space agencies">national space programme</a>, <a href="/wiki/CNES" title="CNES">CNES</a>, is the third oldest in the world, and the oldest, largest, and most active in Europe. France is a founding member of the <a href="/wiki/European_Space_Agency" title="European Space Agency">European Space Agency</a> (ESA), contributing over a quarter of its budget, the most of any member state.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-266"><a href="#cite_note-266">[254]</a></sup> ESA is headquartered in Paris, has its principal spaceport in French Guiana, and utilises the French-made <a href="/wiki/Ariane_5" title="Ariane 5">Ariane 5</a> as its primary launch vehicle.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-267"><a href="#cite_note-267">[255]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-268"><a href="#cite_note-268">[256]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-269"><a href="#cite_note-269">[257]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Airbus" title="Airbus">Airbus</a>, a leading aerospace company and the world's largest airline manufacturer, was formed partly from the French company, <a href="/wiki/A%C3%A9rospatiale" title="Aérospatiale">Aérospatiale</a>; its main commercial airline business is conducted through its French division, Airbus S.A.S.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:ESRF_img_0852.jpg"><img alt="Top view of the ring of European Synchrotron Radiation Facility" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2142" data-file-width="3457" decoding="async" height="136" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/ESRF_img_0852.jpg/220px-ESRF_img_0852.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/ESRF_img_0852.jpg/330px-ESRF_img_0852.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/ESRF_img_0852.jpg/440px-ESRF_img_0852.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:ESRF_img_0852.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/European_Synchrotron_Radiation_Facility" title="European Synchrotron Radiation Facility">European Synchrotron Radiation Facility</a> in <a href="/wiki/Grenoble" title="Grenoble">Grenoble</a></div></div></div><p>France also hosts major international research facilities, including the <a href="/wiki/European_Synchrotron_Radiation_Facility" title="European Synchrotron Radiation Facility">European Synchrotron Radiation Facility</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Institut_Laue%E2%80%93Langevin" title="Institut Laue–Langevin">Institut Laue–Langevin</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Minatec" title="Minatec">Minatec</a>, Europe's leading <a href="/wiki/Nanotechnology" title="Nanotechnology">nanotechnology</a> research centre. It is also a major member of <a href="/wiki/CERN" title="CERN">CERN</a>, which operates the largest <a href="/wiki/Particle_physics" title="Particle physics">particle physics</a> laboratory in the world and is its third largest contributor. France pioneered and hosts <a href="/wiki/ITER" title="ITER">ITER</a>, an international effort to develop nuclear fusion energy, which is the world's biggest megaproject.
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/TGV" title="TGV">TGV</a>, developed by France's national railway company, the <a href="/wiki/SNCF" title="SNCF">SNCF</a>, is a high-speed train that holds a series of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Land_speed_record_for_railed_vehicles" title="Land speed record for railed vehicles">world speed records</a>; in 2007, it became the fastest commercial wheeled train, achieving a speed of 574.8 km/h (357.2 mph).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-270"><a href="#cite_note-270">[258]</a></sup> As of 2021, it is the third-fastest train in the world, surpassed only by <a href="/wiki/Maglev" title="Maglev">maglev</a> models that utilise magnetic levitation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-271"><a href="#cite_note-271">[259]</a></sup> Western Europe is now serviced by a network of TGV lines.
</p><p>The <i><a href="/wiki/French_National_Centre_for_Scientific_Research" title="French National Centre for Scientific Research">Centre National de la Recherche Scientifique</a></i> (CNRS), the state research agency, is the largest research institute in Europe and among the most prominent internationally; according to the <a href="/wiki/Nature_Index" title="Nature Index">2020 Nature Index</a>, it ranks fourth in the share of articles published in scientific journals worldwide,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-272"><a href="#cite_note-272">[260]</a></sup> with France as a whole having the sixth-highest share.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-273"><a href="#cite_note-273">[261]</a></sup>
</p><p>As of 2022, France ranks fourth in the number of Nobel laureates, with <a href="/wiki/List_of_Nobel_laureates_by_country" title="List of Nobel laureates by country">70 French</a> people having been awarded a Nobel Prize.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-274"><a href="#cite_note-274">[262]</a></sup> Twelve French mathematicians have received a <a href="/wiki/Fields_Medal" title="Fields Medal">Fields Medal</a>, considered the most prestigious award in the field, making up one-fifth of total recipients,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-275"><a href="#cite_note-275">[263]</a></sup> and second only the United States.
</p><p>France ranked 11th in the 2021 <a href="/wiki/Global_Innovation_Index" title="Global Innovation Index">Global Innovation Index</a>, compared to 12th in 2020 and 16th in 2019.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-276"><a href="#cite_note-276">[264]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-277"><a href="#cite_note-277">[265]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-278"><a href="#cite_note-278">[266]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-279"><a href="#cite_note-279">[267]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">Demographics</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_France" title="Demographics of France">Demographics of France</a> and <a href="/wiki/French_people" title="French people">French people</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:352px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Population_density_in_France.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2100" data-file-width="2300" decoding="async" height="320" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/Population_density_in_France.png/350px-Population_density_in_France.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/Population_density_in_France.png/525px-Population_density_in_France.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/Population_density_in_France.png/700px-Population_density_in_France.png 2x" width="350"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Population_density_in_France.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Population density in France by <a href="/wiki/Arrondissements_of_France" title="Arrondissements of France">arrondissement</a>. The main urban areas are visible, notably the <a href="/wiki/%C3%8Ele-de-France" title="Île-de-France">Paris</a> (centre-north), <a href="/wiki/M%C3%A9tropole_Europ%C3%A9enne_de_Lille" title="Métropole Européenne de Lille">Lille</a> (north), <a href="/wiki/Aix-Marseille-Provence_Metropolis" title="Aix-Marseille-Provence Metropolis">Marseille</a> (southeast) and <a href="/wiki/Lyon_Metropolis" title="Lyon Metropolis">Lyon</a> (centre-southeast) urban areas.</div></div></div>
<p>With an estimated July 2022 population of 67,897,000 people,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pop_est_13-2"><a href="#cite_note-pop_est-13">[8]</a></sup> France is the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_population#Table" title="List of countries by population">20th most populous country in the world</a>, the third-most populous in Europe (after <a href="/wiki/Russia" title="Russia">Russia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Germany" title="Germany">Germany</a>), and the second most populous in the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a> (after Germany).
</p><p>France is an outlier among developed countries, particularly in Europe, for its relatively high rate of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Natural_population_growth" title="Natural population growth">natural population growth</a>: By birth rates alone, it was responsible for almost all natural population growth in the European Union in 2006.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-280"><a href="#cite_note-280">[268]</a></sup> Between 2006 and 2016, France saw the second-highest overall increase in population in the EU and was one of only four EU countries where natural births accounted for most population growth.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-281"><a href="#cite_note-281">[269]</a></sup> This was the highest rate since the end of the <a href="/wiki/Baby_boom" title="Baby boom">baby boom</a> in 1973 and coincides with the rise of the <a href="/wiki/Total_fertility_rate" title="Total fertility rate">total fertility rate</a> from a nadir of 1.7 in 1994 to 2.0 in 2010.
</p><p>As of January 2021<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=France&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, the fertility rate declined slightly to 1.84 children per woman, below the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Replacement_rate" title="Replacement rate">replacement rate</a> of 2.1, and considerably below the high of 4.41 in 1800.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-282"><a href="#cite_note-282">[270]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-283"><a href="#cite_note-283">[271]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-population_284-0"><a href="#cite_note-population-284">[272]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-285"><a href="#cite_note-285">[273]</a></sup> France's fertility rate and crude birth rate nonetheless remain among the highest in the EU. However, like many developed nations, the French <a href="/wiki/Population_ageing" title="Population ageing">population is aging</a>; the average age is 41.7 years, while about a fifth of French people are 65 or over.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-286"><a href="#cite_note-286">[274]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_life_expectancy" title="List of countries by life expectancy">Average life expectancy</a> at birth is 82.7 years, the 12th highest in the world.
</p><p>From 2006 to 2011, population growth averaged 0.6 percent per year;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-evol_287-0"><a href="#cite_note-evol-287">[275]</a></sup> since 2011, annual growth has been between 0.4 and 0.5 percent annually.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-288"><a href="#cite_note-288">[276]</a></sup> Immigrants are major contributors to this trend; in 2010, 27 percent of newborns in metropolitan France had at least one <a href="/wiki/Immigration_to_France#Immigration_per_region" title="Immigration to France">foreign-born</a> parent and another 24 percent had at least one parent born outside Europe (excluding French overseas territories).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-289"><a href="#cite_note-289">[277]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Ethnic_groups">Ethnic groups</span></h3>
<p>Most <a href="/wiki/French_people" title="French people">French people</a> are of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Celtic_peoples" title="Celtic peoples">Celtic</a>-<a href="/wiki/Gauls" title="Gauls">Gallic</a> origin, with a significant admixture of <a href="/wiki/Italic_peoples" title="Italic peoples">Italic</a> (<a href="/wiki/Roman_Empire" title="Roman Empire">Romans</a>) and <a href="/wiki/Germanic_peoples" title="Germanic peoples">Germanic</a> (<a href="/wiki/Franks" title="Franks">Franks</a>) groups reflecting centuries of respective migration and settlement.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-290"><a href="#cite_note-290">[278]</a></sup> Through the course of the <a href="/wiki/Middle_Ages" title="Middle Ages">Middle Ages</a>, France incorporated various neighbouring ethnic and linguistic groups, as evidenced by <a href="/wiki/Bretons" title="Bretons">Breton</a> elements in the west, <a href="/wiki/Aquitani" title="Aquitani">Aquitanian</a> in the southwest, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Scandinavian_people" title="Scandinavian people">Scandinavian</a> in the northwest, <a href="/wiki/Alemanni" title="Alemanni">Alemannic</a> in the northeast, and <a href="/wiki/Ligures" title="Ligures">Ligurian</a> in the southeast.
</p><p>Large-scale immigration over the last century and a half has led to a more multicultural society; beginning with the French Revolution, and further codified in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/French_Constitution" title="French Constitution">French Constitution of 1958</a>, the government is prohibited from collecting data on ethnicity and ancestry; most demographic information is drawn from private sector organisations or academic institutions. In 2004, the <i>Institut Montaign</i>e estimated that within Metropolitan France, 51 million people were White (85% of the population), 6 million were Northwest African (10%), 2 million were Black (3.3%), and 1 million were Asian (1.7%).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-291"><a href="#cite_note-291">[279]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-292"><a href="#cite_note-292">[280]</a></sup>
</p><p>A 2008 poll conducted jointly by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/INED" title="INED">INED</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/INSEE" title="INSEE">the French National Institute of Statistics</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-293"><a href="#cite_note-293">[281]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Oppenheimer_294-0"><a href="#cite_note-Oppenheimer-294">[282]</a></sup> estimated that the largest ancestry groups were <a href="/wiki/Italians_in_France" title="Italians in France">Italian</a> (5 million), followed by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Northwest_African" title="Northwest African">Northwest African</a> (3-6 million),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Cohen1995_295-0"><a href="#cite_note-Cohen1995-295">[283]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-296"><a href="#cite_note-296">[284]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-297"><a href="#cite_note-297">[285]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Afro-French" title="Afro-French">Sub-Saharan African</a> (2.5 million), Armenian (500,000), and Turkish (200,000).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-298"><a href="#cite_note-298">[286]</a></sup> There are also sizeable minorities of other <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/European_ethnic_groups" title="European ethnic groups">European ethnic groups</a>, namely <a href="/wiki/Spaniards" title="Spaniards">Spanish</a>, <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_people" title="Portuguese people">Portuguese</a>, <a href="/wiki/Poles" title="Poles">Polish</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Greeks" title="Greeks">Greek</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Cohen1995_295-1"><a href="#cite_note-Cohen1995-295">[283]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-299"><a href="#cite_note-299">[287]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-300"><a href="#cite_note-300">[288]</a></sup> France has a significant <a href="/wiki/Romani_people_in_France" title="Romani people in France">Gitan (Romani)</a> population, numbering between 20,000 and 400,000;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-301"><a href="#cite_note-301">[289]</a></sup> many foreign <a href="/wiki/Romani_people" title="Romani people">Roma</a> are <a href="/wiki/Deportation_of_Roma_migrants_from_France" title="Deportation of Roma migrants from France">expelled back to Bulgaria and Romania frequently.</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-302"><a href="#cite_note-302">[290]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Immigration">Immigration</span></h3>
