<td colspan="4" style="text-align: left"><span style="font-size:85%;">Sources: INSEE census figures,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-304"><a href="#cite_note-304">[291]</a></sup> UN SDG regions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-305"><a href="#cite_note-305">[292]</a></sup></span>
<p><span style="font-size:85%;">Note: Figures for 2019 refer to <a href="/wiki/Metropolitan_France" title="Metropolitan France">Metropolitan France</a> and the 5 <a href="/wiki/Overseas_departments_and_regions_of_France" title="Overseas departments and regions of France">overseas regions</a> (<a href="/wiki/Mayotte" title="Mayotte">Mayotte</a> included). Figures for 2009 do not include Mayotte. The <a href="/wiki/Overseas_collectivity" title="Overseas collectivity">overseas collectivities</a> in the Pacific Ocean are included neither in 2009 nor in 2019.</span>
</p>
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>It is currently estimated that 40% of the French population is descended at least partially from the different waves of immigration since the early 20th century;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-306"><a href="#cite_note-306">[293]</a></sup> between 1921 and 1935 alone, about 1.1 million net immigrants came to France.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-307"><a href="#cite_note-307">[294]</a></sup> The next largest wave came in the 1960s, when around 1.6 million <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pieds_noirs" title="Pieds noirs">pieds noirs</a></i> returned to France following the independence of its Northwest African possessions, Algeria and Morocco.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-308"><a href="#cite_note-308">[295]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-309"><a href="#cite_note-309">[296]</a></sup> They were joined by numerous former colonial subjects from North and West Africa, as well as numerous European immigrants from Spain and Portugal.
</p><p>France remains a major destination for immigrants, accepting about 200,000 legal immigrants annually.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-310"><a href="#cite_note-310">[297]</a></sup> In 2005, it was Western Europe's leading recipient of <a href="/wiki/Refugee" title="Refugee">asylum</a> seekers, with an estimated 50,000 applications (albeit 15% decrease from 2004).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UNHCR_311-0"><a href="#cite_note-UNHCR-311">[298]</a></sup> In 2010, France received about 48,100 asylum applications—placing it among the top five asylum recipients in the world<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-312"><a href="#cite_note-312">[299]</a></sup> and in subsequent years it saw the number of applications increase, ultimately doubling to 100,412 in 2017.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-313"><a href="#cite_note-313">[300]</a></sup> The European Union allows free movement between the member states, although France established controls to curb <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Eastern_European" title="Eastern European">Eastern European</a> migration,<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (October 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> and immigration remains a contentious political issue.
</p><p>In 2008, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/INSEE" title="INSEE">INSEE</a> (National Institute of Statistics and Economic Studies) estimated that the total number of foreign-born immigrants was around 5 million (8% of the population), while their French-born descendants numbered 6.5 million, or 11% of the population. Thus, nearly a fifth of the country's population were either first or second-generation immigrants, of which more than 5 million were of European origin and 4 million of <a href="/wiki/Maghrebis" title="Maghrebis">Maghrebi</a> ancestry.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-314"><a href="#cite_note-314">[301]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Insee_1_315-0"><a href="#cite_note-Insee_1-315">[302]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-INSEE1_316-0"><a href="#cite_note-INSEE1-316">[303]</a></sup> In 2008, France granted <a href="/wiki/Citizenship" title="Citizenship">citizenship</a> to 137,000 persons, mostly from Morocco, Algeria and Turkey.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-317"><a href="#cite_note-317">[304]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2014, the INSEE reported a significant increase in the number of immigrants coming from Spain, Portugal and Italy between 2009 and 2012. According to the French Institute, this increase resulted from the financial crisis that hit several European countries in that period.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sudouest.fr_318-0"><a href="#cite_note-sudouest.fr-318">[305]</a></sup> Statistics on Spanish immigrants in France show a growth of 107 percent between 2009 and 2012, with the population growing from 5,300 to 11,000.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sudouest.fr_318-1"><a href="#cite_note-sudouest.fr-318">[305]</a></sup> Of the total of 229,000 foreigners who were in France in 2012, nearly 8% were Portuguese, 5% British, 5% Spanish, 4% Italian, 4% German, 3% Romanian, and 3% Belgian.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sudouest.fr_318-2"><a href="#cite_note-sudouest.fr-318">[305]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Major_cities">Major cities</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Functional_area_(France)" title="Functional area (France)">Functional area (France)</a> and <a href="/wiki/Urban_unit" title="Urban unit">Urban unit</a></div>
<p>France is a highly urbanised country, with its <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_cities_in_France_over_20,000_population_(1999_census)" title="List of cities in France over 20,000 population (1999 census)">largest cities</a> (in terms of <a href="/wiki/Functional_area_(France)" title="Functional area (France)">metropolitan area</a> population in 2019<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-319"><a href="#cite_note-319">[306]</a></sup>) being Paris (13,114,718 inh.), <a href="/wiki/Lyon" title="Lyon">Lyon</a> (2,280,845), <a href="/wiki/Marseille" title="Marseille">Marseille</a> (1,873,270), <a href="/wiki/Lille" title="Lille">Lille</a> (1,510,079), <a href="/wiki/Toulouse" title="Toulouse">Toulouse</a> (1,454,158), <a href="/wiki/Bordeaux" title="Bordeaux">Bordeaux</a> (1,363,711), <a href="/wiki/Nantes" title="Nantes">Nantes</a> (1,011,020), <a href="/wiki/Strasbourg" title="Strasbourg">Strasbourg</a> (853,110), <a href="/wiki/Montpellier" title="Montpellier">Montpellier</a> (801,595), and <a href="/wiki/Rennes" title="Rennes">Rennes</a> (755,668). (Note: since its 2020 revision of metropolitan area borders, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/INSEE" title="INSEE">INSEE</a> considers that <a href="/wiki/Nice" title="Nice">Nice</a> is a metropolitan area separate from the <a href="/wiki/Cannes" title="Cannes">Cannes</a>-<a href="/wiki/Antibes" title="Antibes">Antibes</a> metropolitan area; these two combined would have a population of 1,008,296, as of 2019 census). <a href="/wiki/Rural_flight" title="Rural flight">Rural flight</a> was a perennial political issue throughout most of the 20th century.
</p>
<div>

<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Language">Language</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/French_language" title="French language">French language</a>, <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_France" title="Languages of France">Languages of France</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Organisation_internationale_de_la_Francophonie" title="Organisation internationale de la Francophonie">Organisation internationale de la Francophonie</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:332px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Map-Francophone_World.svg"><img alt="world map of French speaking countries" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1398" data-file-width="2754" decoding="async" height="168" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/Map-Francophone_World.svg/330px-Map-Francophone_World.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/Map-Francophone_World.svg/495px-Map-Francophone_World.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/Map-Francophone_World.svg/660px-Map-Francophone_World.svg.png 2x" width="330"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Map-Francophone_World.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Map of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_territorial_entities_where_French_is_an_official_language" title="List of territorial entities where French is an official language">Francophone</a> world: <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r981673959">.mw-parser-output .legend{page-break-inside:avoid;break-inside:avoid-column}.mw-parser-output .legend-color{display:inline-block;min-width:1.25em;height:1.25em;line-height:1.25;margin:1px 0;text-align:center;border:1px solid black;background-color:transparent;color:black}.mw-parser-output .legend-text{}</style><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#0c5eb1; color:white;"> </span> Native language</div> <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#0080ff; color:black;"> </span> Administrative language</div> <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#9fceff; color:black;"> </span> Secondary or non-official language</div> <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#00ff00; color:black;"> </span> Francophone minorities</div></div></div></div>
<p>According to Article 2 of the Constitution, the official language of France is French,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-320"><a href="#cite_note-320">[307]</a></sup> a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Romance_language" title="Romance language">Romance language</a> derived from <a href="/wiki/Latin" title="Latin">Latin</a>. Since 1635, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Acad%C3%A9mie_fran%C3%A7aise" title="Académie française">Académie française</a> has been France's official authority on the French language, although its recommendations carry no legal weight. There are also regional languages spoken in France, such as <a href="/wiki/Occitan_language" title="Occitan language">Occitan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Breton_language" title="Breton language">Breton</a>, <a href="/wiki/Catalan_language" title="Catalan language">Catalan</a>, <a href="/wiki/French_Flemish" title="French Flemish">Flemish</a> (<a href="/wiki/Dutch_language" title="Dutch language">Dutch</a> dialect), <a href="/wiki/Alsatian_dialect" title="Alsatian dialect">Alsatian</a> (German dialect), <a href="/wiki/Basque_language" title="Basque language">Basque</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Corsican_language" title="Corsican language">Corsican</a> (Italian dialect). Italian was the official language of Corsica until 9 May 1859.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-321"><a href="#cite_note-321">[308]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Government of France does not regulate the choice of language in publications by individuals, but the use of French is required by law in commercial and workplace communications. In addition to mandating the use of French in the territory of the Republic, the French government tries to promote French in the European Union and globally through institutions such as the <a href="/wiki/Organisation_internationale_de_la_Francophonie" title="Organisation internationale de la Francophonie">Organisation internationale de la Francophonie</a>. The perceived threat from <a href="/wiki/Anglicisation" title="Anglicisation">anglicisation</a> has prompted efforts to safeguard the position of the French language in France. Besides French, there exist 77 vernacular minority languages of France, eight spoken in French metropolitan territory and 69 in the French <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Overseas_departments_and_territories_of_France" title="Overseas departments and territories of France">overseas territories</a>.
</p><p>From the 17th to the mid-20th century, French served as the pre-eminent international language of diplomacy and international affairs as well as a <a href="/wiki/Lingua_franca" title="Lingua franca">lingua franca</a> among the educated classes of Europe.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-exception_322-0"><a href="#cite_note-exception-322">[309]</a></sup> The dominant position of French language in international affairs was overtaken by English, since the emergence of the United States as a major power.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Language_and_Diplomacy_69-1"><a href="#cite_note-Language_and_Diplomacy-69">[57]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-323"><a href="#cite_note-323">[310]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-324"><a href="#cite_note-324">[311]</a></sup>
</p><p>For most of the time in which French served as an international lingua franca, it was not the native language of most Frenchmen: a report in 1794 conducted by <a href="/wiki/Henri_Gr%C3%A9goire" title="Henri Grégoire">Henri Grégoire</a> found that of the country's 25 million people, only three million spoke French natively; the rest spoke one of the country's many regional languages, such as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Alsatian_language" title="Alsatian language">Alsatian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Breton_language" title="Breton language">Breton</a> or <a href="/wiki/Occitan_language" title="Occitan language">Occitan</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-325"><a href="#cite_note-325">[312]</a></sup> Through the expansion of public education, in which French was the sole language of instruction, as well as other factors such as increased urbanisation and the rise of mass communication, French gradually came to be adopted by virtually the entire population, a process not completed until the 20th century.
</p><p>As a result of France's extensive <a href="/wiki/French_colonial_empire" title="French colonial empire">colonial ambitions</a> between the 17th and 20th centuries, French was introduced to the Americas, Africa, Polynesia, South-East Asia, as well as the <a href="/wiki/Caribbean" title="Caribbean">Caribbean</a>. French is the second most studied foreign language in the world after English,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-326"><a href="#cite_note-326">[313]</a></sup> and is a lingua franca in some regions, notably in Africa. The legacy of French as a living language outside Europe is mixed: it is nearly extinct in some former French colonies (The Levant, South and Southeast Asia), while creoles and pidgins based on French have emerged in the French departments in the <a href="/wiki/West_Indies" title="West Indies">West Indies</a> and the South Pacific (<a href="/wiki/French_Polynesia" title="French Polynesia">French Polynesia</a>). On the other hand, many former French colonies have adopted French as an official language, and the total number of French speakers is increasing, especially in Africa.
</p><p>It is estimated that between 300 million<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-327"><a href="#cite_note-327">[314]</a></sup> and 500 million<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-328"><a href="#cite_note-328">[315]</a></sup> people worldwide can speak French, either as a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mother_tongue" title="Mother tongue">mother tongue</a> or a <a href="/wiki/Second_language" title="Second language">second language</a>.
</p><p>According to the 2007 Adult Education survey, part of a project by the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a> and carried in France by the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/INSEE" title="INSEE">INSEE</a> and based on a sample of 15,350 persons, French was the native language of 87.2% of the total population, or roughly 55.81 million people, followed by Arabic (3.6%, 2.3 million), Portuguese (1.5%, 960,000), Spanish (1.2%, 770,000) and Italian (1.0%, 640,000). Native speakers of other languages made up the remaining 5.2% of the population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-329"><a href="#cite_note-329">[316]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Religion">Religion</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_France" title="Religion in France">Religion in France</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Reims_Cath%C3%A9drale_Notre-Dame_5002_(fixed_angles).jpg"><img alt="Notre-Dame de Reims façade, gothic stone cathedral against blue sky" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2918" data-file-width="1925" decoding="async" height="273" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9e/Reims_Cath%C3%A9drale_Notre-Dame_5002_%28fixed_angles%29.jpg/180px-Reims_Cath%C3%A9drale_Notre-Dame_5002_%28fixed_angles%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9e/Reims_Cath%C3%A9drale_Notre-Dame_5002_%28fixed_angles%29.jpg/270px-Reims_Cath%C3%A9drale_Notre-Dame_5002_%28fixed_angles%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9e/Reims_Cath%C3%A9drale_Notre-Dame_5002_%28fixed_angles%29.jpg/360px-Reims_Cath%C3%A9drale_Notre-Dame_5002_%28fixed_angles%29.jpg 2x" width="180"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Reims_Cath%C3%A9drale_Notre-Dame_5002_(fixed_angles).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Reims_Cathedral" title="Reims Cathedral">Notre-Dame de Reims</a> is the Roman Catholic cathedral where the <a href="/wiki/Coronation_of_the_French_monarch" title="Coronation of the French monarch">Kings of France were crowned</a> until 1825.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-330"><a href="#cite_note-330">[XIV]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>France is a secular country in which <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_religion" title="Freedom of religion">freedom of religion</a> is a constitutional right. French religious policy is based on the concept of <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/La%C3%AFcit%C3%A9" title="Laïcité">laïcité</a></i>, a strict <a href="/wiki/Separation_of_church_and_state" title="Separation of church and state">separation of church and state</a> under which public life is kept completely secular. The exception to this is the region of <a href="/wiki/Alsace" title="Alsace">Alsace</a> and <a href="/wiki/Moselle" title="Moselle">Moselle</a> where Lutheranism, Catholicism and Judaism enjoy official status and state funding.
</p><p>According to a survey held in 2016 by <a href="/wiki/Institut_Montaigne" title="Institut Montaigne">Institut Montaigne</a> and <a href="/wiki/Institut_fran%C3%A7ais_d%27opinion_publique" title="Institut français d'opinion publique">Institut français d'opinion publique</a> (IFOP), 51.1% of the total population of France was Christian, 39.6% had no religion (<a href="/wiki/Atheism" title="Atheism">atheism</a> or agnosticism), 5.6% were <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Muslim" title="Muslim">Muslims</a>, 2.5% were followers of other faiths, and the remaining 0.4% were undecided about their faith.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2016Montaigne-IFOP_331-0"><a href="#cite_note-2016Montaigne-IFOP-331">[317]</a></sup> Estimates of the number of <a href="/wiki/Islam_in_France" title="Islam in France">Muslims in France</a> vary widely. In 2003, the French Ministry of the Interior estimated the total number of people of Muslim background to be between 5 and 6 million (8–10%).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-332"><a href="#cite_note-332">[318]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-333"><a href="#cite_note-333">[319]</a></sup> The current <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jews_in_France" title="Jews in France">Jewish community in France</a> is the largest in Europe and the third largest in the world after Israel and the United States, ranging between 480,000 and 600,000, about 0.8% of the population as of 2016.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2016Montaigne-IFOP_331-1"><a href="#cite_note-2016Montaigne-IFOP-331">[317]</a></sup>
</p><p><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Catholicism" title="Catholicism">Catholicism</a> has been the predominant religion in France for more than a millennium, though it is not as actively practised today as it was. Among the 47,000 religious buildings in France, 94% are <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church" title="Catholic Church">Roman Catholic</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-334"><a href="#cite_note-334">[320]</a></sup> During the <a href="/wiki/French_Revolution" title="French Revolution">French Revolution</a>, activists conducted a brutal <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dechristianisation_of_France_during_the_French_Revolution" title="Dechristianisation of France during the French Revolution">campaign of de-Christianisation</a>, ending the Catholic Church as the state religion. In some cases, clergy and churches were attacked, with iconoclasm stripping the churches of statues and ornaments. After alternating between royal and secular republican governments during the 19th century, in 1905 France passed the <a href="/wiki/1905_French_law_on_the_Separation_of_the_Churches_and_the_State" title="1905 French law on the Separation of the Churches and the State">1905 law on the Separation of the Churches and the State</a>, which established the principle of <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/La%C3%AFcit%C3%A9" title="Laïcité">laïcité</a></i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-georgetown2_335-0"><a href="#cite_note-georgetown2-335">[321]</a></sup>
</p><p>To this day, the government is prohibited from recognising any specific right to a religious community (except for legacy statutes like those of military chaplains and the <a href="/wiki/Local_law_in_Alsace-Moselle" title="Local law in Alsace-Moselle">local law in Alsace-Moselle</a>). It recognises religious organisations according to formal legal criteria that do not address religious doctrine. Conversely, religious organisations are expected to refrain from intervening in policymaking.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-336"><a href="#cite_note-336">[322]</a></sup>
</p><p>Certain groups, such as <a href="/wiki/Scientology" title="Scientology">Scientology</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Children_of_God_(New_Religious_Movement)" title="Children of God (New Religious Movement)">Children of God</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Unification_Church" title="Unification Church">Unification Church</a>, or the <a href="/wiki/Order_of_the_Solar_Temple" title="Order of the Solar Temple">Order of the Solar Temple</a> are considered <a href="/wiki/Cult" title="Cult">cults</a> ("<i><a href="/wiki/Sect" title="Sect">sectes</a></i>" in French); therefore they do not have the same status as recognised religions in France.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-337"><a href="#cite_note-337">[323]</a></sup> <i>Secte</i> is considered a pejorative term in France.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-338"><a href="#cite_note-338">[324]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Health">Health</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Health_in_France" title="Health in France">Health in France</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:La_Pitie-Salpetriere_under_snow_2013-03-12.jpg"><img alt="Pitié-Salpêtrière Hospital in Paris, stone building with slate dome" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2386" data-file-width="6759" decoding="async" height="78" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/La_Pitie-Salpetriere_under_snow_2013-03-12.jpg/220px-La_Pitie-Salpetriere_under_snow_2013-03-12.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/La_Pitie-Salpetriere_under_snow_2013-03-12.jpg/330px-La_Pitie-Salpetriere_under_snow_2013-03-12.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/La_Pitie-Salpetriere_under_snow_2013-03-12.jpg/440px-La_Pitie-Salpetriere_under_snow_2013-03-12.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:La_Pitie-Salpetriere_under_snow_2013-03-12.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Piti%C3%A9-Salp%C3%AAtri%C3%A8re_Hospital" title="Pitié-Salpêtrière Hospital">Pitié-Salpêtrière Hospital</a>, a teaching hospital in Paris, is one of Europe's largest hospitals.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-339"><a href="#cite_note-339">[325]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Health_in_France" title="Health in France">French health care system</a> is one of <a href="/wiki/Universal_health_care" title="Universal health care">universal health care</a> largely financed by government <a href="/wiki/National_health_insurance" title="National health insurance">national health insurance</a>. In its 2000 assessment of world health care systems, the <a href="/wiki/World_Health_Organization" title="World Health Organization">World Health Organization</a> found that France provided the "close to best overall health care" in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-who.int_340-0"><a href="#cite_note-who.int-340">[326]</a></sup> The French healthcare system was ranked first worldwide by the World Health Organization in 1997.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-341"><a href="#cite_note-341">[327]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-342"><a href="#cite_note-342">[328]</a></sup> In 2011, France spent 11.6% of GDP on health care, or US$4,086 per capita,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WHO_country_facts:_France_343-0"><a href="#cite_note-WHO_country_facts:_France-343">[329]</a></sup> a figure much higher than the average spent by countries in Europe but <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Health_care_compared" title="Health care compared">less than in the United States</a>. Approximately 77% of health expenditures are covered by government funded agencies.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-344"><a href="#cite_note-344">[330]</a></sup>
</p><p>Care is generally free for people affected by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chronic_disease" title="Chronic disease">chronic diseases</a> (<i>affections de longues durées</i>) such as cancer, AIDS or <a href="/wiki/Cystic_fibrosis" title="Cystic fibrosis">cystic fibrosis</a>. Average life expectancy at birth is 78 years for men and 85 years for women, one of the highest of the European Union and the World.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-345"><a href="#cite_note-345">[331]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-346"><a href="#cite_note-346">[332]</a></sup> There are 3.22 physicians for every 1000 inhabitants in France,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-347"><a href="#cite_note-347">[333]</a></sup> and average health care spending per capita was US$4,719 in 2008.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-348"><a href="#cite_note-348">[334]</a></sup>
As of 2007<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=France&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, approximately 140,000 inhabitants (0.4%) of France are living with HIV/AIDS.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-France_98-5"><a href="#cite_note-France-98">[86]</a></sup>
</p><p>Even if the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Frenchmen" title="Frenchmen">French</a> have the reputation of being one of the thinnest people in developed countries,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-obesity_349-0"><a href="#cite_note-obesity-349">[335]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-daily_350-0"><a href="#cite_note-daily-350">[336]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Telegraph_351-0"><a href="#cite_note-Telegraph-351">[337]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bloomberg_352-0"><a href="#cite_note-bloomberg-352">[338]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-353"><a href="#cite_note-353">[339]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources#Bundling_citations" title="Wikipedia:Citing sources"><span title="This claim has too many footnotes for reading to be smooth. (September 2021)">excessive citations</span></a></i>]</sup> France—like other rich countries—faces an increasing and recent epidemic of <a href="/wiki/Obesity" title="Obesity">obesity</a>, due mostly to the replacement in French eating habits of traditional healthy French cuisine by <a href="/wiki/Junk_food" title="Junk food">junk food</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-354"><a href="#cite_note-354">[340]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-obesity_349-1"><a href="#cite_note-obesity-349">[335]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-daily_350-1"><a href="#cite_note-daily-350">[336]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-obesity2_355-0"><a href="#cite_note-obesity2-355">[341]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources#Bundling_citations" title="Wikipedia:Citing sources"><span title="This claim has too many footnotes for reading to be smooth. (September 2021)">excessive citations</span></a></i>]</sup> The French obesity rate is still far below that of the United States—currently equal to American rate in the 1970s—and is still the lowest of Europe.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-daily_350-2"><a href="#cite_note-daily-350">[336]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bloomberg_352-1"><a href="#cite_note-bloomberg-352">[338]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-obesity2_355-1"><a href="#cite_note-obesity2-355">[341]</a></sup> Authorities now regard obesity as one of the main public health issues and fight it fiercely.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-356"><a href="#cite_note-356">[342]</a></sup> Rates of <a href="/wiki/Childhood_obesity" title="Childhood obesity">childhood obesity</a> are slowing in France, while continuing to grow in other countries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-357"><a href="#cite_note-357">[343]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Education">Education</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Education_in_France" title="Education in France">Education in France</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:%C3%89cole_normale_sup%C3%A9rieure_de_Paris,_26_January_2013.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2668" data-file-width="1814" decoding="async" height="324" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8c/%C3%89cole_normale_sup%C3%A9rieure_de_Paris%2C_26_January_2013.jpg/220px-%C3%89cole_normale_sup%C3%A9rieure_de_Paris%2C_26_January_2013.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8c/%C3%89cole_normale_sup%C3%A9rieure_de_Paris%2C_26_January_2013.jpg/330px-%C3%89cole_normale_sup%C3%A9rieure_de_Paris%2C_26_January_2013.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8c/%C3%89cole_normale_sup%C3%A9rieure_de_Paris%2C_26_January_2013.jpg/440px-%C3%89cole_normale_sup%C3%A9rieure_de_Paris%2C_26_January_2013.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:%C3%89cole_normale_sup%C3%A9rieure_de_Paris,_26_January_2013.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/%C3%89cole_normale_sup%C3%A9rieure_(Paris)" title="École normale supérieure (Paris)">École normale supérieure</a> (ENS) in Paris, established in the end of the 18th century, produces more <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize" title="Nobel Prize">Nobel Prize</a> laureates <a href="/wiki/Per_capita" title="Per capita">per capita</a> than any other institution in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-358"><a href="#cite_note-358">[344]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>In 1802, <a href="/wiki/Napoleon" title="Napoleon">Napoleon</a> created the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lyc%C3%A9e" title="Lycée">lycée</a>, the second and final stage of secondary education that prepares students for higher education studies or a profession.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-359"><a href="#cite_note-359">[345]</a></sup> Nevertheless, <a href="/wiki/Jules_Ferry" title="Jules Ferry">Jules Ferry</a> is considered the father of the French modern school, leading reforms in the late 19th century that established free, secular and compulsory education (currently mandatory until the age of 16).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-360"><a href="#cite_note-360">[346]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-361"><a href="#cite_note-361">[347]</a></sup>
</p><p>French education is centralised and divided into three stages: Primary, secondary, and higher education. The <a href="/wiki/Programme_for_International_Student_Assessment" title="Programme for International Student Assessment">Programme for International Student Assessment</a>, coordinated by the <a href="/wiki/OECD" title="OECD">OECD</a>, ranked France's education as near OECD average in 2018.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-362"><a href="#cite_note-362">[348]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:2_363-0"><a href="#cite_note-:2-363">[349]</a></sup> France was one of the PISA-participating countries where school children perceived some of the lowest levels of support and feedback from their teachers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:2_363-1"><a href="#cite_note-:2-363">[349]</a></sup> School children in France reported greater concern about the disciplinary climate and behaviour in classrooms compared to other <a href="/wiki/OECD" title="OECD">OECD</a> countries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:2_363-2"><a href="#cite_note-:2-363">[349]</a></sup>
</p><p>Primary and secondary education are predominantly public, run by the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_National_Education_(France)" title="Ministry of National Education (France)">Ministry of National Education</a>. While training and remuneration of teachers and the curriculum are the responsibility of the state centrally, the management of primary and secondary schools is overseen by local authorities. Primary education comprises two phases, nursery school (<i>école maternelle</i>) and elementary school (<i>école élémentaire</i>). Nursery school aims to stimulate the minds of very young children and promote their socialisation and development of a basic grasp of language and numbers. Around the age of six, children transfer to elementary school, whose primary objectives are learning about writing, arithmetic and citizenship. Secondary education also consists of two phases. The first is delivered through colleges (<i>collège</i>) and leads to the national certificate (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dipl%C3%B4me_national_du_brevet" title="Diplôme national du brevet">Diplôme national du brevet</a>). The second is offered in high schools (<i>lycée</i>) and finishes in national exams leading to a baccalaureate (<i>baccalauréat</i>, available in professional, technical or general flavours) or certificate of professional competence (<i>certificat d'aptitude professionelle</i>).
</p><p>Higher education is divided between <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Universities_in_France" title="Universities in France">public universities</a> and the prestigious and selective <i><a href="/wiki/Grande_%C3%A9cole" title="Grande école">Grandes écoles</a></i>, such as <a href="/wiki/Sciences_Po" title="Sciences Po">Sciences Po Paris</a> for Political studies, <a href="/wiki/HEC_Paris" title="HEC Paris">HEC Paris</a> for Economics, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/%C3%89cole_Polytechnique" title="École Polytechnique">Polytechnique</a>, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/%C3%89cole_des_hautes_%C3%A9tudes_en_sciences_sociales" title="École des hautes études en sciences sociales">École des hautes études en sciences sociales</a> for Social studies and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/%C3%89cole_nationale_sup%C3%A9rieure_des_mines_de_Paris" title="École nationale supérieure des mines de Paris">École nationale supérieure des mines de Paris</a> that produce high-profile engineers, or the <a href="/wiki/%C3%89cole_nationale_d%27administration" title="École nationale d'administration">École nationale d'administration</a> for careers in the <a href="/wiki/Grands_corps_de_l%27%C3%89tat" title="Grands corps de l'État">Grands Corps</a> of the state. The <i>Grandes écoles</i> have been criticised for alleged <a href="/wiki/Elitism" title="Elitism">elitism</a>, producing many if not most of France's high-ranking civil servants, CEOs and politicians.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-gécoles_364-0"><a href="#cite_note-gécoles-364">[350]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Culture">Culture</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_France" title="Culture of France">Culture of France</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:252px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Eug%C3%A8ne_Delacroix_-_La_libert%C3%A9_guidant_le_peuple.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2480" data-file-width="3133" decoding="async" height="198" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/Eug%C3%A8ne_Delacroix_-_La_libert%C3%A9_guidant_le_peuple.jpg/250px-Eug%C3%A8ne_Delacroix_-_La_libert%C3%A9_guidant_le_peuple.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/Eug%C3%A8ne_Delacroix_-_La_libert%C3%A9_guidant_le_peuple.jpg/375px-Eug%C3%A8ne_Delacroix_-_La_libert%C3%A9_guidant_le_peuple.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/Eug%C3%A8ne_Delacroix_-_La_libert%C3%A9_guidant_le_peuple.jpg/500px-Eug%C3%A8ne_Delacroix_-_La_libert%C3%A9_guidant_le_peuple.jpg 2x" width="250"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Eug%C3%A8ne_Delacroix_-_La_libert%C3%A9_guidant_le_peuple.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Eug%C3%A8ne_Delacroix" title="Eugène Delacroix">Eugène Delacroix</a>'s <i><a href="/wiki/Liberty_Leading_the_People" title="Liberty Leading the People">Liberty Leading the People</a></i> (1830) portrays the <a href="/wiki/July_Revolution" title="July Revolution">July Revolution</a> using the stylistic views of <a href="/wiki/Romanticism" title="Romanticism">Romanticism</a>. Since Liberty is part of the motto "<a href="/wiki/Libert%C3%A9,_%C3%A9galit%C3%A9,_fraternit%C3%A9" title="Liberté, égalité, fraternité">Liberté, égalité, fraternité</a>", as the French put it, this painting has become the primary symbol of the French Republic.</div></div></div>
<p>France has been a centre of Western cultural development for centuries. Many French artists have been among the most renowned of their time; France is still recognised in the world for its rich cultural tradition.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-365"><a href="#cite_note-365">[351]</a></sup>
</p><p>The successive political regimes have always promoted artistic creation. The creation of the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Culture_(France)" title="Ministry of Culture (France)">Ministry of Culture</a> in 1959 helped preserve the cultural heritage of the country and make it available to the public. The Ministry of Culture has been very active since its creation, granting subsidies to artists, promoting French culture in the world, supporting festivals and cultural events, protecting <a href="/wiki/Monument_historique" title="Monument historique">historical monuments</a>. The French government also succeeded in maintaining a <a href="/wiki/Cultural_exception" title="Cultural exception">cultural exception</a> to defend audiovisual products made in the country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-366"><a href="#cite_note-366">[352]</a></sup>
</p><p>France receives the highest number of tourists per year, largely thanks to the numerous cultural establishments and historical buildings implanted all over the territory. It counts 1,200 <a href="/wiki/List_of_museums_in_France" title="List of museums in France">museums</a> welcoming more than 50 million people annually.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-367"><a href="#cite_note-367">[353]</a></sup> The most important cultural sites are run by the government, for instance through the public agency <a href="/wiki/Centre_des_monuments_nationaux" title="Centre des monuments nationaux">Centre des monuments nationaux</a>, which is responsible for approximately 85 national historical monuments. The 43,180 buildings protected as historical monuments include mainly residences (many <a href="/wiki/List_of_castles_in_France" title="List of castles in France">castles</a>) and religious buildings (<a href="/wiki/List_of_cathedrals_in_France" title="List of cathedrals in France">cathedrals</a>, <a href="/wiki/List_of_basilicas_in_France" title="List of basilicas in France">basilicas</a>, <a href="/wiki/Church_(building)" title="Church (building)">churches</a>), but also statues, memorials and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gardens_of_France" title="Gardens of France">gardens</a>. The <a href="/wiki/UNESCO" title="UNESCO">UNESCO</a> inscribed 45 sites in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Table_of_World_Heritage_Sites_by_country" title="Table of World Heritage Sites by country">France on the World Heritage List</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-368"><a href="#cite_note-368">[354]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Art">Art</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/French_art" title="French art">French art</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Louvre_Museum_Wikimedia_Commons.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2832" data-file-width="6740" decoding="async" height="126" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/66/Louvre_Museum_Wikimedia_Commons.jpg/300px-Louvre_Museum_Wikimedia_Commons.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/66/Louvre_Museum_Wikimedia_Commons.jpg/450px-Louvre_Museum_Wikimedia_Commons.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/66/Louvre_Museum_Wikimedia_Commons.jpg/600px-Louvre_Museum_Wikimedia_Commons.jpg 2x" width="300"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Louvre_Museum_Wikimedia_Commons.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Louvre" title="Louvre">Louvre Museum</a>, widely recognised as one of the finest <a href="/wiki/Art_museum" title="Art museum">art museums</a> in the world, was in 2019 both <a href="/wiki/List_of_largest_art_museums" title="List of largest art museums">the largest</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_most-visited_museums" title="List of most-visited museums">the most-visited museum</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ArtNewspaper2019_369-0"><a href="#cite_note-ArtNewspaper2019-369">[355]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>The origins of French art were very much influenced by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Flemish_art" title="Flemish art">Flemish art</a> and by <a href="/wiki/Italian_art" title="Italian art">Italian art</a> at the time of the <a href="/wiki/Renaissance" title="Renaissance">Renaissance</a>. <a href="/wiki/Jean_Fouquet" title="Jean Fouquet">Jean Fouquet</a>, the most famous medieval French painter, is said to have been the first to travel to Italy and experience the Early Renaissance firsthand. The Renaissance painting <a href="/wiki/School_of_Fontainebleau" title="School of Fontainebleau">School of Fontainebleau</a> was directly inspired by Italian painters such as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Primaticcio" title="Primaticcio">Primaticcio</a> and <a href="/wiki/Rosso_Fiorentino" title="Rosso Fiorentino">Rosso Fiorentino</a>, who both worked in France. Two of the most famous French artists of the time of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Baroque_era" title="Baroque era">Baroque era</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nicolas_Poussin" title="Nicolas Poussin">Nicolas Poussin</a> and <a href="/wiki/Claude_Lorrain" title="Claude Lorrain">Claude Lorrain</a>, lived in Italy.
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:152px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Claude_Monet_1899_Nadar_crop.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2694" data-file-width="2021" decoding="async" height="200" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/Claude_Monet_1899_Nadar_crop.jpg/150px-Claude_Monet_1899_Nadar_crop.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/Claude_Monet_1899_Nadar_crop.jpg/225px-Claude_Monet_1899_Nadar_crop.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/Claude_Monet_1899_Nadar_crop.jpg/300px-Claude_Monet_1899_Nadar_crop.jpg 2x" width="150"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Claude_Monet_1899_Nadar_crop.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Claude_Monet" title="Claude Monet">Claude Monet</a>, founder of the <a href="/wiki/Impressionism" title="Impressionism">Impressionist</a> movement</div></div></div>
<p>The 17th century was the period when French painting became prominent and individualised itself through classicism. Prime Minister <a href="/wiki/Jean-Baptiste_Colbert" title="Jean-Baptiste Colbert">Jean-Baptiste Colbert</a> founded in 1648 the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Royal_Academy_of_Painting_and_Sculpture" title="Royal Academy of Painting and Sculpture">Royal Academy of Painting and Sculpture</a> under Louis XIV to protect these artists; in 1666 he also created the still-active <a href="/wiki/French_Academy_in_Rome" title="French Academy in Rome">French Academy in Rome</a> to have direct relations with Italian artists.
</p><p>French artists developed the <a href="/wiki/Rococo" title="Rococo">rococo</a> style in the 18th century, as a more intimate imitation of old baroque style, the works of the court-endorsed artists <a href="/wiki/Antoine_Watteau" title="Antoine Watteau">Antoine Watteau</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fran%C3%A7ois_Boucher" title="François Boucher">François Boucher</a> and <a href="/wiki/Jean-Honor%C3%A9_Fragonard" title="Jean-Honoré Fragonard">Jean-Honoré Fragonard</a> being the most representative in the country. The French Revolution brought great changes, as <a href="/wiki/Napoleon" title="Napoleon">Napoleon</a> favoured artists of <a href="/wiki/Neoclassicism" title="Neoclassicism">neoclassic style</a> such as <a href="/wiki/Jacques-Louis_David" title="Jacques-Louis David">Jacques-Louis David</a> and the highly influential <a href="/wiki/Acad%C3%A9mie_des_Beaux-Arts" title="Académie des Beaux-Arts">Académie des Beaux-Arts</a> defined the style known as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Academism" title="Academism">Academism</a>. At this time France had become a centre of artistic creation, the first half of the 19th century being dominated by two successive movements, at first <a href="/wiki/Romanticism" title="Romanticism">Romanticism</a> with <a href="/wiki/Th%C3%A9odore_G%C3%A9ricault" title="Théodore Géricault">Théodore Géricault</a> and <a href="/wiki/Eug%C3%A8ne_Delacroix" title="Eugène Delacroix">Eugène Delacroix</a>, then <a href="/wiki/Realism_(arts)" title="Realism (arts)">Realism</a> with <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Camille_Corot" title="Camille Corot">Camille Corot</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gustave_Courbet" title="Gustave Courbet">Gustave Courbet</a> and <a href="/wiki/Jean-Fran%C3%A7ois_Millet" title="Jean-François Millet">Jean-François Millet</a>, a style that eventually evolved into <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Naturalism_(arts)" title="Naturalism (arts)">Naturalism</a>.
</p><p>In the second part of the 19th century, France's influence over painting became even more important, with the development of new styles of painting such as <a href="/wiki/Impressionism" title="Impressionism">Impressionism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Symbolism_(arts)" title="Symbolism (arts)">Symbolism</a>. The most famous impressionist painters of the period were <a href="/wiki/Camille_Pissarro" title="Camille Pissarro">Camille Pissarro</a>, <a href="/wiki/%C3%89douard_Manet" title="Édouard Manet">Édouard Manet</a>, <a href="/wiki/Edgar_Degas" title="Edgar Degas">Edgar Degas</a>, <a href="/wiki/Claude_Monet" title="Claude Monet">Claude Monet</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Auguste_Renoir" title="Auguste Renoir">Auguste Renoir</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-370"><a href="#cite_note-370">[356]</a></sup> The second generation of impressionist-style painters, <a href="/wiki/Paul_C%C3%A9zanne" title="Paul Cézanne">Paul Cézanne</a>, <a href="/wiki/Paul_Gauguin" title="Paul Gauguin">Paul Gauguin</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Toulouse-Lautrec" title="Toulouse-Lautrec">Toulouse-Lautrec</a> and <a href="/wiki/Georges_Seurat" title="Georges Seurat">Georges Seurat</a>, were also at the avant-garde of artistic evolutions,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-371"><a href="#cite_note-371">[357]</a></sup> as well as the <a href="/wiki/Fauvism" title="Fauvism">fauvist</a> artists <a href="/wiki/Henri_Matisse" title="Henri Matisse">Henri Matisse</a>, <a href="/wiki/Andr%C3%A9_Derain" title="André Derain">André Derain</a> and <a href="/wiki/Maurice_de_Vlaminck" title="Maurice de Vlaminck">Maurice de Vlaminck</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-372"><a href="#cite_note-372">[358]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-373"><a href="#cite_note-373">[359]</a></sup>
</p><p>At the beginning of the 20th century, Cubism was developed by <a href="/wiki/Georges_Braque" title="Georges Braque">Georges Braque</a> and the Spanish painter <a href="/wiki/Pablo_Picasso" title="Pablo Picasso">Pablo Picasso</a>, living in Paris. Other foreign artists also settled and worked in or near Paris, such as <a href="/wiki/Vincent_van_Gogh" title="Vincent van Gogh">Vincent van Gogh</a>, <a href="/wiki/Marc_Chagall" title="Marc Chagall">Marc Chagall</a>, <a href="/wiki/Amedeo_Modigliani" title="Amedeo Modigliani">Amedeo Modigliani</a> and <a href="/wiki/Wassily_Kandinsky" title="Wassily Kandinsky">Wassily Kandinsky</a>.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Mus%C3%A9e_Rodin_1.jpg"><img alt="The Thinker bronze statue from 1902 from the Musée Rodin, Paris" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="5472" data-file-width="3648" decoding="async" height="270" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a5/Mus%C3%A9e_Rodin_1.jpg/180px-Mus%C3%A9e_Rodin_1.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a5/Mus%C3%A9e_Rodin_1.jpg/270px-Mus%C3%A9e_Rodin_1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a5/Mus%C3%A9e_Rodin_1.jpg/360px-Mus%C3%A9e_Rodin_1.jpg 2x" width="180"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Mus%C3%A9e_Rodin_1.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><i><a href="/wiki/The_Thinker" title="The Thinker">Le Penseur</a></i> by <a href="/wiki/Auguste_Rodin" title="Auguste Rodin">Auguste Rodin</a> (1902), <a href="/wiki/Mus%C3%A9e_Rodin" title="Musée Rodin">Musée Rodin</a>, Paris</div></div></div>
<p>Many museums in France are entirely or partly devoted to sculptures and painting works. A huge collection of old masterpieces created before or during the 18th century are displayed in the state-owned <a href="/wiki/Louvre" title="Louvre">Musée du Louvre</a>, such as the <i><a href="/wiki/Mona_Lisa" title="Mona Lisa">Mona Lisa</a></i>, also known as "La Joconde". While the <a href="/wiki/Louvre_Palace" title="Louvre Palace">Louvre Palace</a> has been for a long time a museum, the <a href="/wiki/Mus%C3%A9e_d%27Orsay" title="Musée d'Orsay">Musée d'Orsay</a> was inaugurated in 1986 in the old railway station <a href="/wiki/Gare_d%27Orsay" title="Gare d'Orsay">Gare d'Orsay</a>, in a major reorganisation of national art collections, to gather French paintings from the second part of the 19th century (mainly Impressionism and Fauvism movements).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-374"><a href="#cite_note-374">[360]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-375"><a href="#cite_note-375">[361]</a></sup> The Musée d'Orsay was voted in 2018 the best museum in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-376"><a href="#cite_note-376">[362]</a></sup>
</p><p>Modern works are presented in the <a href="/wiki/Mus%C3%A9e_National_d%27Art_Moderne" title="Musée National d'Art Moderne">Musée National d'Art Moderne</a>, which moved in 1976 to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Centre_Georges_Pompidou" title="Centre Georges Pompidou">Centre Georges Pompidou</a>. These three state-owned museums welcome close to 17 million people a year.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sites_377-0"><a href="#cite_note-sites-377">[363]</a></sup> Other national museums hosting paintings include the <a href="/wiki/Grand_Palais" title="Grand Palais">Grand Palais</a> (1.3 million visitors in 2008), but there are also many museums owned by cities, the most visited being the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mus%C3%A9e_d%27Art_Moderne_de_la_Ville_de_Paris" title="Musée d'Art Moderne de la Ville de Paris">Musée d'Art Moderne de la Ville de Paris</a> (0.8 million entries in 2008), which hosts contemporary works.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sites_377-1"><a href="#cite_note-sites-377">[363]</a></sup> Outside Paris, all the large cities have a Museum of Fine Arts with a section dedicated to European and French painting. Some of the finest collections are in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mus%C3%A9e_des_Beaux-Arts_de_Lyon" title="Musée des Beaux-Arts de Lyon">Lyon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Palais_des_Beaux-Arts_de_Lille" title="Palais des Beaux-Arts de Lille">Lille</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mus%C3%A9e_des_Beaux-Arts_de_Rouen" title="Musée des Beaux-Arts de Rouen">Rouen</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mus%C3%A9e_des_Beaux-Arts_de_Dijon" title="Musée des Beaux-Arts de Dijon">Dijon</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mus%C3%A9e_des_Beaux-Arts_de_Rennes" title="Musée des Beaux-Arts de Rennes">Rennes</a> and <a href="/wiki/Museum_of_Grenoble" title="Museum of Grenoble">Grenoble</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Architecture">Architecture</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/French_architecture" title="French architecture">French architecture</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Sainte_Chapelle_-_Upper_level_1.jpg"><img alt="Sainte Chapelle interior showing painted stonework vaulting and stained glass" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1961" data-file-width="989" decoding="async" height="357" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/Sainte_Chapelle_-_Upper_level_1.jpg/180px-Sainte_Chapelle_-_Upper_level_1.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/Sainte_Chapelle_-_Upper_level_1.jpg/270px-Sainte_Chapelle_-_Upper_level_1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/Sainte_Chapelle_-_Upper_level_1.jpg/360px-Sainte_Chapelle_-_Upper_level_1.jpg 2x" width="180"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Sainte_Chapelle_-_Upper_level_1.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Louis_IX_of_France" title="Louis IX of France">Saint Louis</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Sainte-Chapelle" title="Sainte-Chapelle">Sainte-Chapelle</a> represents the French impact on religious architecture.</div></div></div>
<p>During the Middle Ages, many fortified castles were built by feudal nobles to mark their powers. Some French castles that survived are <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chinon_(castle)" title="Chinon (castle)">Chinon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ch%C3%A2teau_d%27Angers" title="Château d'Angers">Château d'Angers</a>, the massive <a href="/wiki/Ch%C3%A2teau_de_Vincennes" title="Château de Vincennes">Château de Vincennes</a> and the so-called <a href="/wiki/Cathar_castles" title="Cathar castles">Cathar castles</a>. During this era, France had been using <a href="/wiki/Romanesque_architecture" title="Romanesque architecture">Romanesque architecture</a> like most of Western Europe. Some of the greatest examples of Romanesque churches in France are the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Basilique_de_Saint-Sernin,_Toulouse" title="Basilique de Saint-Sernin, Toulouse">Saint Sernin Basilica</a> in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Toulouse,_France" title="Toulouse, France">Toulouse</a>, the largest Romanesque church in Europe,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-378"><a href="#cite_note-378">[364]</a></sup> and the remains of the <a href="/wiki/Cluny_Abbey" title="Cluny Abbey">Cluny Abbey</a>.
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Gothic_architecture" title="Gothic architecture">Gothic architecture</a>, originally named <i>Opus Francigenum</i> meaning "French work",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-379"><a href="#cite_note-379">[365]</a></sup> was born in <a href="/wiki/%C3%8Ele-de-France" title="Île-de-France">Île-de-France</a> and was the first French style of architecture to be copied in all Europe.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-380"><a href="#cite_note-380">[366]</a></sup> Northern France is the home of some of the most important Gothic cathedrals and basilicas, the first of these being the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Saint_Denis_Basilica" title="Saint Denis Basilica">Saint Denis Basilica</a> (used as the royal necropolis); other important French Gothic cathedrals are <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cathedral_of_Chartres" title="Cathedral of Chartres">Notre-Dame de Chartres</a> and <a href="/wiki/Amiens_Cathedral" title="Amiens Cathedral">Notre-Dame d'Amiens</a>. The kings were crowned in another important Gothic church: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Notre-Dame_de_Reims" title="Notre-Dame de Reims">Notre-Dame de Reims</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-381"><a href="#cite_note-381">[367]</a></sup> Aside from churches, Gothic Architecture had been used for many religious palaces, the most important one being the <a href="/wiki/Palais_des_Papes" title="Palais des Papes">Palais des Papes</a> in <a href="/wiki/Avignon" title="Avignon">Avignon</a>.
</p><p>The final victory in the Hundred Years' War marked an important stage in the evolution of French architecture. It was the time of the <a href="/wiki/French_Renaissance" title="French Renaissance">French Renaissance</a> and several artists from Italy were invited to the French court; many residential palaces were built in the <a href="/wiki/Loire_Valley" title="Loire Valley">Loire Valley</a>, from 1450 with as a first reference the <a href="/wiki/Ch%C3%A2teau_de_Montsoreau" title="Château de Montsoreau">Château de Montsoreau</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-382"><a href="#cite_note-382">[368]</a></sup> Such residential castles were the <a href="/wiki/Ch%C3%A2teau_de_Chambord" title="Château de Chambord">Château de Chambord</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Ch%C3%A2teau_de_Chenonceau" title="Château de Chenonceau">Château de Chenonceau</a>, or the <a href="/wiki/Ch%C3%A2teau_d%27Amboise" title="Château d'Amboise">Château d'Amboise</a>.
</p><p>Following the renaissance and the end of the Middle Ages, <a href="/wiki/French_Baroque_architecture" title="French Baroque architecture">Baroque architecture</a> replaced the traditional Gothic style. However, in France, baroque architecture found a greater success in the secular domain than in a religious one.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-383"><a href="#cite_note-383">[369]</a></sup> In the secular domain, the <a href="/wiki/Palace_of_Versailles" title="Palace of Versailles">Palace of Versailles</a> has many baroque features. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jules_Hardouin_Mansart" title="Jules Hardouin Mansart">Jules Hardouin Mansart</a>, who designed the extensions to Versailles, was one of the most influential French architects of the baroque era; he is famous for his dome at <a href="/wiki/Les_Invalides" title="Les Invalides">Les Invalides</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-384"><a href="#cite_note-384">[370]</a></sup> Some of the most impressive provincial baroque architecture is found in places that were not yet French such as <a href="/wiki/Place_Stanislas" title="Place Stanislas">Place Stanislas</a> in <a href="/wiki/Nancy,_France" title="Nancy, France">Nancy</a>. On the military architectural side, <a href="/wiki/S%C3%A9bastien_Le_Prestre_de_Vauban" title="Sébastien Le Prestre de Vauban">Vauban</a> designed some of the most efficient fortresses in Europe and became an influential military architect; as a result, imitations of his works can be found all over Europe, the Americas, Russia and Turkey.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-385"><a href="#cite_note-385">[371]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-386"><a href="#cite_note-386">[372]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Bordeaux_place_de_la_bourse_with_tram.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2276" data-file-width="3401" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/64/Bordeaux_place_de_la_bourse_with_tram.JPG/220px-Bordeaux_place_de_la_bourse_with_tram.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/64/Bordeaux_place_de_la_bourse_with_tram.JPG/330px-Bordeaux_place_de_la_bourse_with_tram.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/64/Bordeaux_place_de_la_bourse_with_tram.JPG/440px-Bordeaux_place_de_la_bourse_with_tram.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Bordeaux_place_de_la_bourse_with_tram.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Place_de_la_Bourse" title="Place de la Bourse">Place de la Bourse</a> in <a href="/wiki/Bordeaux" title="Bordeaux">Bordeaux</a>, an example of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/French_baroque_architecture" title="French baroque architecture">French baroque architecture</a></div></div></div>
<p>After the Revolution, the <a href="/wiki/Republicanism" title="Republicanism">Republicans</a> favoured <a href="/wiki/Neoclassicism" title="Neoclassicism">Neoclassicism</a> although it was introduced in France prior to the revolution with such buildings as the <a href="/wiki/Panth%C3%A9on" title="Panthéon">Parisian Pantheon</a> or the <a href="/wiki/Capitole_de_Toulouse" title="Capitole de Toulouse">Capitole de Toulouse</a>. Built during the first French Empire, the <a href="/wiki/Arc_de_Triomphe" title="Arc de Triomphe">Arc de Triomphe</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/%C3%89glise_de_la_Madeleine" title="Église de la Madeleine">Sainte Marie-Madeleine</a> represent the best example of <a href="/wiki/Empire_style" title="Empire style">Empire style</a> architecture.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-387"><a href="#cite_note-387">[373]</a></sup>
</p><p>Under <a href="/wiki/Napoleon_III" title="Napoleon III">Napoleon III</a>, a new wave of urbanism and architecture was given birth; extravagant buildings such as the neo-baroque <a href="/wiki/Palais_Garnier" title="Palais Garnier">Palais Garnier</a> were built. The urban planning of the time was very organised and rigorous; most notably, <a href="/wiki/Haussmann%27s_renovation_of_Paris" title="Haussmann's renovation of Paris">Haussmann's renovation of Paris</a>. The architecture associated with this era is named <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Second_Empire_(architecture)" title="Second Empire (architecture)">Second Empire</a> in English, the term being taken from the <a href="/wiki/Second_French_Empire" title="Second French Empire">Second French Empire</a>. At this time there was a strong Gothic resurgence across Europe and in France; the associated architect was <a href="/wiki/Eug%C3%A8ne_Viollet-le-Duc" title="Eugène Viollet-le-Duc">Eugène Viollet-le-Duc</a>. In the late 19th century, <a href="/wiki/Gustave_Eiffel" title="Gustave Eiffel">Gustave Eiffel</a> designed many bridges, such as <a href="/wiki/Garabit_viaduct" title="Garabit viaduct">Garabit viaduct</a>, and remains one of the most influential bridge designers of his time, although he is best remembered for the iconic <a href="/wiki/Eiffel_Tower" title="Eiffel Tower">Eiffel Tower</a>.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Toulouse_Homebanner_Capitole_Night.jpg"><img alt="The City hall of Toulouse" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1692" data-file-width="5067" decoding="async" height="73" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/94/Toulouse_Homebanner_Capitole_Night.jpg/220px-Toulouse_Homebanner_Capitole_Night.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/94/Toulouse_Homebanner_Capitole_Night.jpg/330px-Toulouse_Homebanner_Capitole_Night.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/94/Toulouse_Homebanner_Capitole_Night.jpg/440px-Toulouse_Homebanner_Capitole_Night.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Toulouse_Homebanner_Capitole_Night.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Capitole_de_Toulouse" title="Capitole de Toulouse">Capitole de Toulouse</a> hosts Toulouse City Hall.</div></div></div>
<p>In the 20th century, French-Swiss architect <a href="/wiki/Le_Corbusier" title="Le Corbusier">Le Corbusier</a> designed several buildings in France. More recently, French architects have combined both modern and old architectural styles. The <a href="/wiki/Louvre_Pyramid" title="Louvre Pyramid">Louvre Pyramid</a> is an example of modern architecture added to an older building. The most difficult buildings to integrate within French cities are skyscrapers, as they are visible from afar. For instance, in Paris, since 1977, new buildings had to be under 37 metres (121 ft).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-388"><a href="#cite_note-388">[374]</a></sup> France's largest financial district is <a href="/wiki/La_D%C3%A9fense" title="La Défense">La Défense</a>, where a significant number of skyscrapers are located.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-389"><a href="#cite_note-389">[375]</a></sup> Other massive buildings that are a challenge to integrate into their environment are large bridges; an example of the way this has been done is the <a href="/wiki/Millau_Viaduct" title="Millau Viaduct">Millau Viaduct</a>. Some famous modern French architects include <a href="/wiki/Jean_Nouvel" title="Jean Nouvel">Jean Nouvel</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dominique_Perrault" title="Dominique Perrault">Dominique Perrault</a>, <a href="/wiki/Christian_de_Portzamparc" title="Christian de Portzamparc">Christian de Portzamparc</a> or <a href="/wiki/Paul_Andreu" title="Paul Andreu">Paul Andreu</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Literature">Literature</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/French_literature" title="French literature">French literature</a></div>
<p>The earliest French literature dates from the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Middle_Age" title="Middle Age">Middle Ages</a>, when what is now known as modern France did not have a single, uniform language. There were several languages and dialects, and writers used their own spelling and grammar. Some authors of French medieval texts are unknown, such as <i><a href="/wiki/Tristan_and_Iseult" title="Tristan and Iseult">Tristan and Iseult</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Lancelot-Grail" title="Lancelot-Grail">Lancelot-Grail</a></i>. Other authors are known, for example <a href="/wiki/Chr%C3%A9tien_de_Troyes" title="Chrétien de Troyes">Chrétien de Troyes</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/William_IX_of_Aquitaine" title="William IX of Aquitaine">Duke William IX of Aquitaine</a>, who wrote in <a href="/wiki/Occitan_language" title="Occitan language">Occitan</a>.
</p><p>Much medieval French poetry and literature were inspired by the legends of the <a href="/wiki/Matter_of_France" title="Matter of France">Matter of France</a>, such as <i><a href="/wiki/The_Song_of_Roland" title="The Song of Roland">The Song of Roland</a></i> and the various <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chansons_de_geste" title="Chansons de geste">chansons de geste</a>. The <i>Roman de Renart</i>, written in 1175 by Perrout de Saint Cloude, tells the story of the medieval character <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Reynard" title="Reynard">Reynard</a> ('the Fox') and is another example of early French writing. An important 16th-century writer was <a href="/wiki/Fran%C3%A7ois_Rabelais" title="François Rabelais">François Rabelais</a>, whose novel <i><a href="/wiki/Gargantua_and_Pantagruel" title="Gargantua and Pantagruel">Gargantua and Pantagruel</a></i> has remained famous and appreciated until now. <a href="/wiki/Michel_de_Montaigne" title="Michel de Montaigne">Michel de Montaigne</a> was another major figure of French literature during that century. His most famous work, <i><a href="/wiki/Essays_(Montaigne)" title="Essays (Montaigne)">Essais</a></i>, created the literary genre of the essay.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-390"><a href="#cite_note-390">[376]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/French_poetry" title="French poetry">French poetry</a> during that century was embodied by <a href="/wiki/Pierre_de_Ronsard" title="Pierre de Ronsard">Pierre de Ronsard</a> and <a href="/wiki/Joachim_du_Bellay" title="Joachim du Bellay">Joachim du Bellay</a>. Both writers founded the <a href="/wiki/La_Pl%C3%A9iade" title="La Pléiade">La Pléiade</a> literary movement.
</p><p>In 1678, <a href="/wiki/Madame_de_La_Fayette" title="Madame de La Fayette">Madame de La Fayette</a> published anonymously <i><a href="/wiki/La_Princesse_de_Cl%C3%A8ves" title="La Princesse de Clèves">La Princesse de Clèves</a></i>, a novel that is considered to be one of the first <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Psychological_novel" title="Psychological novel">psychological novels</a> of all time.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-391"><a href="#cite_note-391">[377]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Jean_de_La_Fontaine" title="Jean de La Fontaine">Jean de La Fontaine</a> is one of the most famous <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fabulist" title="Fabulist">fabulists</a> of that time, as he wrote hundreds of fables, some being far more famous than others, such as <i><a href="/wiki/The_Ant_and_the_Grasshopper" title="The Ant and the Grasshopper">The Ant and the Grasshopper</a></i>. Generations of French pupils had to learn his fables, which were seen as helping teach <a href="/wiki/Wisdom" title="Wisdom">wisdom</a> and <a href="/wiki/Common_sense" title="Common sense">common sense</a> to the young people. Some of his verses have entered the popular language to become proverbs, such as "<i>À l'œuvre, on connaît l'artisan."[A workman is known by his chips].</i><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-392"><a href="#cite_note-392">[378]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:French_literary_figures.jpg"><img alt="see description" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1476" data-file-width="1181" decoding="async" height="275" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/f/f1/French_literary_figures.jpg/220px-French_literary_figures.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/f/f1/French_literary_figures.jpg/330px-French_literary_figures.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/f/f1/French_literary_figures.jpg/440px-French_literary_figures.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:French_literary_figures.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>French literary figures. Clockwise from top left: <a href="/wiki/Moli%C3%A8re" title="Molière">Molière</a> is the most played author in the <a href="/wiki/Com%C3%A9die-Fran%C3%A7aise" title="Comédie-Française">Comédie-Française</a>;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-393"><a href="#cite_note-393">[379]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Victor_Hugo" title="Victor Hugo">Victor Hugo</a> is one of the most important French novelist and poet; 19th-century poet, writer and translator <a href="/wiki/Charles_Baudelaire" title="Charles Baudelaire">Charles Baudelaire</a>; 20th-century philosopher and novelist <a href="/wiki/Jean-Paul_Sartre" title="Jean-Paul Sartre">Jean-Paul Sartre</a></div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Jean_Racine" title="Jean Racine">Jean Racine</a>, whose incredible mastery of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/French_Alexandrine" title="French Alexandrine">alexandrine</a> and of the French language has been praised for centuries, created plays such as <i><a href="/wiki/Ph%C3%A8dre" title="Phèdre">Phèdre</a></i> or <i><a href="/wiki/Britannicus" title="Britannicus">Britannicus</a></i>. He is, along with <a href="/wiki/Pierre_Corneille" title="Pierre Corneille">Pierre Corneille</a> (<i><a href="/wiki/Le_Cid" title="Le Cid">Le Cid</a></i>) and <a href="/wiki/Moli%C3%A8re" title="Molière">Molière</a>, considered one of the three great dramatists of France's golden age. Molière, who is deemed to be one of the greatest masters of comedy of the <a href="/wiki/Western_literature" title="Western literature">Western literature</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-394"><a href="#cite_note-394">[380]</a></sup> wrote dozens of plays, including <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Le_Misanthrope" title="Le Misanthrope">Le Misanthrope</a></i>, <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/L%27Avare" title="L'Avare">L'Avare</a></i>, <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Le_Malade_imaginaire" title="Le Malade imaginaire">Le Malade imaginaire</a></i>, as well as <i><a href="/wiki/Le_Bourgeois_gentilhomme" title="Le Bourgeois gentilhomme">Le Bourgeois gentilhomme</a></i>. His plays have been so popular around the world that the French language is sometimes dubbed as "the language of Molière" (<i>la langue de Molière</i>),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-395"><a href="#cite_note-395">[381]</a></sup> just like English is considered "the language of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Shakespeare" title="Shakespeare">Shakespeare</a>".
</p><p>French literature and poetry flourished even more in the 18th and 19th centuries. <a href="/wiki/Denis_Diderot" title="Denis Diderot">Denis Diderot</a>'s best-known works are <i><a href="/wiki/Jacques_the_Fatalist" title="Jacques the Fatalist">Jacques the Fatalist</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Rameau%27s_Nephew" title="Rameau's Nephew">Rameau's Nephew</a></i>. He is however best known for being the main redactor of the <i><a href="/wiki/Encyclop%C3%A9die" title="Encyclopédie">Encyclopédie</a></i>, whose aim was to sum up all the knowledge of his century (in fields such as arts, sciences, languages, and philosophy) and to present them to the people, to fight ignorance and <a href="/wiki/Obscurantism" title="Obscurantism">obscurantism</a>. During that same century, <a href="/wiki/Charles_Perrault" title="Charles Perrault">Charles Perrault</a> was a prolific writer of famous children's fairy tales including <i><a href="/wiki/Puss_in_Boots" title="Puss in Boots">Puss in Boots</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Cinderella" title="Cinderella">Cinderella</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Sleeping_Beauty" title="Sleeping Beauty">Sleeping Beauty</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Bluebeard" title="Bluebeard">Bluebeard</a></i>. At the start of the 19th century, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Symbolist_poetry" title="Symbolist poetry">symbolist poetry</a> was an important movement in French literature, with poets such as Charles Baudelaire, <a href="/wiki/Paul_Verlaine" title="Paul Verlaine">Paul Verlaine</a> and <a href="/wiki/St%C3%A9phane_Mallarm%C3%A9" title="Stéphane Mallarmé">Stéphane Mallarmé</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-396"><a href="#cite_note-396">[382]</a></sup>
</p><p>The 19th century saw the writings of many renowned French authors. Victor Hugo is sometimes seen as "the greatest French writer of all time"<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-victor_397-0"><a href="#cite_note-victor-397">[383]</a></sup> for excelling in all <a href="/wiki/Literary_genre" title="Literary genre">literary genres</a>. The preface of his play <i><a href="/wiki/Cromwell_(play)" title="Cromwell (play)">Cromwell</a></i> is considered to be the manifesto of the <a href="/wiki/Romanticism" title="Romanticism">Romantic movement</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/Les_Contemplations" title="Les Contemplations">Les Contemplations</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/La_L%C3%A9gende_des_si%C3%A8cles" title="La Légende des siècles">La Légende des siècles</a></i> are considered "poetic masterpieces",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hugo_398-0"><a href="#cite_note-hugo-398">[384]</a></sup> Hugo's verse having been compared to that of Shakespeare, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dante" title="Dante">Dante</a> and <a href="/wiki/Homer" title="Homer">Homer</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hugo_398-1"><a href="#cite_note-hugo-398">[384]</a></sup> His novel <i><a href="/wiki/Les_Mis%C3%A9rables" title="Les Misérables">Les Misérables</a></i> is widely seen as one of the greatest novel ever written<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-399"><a href="#cite_note-399">[385]</a></sup> and <i><a href="/wiki/The_Hunchback_of_Notre-Dame" title="The Hunchback of Notre-Dame">The Hunchback of Notre Dame</a></i> has remained immensely popular.
