Other major authors of that century include <a href="/wiki/Alexandre_Dumas" title="Alexandre Dumas">Alexandre Dumas</a> (<i><a href="/wiki/The_Three_Musketeers" title="The Three Musketeers">The Three Musketeers</a></i> and <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/The_Count_of_Monte-Cristo" title="The Count of Monte-Cristo">The Count of Monte-Cristo</a></i>), <a href="/wiki/Jules_Verne" title="Jules Verne">Jules Verne</a> (<i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Twenty_Thousand_Leagues_Under_the_Sea" title="Twenty Thousand Leagues Under the Sea">Twenty Thousand Leagues Under the Sea</a></i>), <a href="/wiki/%C3%89mile_Zola" title="Émile Zola">Émile Zola</a> (<i><a href="/wiki/Les_Rougon-Macquart" title="Les Rougon-Macquart">Les Rougon-Macquart</a></i>), <a href="/wiki/Honor%C3%A9_de_Balzac" title="Honoré de Balzac">Honoré de Balzac</a> (<i><a href="/wiki/La_Com%C3%A9die_humaine" title="La Comédie humaine">La Comédie humaine</a></i>), <a href="/wiki/Guy_de_Maupassant" title="Guy de Maupassant">Guy de Maupassant</a>, <a href="/wiki/Th%C3%A9ophile_Gautier" title="Théophile Gautier">Théophile Gautier</a> and <a href="/wiki/Stendhal" title="Stendhal">Stendhal</a> (<i><a href="/wiki/The_Red_and_the_Black" title="The Red and the Black">The Red and the Black</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Charterhouse_of_Parma" title="The Charterhouse of Parma">The Charterhouse of Parma</a></i>), whose works are among the most well known in France and the world. The <a href="/wiki/Prix_Goncourt" title="Prix Goncourt">Prix Goncourt</a> is a French literary prize first awarded in 1903.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-400"><a href="#cite_note-400">[386]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the early 20th century France was a haven for literary freedom.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Beat_censors_401-0"><a href="#cite_note-Beat_censors-401">[387]</a></sup> Works banned for obscenity in the US, the UK and other Anglophone nations were published in France decades before they were available in the respective authors' home countries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Beat_censors_401-1"><a href="#cite_note-Beat_censors-401">[387]</a></sup> The innate French regard for the mind meant that France was disinclined to punish literary figures for their writing, and prosecutions were rare.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Beat_censors_401-2"><a href="#cite_note-Beat_censors-401">[387]</a></sup> Important writers of the 20th century include <a href="/wiki/Marcel_Proust" title="Marcel Proust">Marcel Proust</a>, <a href="/wiki/Louis-Ferdinand_C%C3%A9line" title="Louis-Ferdinand Céline">Louis-Ferdinand Céline</a>, <a href="/wiki/Albert_Camus" title="Albert Camus">Albert Camus</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Jean-Paul_Sartre" title="Jean-Paul Sartre">Jean-Paul Sartre</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Antoine_de_Saint_Exup%C3%A9ry" title="Antoine de Saint Exupéry">Antoine de Saint Exupéry</a> wrote <i><a href="/wiki/The_Little_Prince" title="The Little Prince">Little Prince</a></i>, which has remained popular for decades with children and adults around the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-402"><a href="#cite_note-402">[388]</a></sup> As of 2014<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=France&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, French authors had more <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Literature" title="Nobel Prize in Literature">Literature Nobel Prizes</a> than <a href="/wiki/List_of_Nobel_laureates_in_Literature" title="List of Nobel laureates in Literature">those of any other nation</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Patrick_Modiano_403-0"><a href="#cite_note-Patrick_Modiano-403">[389]</a></sup> The first Nobel Prize in Literature was a French author, while France's latest Nobel prize in literature is <a href="/wiki/Patrick_Modiano" title="Patrick Modiano">Patrick Modiano</a>, who was awarded the prize in 2014.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Patrick_Modiano_403-1"><a href="#cite_note-Patrick_Modiano-403">[389]</a></sup> Jean-Paul Sartre was also the first nominee in the committee's history to refuse the prize in 1964.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Patrick_Modiano_403-2"><a href="#cite_note-Patrick_Modiano-403">[389]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Philosophy">Philosophy</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/French_philosophy" title="French philosophy">French philosophy</a></div>
<p>Medieval philosophy was dominated by <a href="/wiki/Scholasticism" title="Scholasticism">Scholasticism</a> until the emergence of <a href="/wiki/Humanism_in_France" title="Humanism in France">Humanism</a> in the Renaissance. <a href="/wiki/Modern_philosophy" title="Modern philosophy">Modern philosophy</a> began in France in the 17th century with the philosophy of <a href="/wiki/Ren%C3%A9_Descartes" title="René Descartes">René Descartes</a>, <a href="/wiki/Blaise_Pascal" title="Blaise Pascal">Blaise Pascal</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nicolas_Malebranche" title="Nicolas Malebranche">Nicolas Malebranche</a>. Descartes was the first <a href="/wiki/Western_philosophy" title="Western philosophy">Western philosopher</a> since ancient times to attempt to build a philosophical system from the ground up rather than building on the work of predecessors.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-404"><a href="#cite_note-404">[390]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-405"><a href="#cite_note-405">[391]</a></sup> His <i><a href="/wiki/Meditations_on_First_Philosophy" title="Meditations on First Philosophy">Meditations on First Philosophy</a></i> changed the primary object of philosophical thought and raised some of the most fundamental problems for foreigners such as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Spinoza" title="Spinoza">Spinoza</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gottfried_Wilhelm_Leibniz" title="Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz">Leibniz</a>, <a href="/wiki/David_Hume" title="David Hume">Hume</a>, <a href="/wiki/George_Berkeley" title="George Berkeley">Berkeley</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Immanuel_Kant" title="Immanuel Kant">Kant</a>.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Frans_Hals_-_Portret_van_Ren%C3%A9_Descartes.jpg"><img alt="Frans Hals painting of René Descartes facing right in black coat and white collar" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1000" data-file-width="817" decoding="async" height="208" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/73/Frans_Hals_-_Portret_van_Ren%C3%A9_Descartes.jpg/170px-Frans_Hals_-_Portret_van_Ren%C3%A9_Descartes.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/73/Frans_Hals_-_Portret_van_Ren%C3%A9_Descartes.jpg/255px-Frans_Hals_-_Portret_van_Ren%C3%A9_Descartes.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/73/Frans_Hals_-_Portret_van_Ren%C3%A9_Descartes.jpg/340px-Frans_Hals_-_Portret_van_Ren%C3%A9_Descartes.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Frans_Hals_-_Portret_van_Ren%C3%A9_Descartes.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Ren%C3%A9_Descartes" title="René Descartes">René Descartes</a>, founder of modern <a href="/wiki/Western_philosophy" title="Western philosophy">Western philosophy</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-406"><a href="#cite_note-406">[392]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>French philosophers produced some of the most important political works of the <a href="/wiki/Age_of_Enlightenment" title="Age of Enlightenment">Age of Enlightenment</a>. In <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/The_Spirit_of_the_Laws" title="The Spirit of the Laws">The Spirit of the Laws</a></i>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Baron_de_Montesquieu" title="Baron de Montesquieu">Baron de Montesquieu</a> theorised the principle of <a href="/wiki/Separation_of_powers" title="Separation of powers">separation of powers</a>, which has been implemented in all <a href="/wiki/Liberal_democracy" title="Liberal democracy">liberal democracies</a> since <a href="/wiki/Separation_of_powers_under_the_United_States_Constitution" title="Separation of powers under the United States Constitution">it was first applied in the United States</a>. <a href="/wiki/Voltaire" title="Voltaire">Voltaire</a> came to embody the Enlightenment with his defence of civil liberties, such as the right to a free trial and freedom of religion.
</p><p>19th-century French thought was targeted at responding to the social malaise following the French Revolution. Rationalist philosophers such as <a href="/wiki/Victor_Cousin" title="Victor Cousin">Victor Cousin</a> and <a href="/wiki/Auguste_Comte" title="Auguste Comte">Auguste Comte</a>, who called for a new social doctrine, were opposed by reactionary thinkers such as <a href="/wiki/Joseph_de_Maistre" title="Joseph de Maistre">Joseph de Maistre</a>, <a href="/wiki/Louis_de_Bonald" title="Louis de Bonald">Louis de Bonald</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hugues_Felicit%C3%A9_Robert_de_Lamennais" title="Hugues Felicité Robert de Lamennais">Félicité Robert de Lamennais</a>, who blamed the rationalist rejection of traditional order. De Maistre, together with the Englishman <a href="/wiki/Edmund_Burke" title="Edmund Burke">Edmund Burke</a>, was one of the founders of European conservatism. Comte was the founder of <a href="/wiki/Positivism" title="Positivism">positivism</a>, which <a href="/wiki/%C3%89mile_Durkheim" title="Émile Durkheim">Émile Durkheim</a> reformulated as a basis for social research.
</p><p>In the 20th century, partly as a reaction to the perceived excesses of positivism, French <a href="/wiki/Spiritualism_(philosophy)" title="Spiritualism (philosophy)">spiritualism</a> thrived with thinkers such as <a href="/wiki/Henri_Bergson" title="Henri Bergson">Henri Bergson</a> and it influenced American <a href="/wiki/Pragmatism" title="Pragmatism">pragmatism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Alfred_North_Whitehead" title="Alfred North Whitehead">Whitehead</a>'s version of <a href="/wiki/Process_philosophy" title="Process philosophy">process philosophy</a>. Meanwhile, French epistemology became a prominent school of thought with <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jules_Henri_Poincar%C3%A9" title="Jules Henri Poincaré">Jules Henri Poincaré</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gaston_Bachelard" title="Gaston Bachelard">Gaston Bachelard</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jean_Cavaill%C3%A8s" title="Jean Cavaillès">Jean Cavaillès</a> and <a href="/wiki/Jules_Vuillemin" title="Jules Vuillemin">Jules Vuillemin</a>. Influenced by German <a href="/wiki/Phenomenology_(philosophy)" title="Phenomenology (philosophy)">phenomenology</a> and <a href="/wiki/Existentialism" title="Existentialism">existentialism</a>, the philosophy of <a href="/wiki/Jean-Paul_Sartre" title="Jean-Paul Sartre">Jean-Paul Sartre</a> gained a strong influence after World War II, and late-20th-century-France became the cradle of <a href="/wiki/Postmodern_philosophy" title="Postmodern philosophy">postmodern philosophy</a> with <a href="/wiki/Jean-Fran%C3%A7ois_Lyotard" title="Jean-François Lyotard">Jean-François Lyotard</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jean_Baudrillard" title="Jean Baudrillard">Jean Baudrillard</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jacques_Derrida" title="Jacques Derrida">Jacques Derrida</a> and <a href="/wiki/Michel_Foucault" title="Michel Foucault">Michel Foucault</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Music">Music</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Music_of_France" title="Music of France">Music of France</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Claude_Debussy_atelier_Nadar.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1140" data-file-width="932" decoding="async" height="269" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Claude_Debussy_atelier_Nadar.jpg/220px-Claude_Debussy_atelier_Nadar.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Claude_Debussy_atelier_Nadar.jpg/330px-Claude_Debussy_atelier_Nadar.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Claude_Debussy_atelier_Nadar.jpg/440px-Claude_Debussy_atelier_Nadar.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Claude_Debussy_atelier_Nadar.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Claude_Debussy" title="Claude Debussy">Claude Debussy</a></div></div></div>
<p>France has a long and varied musical history. It experienced a golden age in the 17th century thanks to Louis XIV, who employed many talented musicians and composers in the royal court. The most renowned composers of this period include <a href="/wiki/Marc-Antoine_Charpentier" title="Marc-Antoine Charpentier">Marc-Antoine Charpentier</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fran%C3%A7ois_Couperin" title="François Couperin">François Couperin</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Michel-Richard_Delalande" title="Michel-Richard Delalande">Michel-Richard Delalande</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jean-Baptiste_Lully" title="Jean-Baptiste Lully">Jean-Baptiste Lully</a> and <a href="/wiki/Marin_Marais" title="Marin Marais">Marin Marais</a>, all of them composers at the court. After the death of the "Roi Soleil", French musical creation lost dynamism, but in the next century the music of <a href="/wiki/Jean-Philippe_Rameau" title="Jean-Philippe Rameau">Jean-Philippe Rameau</a> reached some prestige, and today he is still one of the most renowned French composers. Rameau became the dominant composer of <a href="/wiki/French_opera" title="French opera">French opera</a> and the leading French composer for the harpsichord.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-407"><a href="#cite_note-407">[393]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources#What_information_to_include" title="Wikipedia:Citing sources"><span title="A complete citation is needed. (January 2018)">full citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p><p>French composers played an important role during the music of the 19th and early 20th century, which is considered to be the <a href="/wiki/Romantic_music" title="Romantic music">Romantic music</a> era. Romantic music emphasised a surrender to nature, a fascination with the past and the supernatural, the exploration of unusual, strange and surprising sounds, and a focus on national identity. This period was also a golden age for operas. French composers from the Romantic era included: <a href="/wiki/Hector_Berlioz" title="Hector Berlioz">Hector Berlioz</a> (best known for his <i><a href="/wiki/Symphonie_fantastique" title="Symphonie fantastique">Symphonie fantastique</a></i>), <a href="/wiki/Georges_Bizet" title="Georges Bizet">Georges Bizet</a> (best known for <i><a href="/wiki/Carmen" title="Carmen">Carmen</a></i>, which has become one of the most popular and frequently performed operas), <a href="/wiki/Gabriel_Faur%C3%A9" title="Gabriel Fauré">Gabriel Fauré</a> (best known for his <i><a href="/wiki/Pavane_(Faur%C3%A9)" title="Pavane (Fauré)">Pavane</a></i>, <a href="/wiki/Requiem_(Faur%C3%A9)" title="Requiem (Fauré)"><i>Requiem</i></a>, and <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Faur%C3%A9_Nocturnes" title="Fauré Nocturnes">nocturnes</a></i>), <a href="/wiki/Charles_Gounod" title="Charles Gounod">Charles Gounod</a> (best known for his <i><a href="/wiki/Ave_Maria_(Bach/Gounod)" title="Ave Maria (Bach/Gounod)">Ave Maria</a></i> and his opera <i><a href="/wiki/Faust_(opera)" title="Faust (opera)">Faust</a></i>), <a href="/wiki/Jacques_Offenbach" title="Jacques Offenbach">Jacques Offenbach</a> (best known for his 100 <a href="/wiki/Operetta" title="Operetta">operettas</a> of the 1850s–1870s and his uncompleted opera <i><a href="/wiki/The_Tales_of_Hoffmann" title="The Tales of Hoffmann">The Tales of Hoffmann</a></i>), <a href="/wiki/%C3%89douard_Lalo" title="Édouard Lalo">Édouard Lalo</a> (best known for his <i><a href="/wiki/Symphonie_espagnole" title="Symphonie espagnole">Symphonie espagnole</a></i> for violin and orchestra and his <a href="/wiki/Cello_Concerto_(Lalo)" title="Cello Concerto (Lalo)">Cello Concerto in D minor</a>), <a href="/wiki/Jules_Massenet" title="Jules Massenet">Jules Massenet</a> (best known for his operas, of which he wrote more than thirty, the most frequently staged are <i><a href="/wiki/Manon" title="Manon">Manon</a></i> (1884) and <i><a href="/wiki/Werther" title="Werther">Werther</a></i> (1892)) and <a href="/wiki/Camille_Saint-Sa%C3%ABns" title="Camille Saint-Saëns">Camille Saint-Saëns</a> (he has many frequently-performed works, including <i><a href="/wiki/The_Carnival_of_the_Animals" title="The Carnival of the Animals">The Carnival of the Animals</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Danse_macabre_(Saint-Sa%C3%ABns)" title="Danse macabre (Saint-Saëns)">Danse macabre</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Samson_and_Delilah_(opera)" title="Samson and Delilah (opera)">Samson and Delilah</a></i> (Opera), <i><a href="/wiki/Introduction_and_Rondo_Capriccioso" title="Introduction and Rondo Capriccioso">Introduction and Rondo Capriccioso</a></i> and his <a href="/wiki/Symphony_No._3_(Saint-Sa%C3%ABns)" title="Symphony No. 3 (Saint-Saëns)">Symphony No. 3</a>).
</p><p>Later came precursors of modern classical music. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/%C3%89rik_Satie" title="Érik Satie">Érik Satie</a> was a key member of the early-20th-century Parisian <a href="/wiki/Avant-garde" title="Avant-garde">avant-garde</a>, best known for his <i><a href="/wiki/Gymnop%C3%A9dies" title="Gymnopédies">Gymnopédies</a></i>. <a href="/wiki/Francis_Poulenc" title="Francis Poulenc">Francis Poulenc</a>'s best known works are his piano suite <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Trois_mouvements_perp%C3%A9tuels" title="Trois mouvements perpétuels">Trois mouvements perpétuels</a></i> (1919), the ballet <i><a href="/wiki/Les_biches" title="Les biches">Les biches</a></i> (1923), the <i><a href="/wiki/Concert_champ%C3%AAtre" title="Concert champêtre">Concert champêtre</a></i> (1928) for <a href="/wiki/Harpsichord" title="Harpsichord">harpsichord</a> and orchestra, the opera <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dialogues_des_Carm%C3%A9lites" title="Dialogues des Carmélites">Dialogues des Carmélites</a></i> (1957) and the <i><a href="/wiki/Gloria_(Poulenc)" title="Gloria (Poulenc)">Gloria</a></i> (1959) for <a href="/wiki/Soprano" title="Soprano">soprano</a>, choir and orchestra. <a href="/wiki/Maurice_Ravel" title="Maurice Ravel">Maurice Ravel</a> and <a href="/wiki/Claude_Debussy" title="Claude Debussy">Claude Debussy</a> are the most prominent figures associated with <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Impressionist_music" title="Impressionist music">Impressionist music</a>. Debussy was among the most influential composers of the late 19th and early 20th centuries, and his use of non-traditional scales and <a href="/wiki/Chromaticism" title="Chromaticism">chromaticism</a> influenced many composers who followed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-408"><a href="#cite_note-408">[394]</a></sup> Debussy's music is noted for its sensory content and frequent usage of <a href="/wiki/Atonality" title="Atonality">atonality</a>. The two composers invented new musical forms<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-409"><a href="#cite_note-409">[395]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-410"><a href="#cite_note-410">[396]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-411"><a href="#cite_note-411">[397]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-412"><a href="#cite_note-412">[398]</a></sup> and new sounds. Ravel's piano compositions, such as <i><a href="/wiki/Jeux_d%27eau_(Ravel)" title="Jeux d'eau (Ravel)">Jeux d'eau</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Miroirs" title="Miroirs">Miroirs</a></i>, <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Le_tombeau_de_Couperin" title="Le tombeau de Couperin">Le tombeau de Couperin</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Gaspard_de_la_nuit" title="Gaspard de la nuit">Gaspard de la nuit</a></i>, demand considerable virtuosity. His mastery of orchestration is evident in the <i><a href="/wiki/Rapsodie_espagnole" title="Rapsodie espagnole">Rapsodie espagnole</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Daphnis_et_Chlo%C3%A9" title="Daphnis et Chloé">Daphnis et Chloé</a></i>, his arrangement of <a href="/wiki/Modest_Mussorgsky" title="Modest Mussorgsky">Modest Mussorgsky</a>'s <i><a href="/wiki/Pictures_at_an_Exhibition" title="Pictures at an Exhibition">Pictures at an Exhibition</a></i> and his orchestral work <i><a href="/wiki/Bol%C3%A9ro" title="Boléro">Boléro</a></i> (1928). More recently, in the middle of the 20th century, <a href="/wiki/Maurice_Ohana" title="Maurice Ohana">Maurice Ohana</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pierre_Schaeffer" title="Pierre Schaeffer">Pierre Schaeffer</a> and <a href="/wiki/Pierre_Boulez" title="Pierre Boulez">Pierre Boulez</a> contributed to the evolutions of <a href="/wiki/Contemporary_classical_music" title="Contemporary classical music">contemporary classical music</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-413"><a href="#cite_note-413">[399]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Serge_Gainsbourg_par_Claude_Truong-Ngoc_1981.jpg"><img alt="head shot of Serge Gainsbourg" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3661" data-file-width="5622" decoding="async" height="143" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9a/Serge_Gainsbourg_par_Claude_Truong-Ngoc_1981.jpg/220px-Serge_Gainsbourg_par_Claude_Truong-Ngoc_1981.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9a/Serge_Gainsbourg_par_Claude_Truong-Ngoc_1981.jpg/330px-Serge_Gainsbourg_par_Claude_Truong-Ngoc_1981.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9a/Serge_Gainsbourg_par_Claude_Truong-Ngoc_1981.jpg/440px-Serge_Gainsbourg_par_Claude_Truong-Ngoc_1981.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Serge_Gainsbourg_par_Claude_Truong-Ngoc_1981.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Serge_Gainsbourg" title="Serge Gainsbourg">Serge Gainsbourg</a>, one of the world's most influential popular musicians</div></div></div>
<p>French music then followed the rapid emergence of pop and rock music at the middle of the 20th century. Although English-speaking creations achieved popularity in the country, <a href="/wiki/French_popular_music" title="French popular music">French pop music</a>, known as <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chanson_fran%C3%A7aise" title="Chanson française">chanson française</a></i>, has also remained very popular. Among the most important French artists of the century are <a href="/wiki/%C3%89dith_Piaf" title="Édith Piaf">Édith Piaf</a>, <a href="/wiki/Georges_Brassens" title="Georges Brassens">Georges Brassens</a>, <a href="/wiki/L%C3%A9o_Ferr%C3%A9" title="Léo Ferré">Léo Ferré</a>, <a href="/wiki/Charles_Aznavour" title="Charles Aznavour">Charles Aznavour</a> and <a href="/wiki/Serge_Gainsbourg" title="Serge Gainsbourg">Serge Gainsbourg</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-414"><a href="#cite_note-414">[400]</a></sup> Although there are very few rock bands in France compared to English-speaking countries,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-415"><a href="#cite_note-415">[401]</a></sup> bands such as <a href="/wiki/Noir_D%C3%A9sir" title="Noir Désir">Noir Désir</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mano_Negra_(band)" title="Mano Negra (band)">Mano Negra</a>, <a href="/wiki/Niagara_(band)" title="Niagara (band)">Niagara</a>, <a href="/wiki/Les_Rita_Mitsouko" title="Les Rita Mitsouko">Les Rita Mitsouko</a> and more recently <a href="/wiki/Superbus_(band)" title="Superbus (band)">Superbus</a>, <a href="/wiki/Phoenix_(band)" title="Phoenix (band)">Phoenix</a> and <a href="/wiki/Gojira_(band)" title="Gojira (band)">Gojira</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-frmusic_416-0"><a href="#cite_note-frmusic-416">[402]</a></sup> or <a href="/wiki/Shaka_Ponk" title="Shaka Ponk">Shaka Ponk</a>, have reached worldwide popularity.
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Daftpunklapremiere2010.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="524" data-file-width="776" decoding="async" height="149" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/Daftpunklapremiere2010.jpg/220px-Daftpunklapremiere2010.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/Daftpunklapremiere2010.jpg/330px-Daftpunklapremiere2010.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/Daftpunklapremiere2010.jpg/440px-Daftpunklapremiere2010.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Daftpunklapremiere2010.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Daft_Punk" title="Daft Punk">Daft Punk</a>, pioneers of the <a href="/wiki/French_house" title="French house">French house</a> movement</div></div></div>
<p>Other French artists with international careers have been popular in several countries, most notably female singers <a href="/wiki/Dalida" title="Dalida">Dalida</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mireille_Mathieu" title="Mireille Mathieu">Mireille Mathieu</a>, <a href="/wiki/Myl%C3%A8ne_Farmer" title="Mylène Farmer">Mylène Farmer</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-frmusic_416-1"><a href="#cite_note-frmusic-416">[402]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Aliz%C3%A9e" title="Alizée">Alizée</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nolwenn_Leroy" title="Nolwenn Leroy">Nolwenn Leroy</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-417"><a href="#cite_note-417">[403]</a></sup> electronic music pioneers <a href="/wiki/Jean-Michel_Jarre" title="Jean-Michel Jarre">Jean-Michel Jarre</a>, <a href="/wiki/Laurent_Garnier" title="Laurent Garnier">Laurent Garnier</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bob_Sinclar" title="Bob Sinclar">Bob Sinclar</a>, later <a href="/wiki/Martin_Solveig" title="Martin Solveig">Martin Solveig</a> and <a href="/wiki/David_Guetta" title="David Guetta">David Guetta</a>. In the 1990s and 2000s (decade), electronic duos <a href="/wiki/Daft_Punk" title="Daft Punk">Daft Punk</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Justice_(French_band)" title="Justice (French band)">Justice</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Air_(French_band)" title="Air (French band)">Air</a> also reached worldwide popularity and contributed to the reputation of modern electronic music in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-frmusic_416-2"><a href="#cite_note-frmusic-416">[402]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-418"><a href="#cite_note-418">[404]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-419"><a href="#cite_note-419">[405]</a></sup>
</p><p>Among current musical events and institutions in France, many are dedicated to classical music and operas. The most prestigious institutions are the state-owned <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Paris_National_Opera" title="Paris National Opera">Paris National Opera</a> (with its two sites <a href="/wiki/Palais_Garnier" title="Palais Garnier">Palais Garnier</a> and <a href="/wiki/Op%C3%A9ra_Bastille" title="Opéra Bastille">Opéra Bastille</a>), the <a href="/wiki/Op%C3%A9ra_National_de_Lyon" title="Opéra National de Lyon">Opéra National de Lyon</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Th%C3%A9%C3%A2tre_du_Ch%C3%A2telet" title="Théâtre du Châtelet">Théâtre du Châtelet</a> in Paris, the <a href="/wiki/Th%C3%A9%C3%A2tre_du_Capitole" title="Théâtre du Capitole">Théâtre du Capitole</a> in <a href="/wiki/Toulouse" title="Toulouse">Toulouse</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Grand_Th%C3%A9%C3%A2tre_de_Bordeaux" title="Grand Théâtre de Bordeaux">Grand Théâtre de Bordeaux</a>. As for music festivals, there are several events organised, the most popular being <a href="/wiki/Eurock%C3%A9ennes" title="Eurockéennes">Eurockéennes</a> (a <a href="/wiki/Word_play" title="Word play">word play</a> which sounds in French as "European"), <a href="/wiki/Solidays" title="Solidays">Solidays</a> and <a href="/wiki/Rock_en_Seine" title="Rock en Seine">Rock en Seine</a>. The <a href="/wiki/F%C3%AAte_de_la_Musique" title="Fête de la Musique">Fête de la Musique</a>, imitated by many foreign cities, was first launched by the French Government in 1982.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-420"><a href="#cite_note-420">[406]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-421"><a href="#cite_note-421">[407]</a></sup> Major music halls and venues in France include <a href="/wiki/Le_Z%C3%A9nith" title="Le Zénith">Le Zénith</a> sites present in many cities and other places in Paris (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Paris_Olympia" title="Paris Olympia">Paris Olympia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Th%C3%A9%C3%A2tre_Mogador" title="Théâtre Mogador">Théâtre Mogador</a>, <a href="/wiki/%C3%89lys%C3%A9e_Montmartre" title="Élysée Montmartre">Élysée Montmartre</a>).
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cinema">Cinema</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_France" title="Cinema of France">Cinema of France</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:152px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Palmed%27or.jpg"><img alt="Palme d'Or award in presentation case" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2448" data-file-width="3264" decoding="async" height="113" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2a/Palmed%27or.jpg/150px-Palmed%27or.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2a/Palmed%27or.jpg/225px-Palmed%27or.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2a/Palmed%27or.jpg/300px-Palmed%27or.jpg 2x" width="150"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Palmed%27or.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A <i><a href="/wiki/Palme_d%27Or" title="Palme d'Or">Palme d'Or</a></i> from the <a href="/wiki/Cannes_Film_Festival" title="Cannes Film Festival">Cannes Film Festival</a>, one of the "<a href="/wiki/Film_festival" title="Film festival">Big Three</a>" film festivals alongside the <a href="/wiki/Venice_Film_Festival" title="Venice Film Festival">Venice Film Festival</a> and <a href="/wiki/Berlin_International_Film_Festival" title="Berlin International Film Festival">Berlin International Film Festival</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-422"><a href="#cite_note-422">[408]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-423"><a href="#cite_note-423">[409]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-424"><a href="#cite_note-424">[410]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:152px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Louis_de_Fun%C3%A8s_1970.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2359" data-file-width="2000" decoding="async" height="177" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/Louis_de_Fun%C3%A8s_1970.jpg/150px-Louis_de_Fun%C3%A8s_1970.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/Louis_de_Fun%C3%A8s_1970.jpg/225px-Louis_de_Fun%C3%A8s_1970.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/Louis_de_Fun%C3%A8s_1970.jpg/300px-Louis_de_Fun%C3%A8s_1970.jpg 2x" width="150"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Louis_de_Fun%C3%A8s_1970.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Louis_de_Fun%C3%A8s" title="Louis de Funès">Louis de Funès</a>, often called "France's favourite actor", has played over 130 roles in film and over 100 on stage.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-425"><a href="#cite_note-425">[411]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>France has historical and strong links with <a href="/wiki/Filmmaking" title="Filmmaking">cinema</a>, with two Frenchmen, Auguste and Louis Lumière (known as the <a href="/wiki/Auguste_and_Louis_Lumi%C3%A8re" title="Auguste and Louis Lumière">Lumière Brothers</a>) credited with creating cinema in 1895.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-426"><a href="#cite_note-426">[412]</a></sup> The world's first female filmmaker, <a href="/wiki/Alice_Guy-Blach%C3%A9" title="Alice Guy-Blaché">Alice Guy-Blaché</a>, was also from France.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-427"><a href="#cite_note-427">[413]</a></sup> Several important cinematic movements, including the late 1950s and 1960s <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nouvelle_Vague" title="Nouvelle Vague">Nouvelle Vague</a>, began in the country. It is noted for having a strong film industry, due in part to protections afforded by the <a href="/wiki/Government_of_France" title="Government of France">Government of France</a>. France remains a leader in filmmaking, as of 2015<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=France&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup> producing more films than any other European country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-428"><a href="#cite_note-428">[414]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYT_1995-02-28_429-0"><a href="#cite_note-NYT_1995-02-28-429">[415]</a></sup> The nation also hosts the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cannes_Festival" title="Cannes Festival">Cannes Festival</a>, one of the most important and famous film festivals in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-430"><a href="#cite_note-430">[416]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-431"><a href="#cite_note-431">[417]</a></sup>
</p><p>Apart from its strong and innovative film tradition, France has also been a gathering spot for artists from across Europe and the world. For this reason, French cinema is sometimes intertwined with the cinema of foreign nations. Directors from nations such as Poland (<a href="/wiki/Roman_Polanski" title="Roman Polanski">Roman Polanski</a>, <a href="/wiki/Krzysztof_Kie%C5%9Blowski" title="Krzysztof Kieślowski">Krzysztof Kieślowski</a>, <a href="/wiki/Andrzej_%C5%BBu%C5%82awski" title="Andrzej Żuławski">Andrzej Żuławski</a>), Argentina (<a href="/wiki/Gaspar_No%C3%A9" title="Gaspar Noé">Gaspar Noé</a>, <a href="/wiki/Edgardo_Cozarinsky" title="Edgardo Cozarinsky">Edgardo Cozarinsky</a>), Russia (<a href="/wiki/Alexandre_Alexeieff" title="Alexandre Alexeieff">Alexandre Alexeieff</a>, <a href="/wiki/Anatole_Litvak" title="Anatole Litvak">Anatole Litvak</a>), Austria (<a href="/wiki/Michael_Haneke" title="Michael Haneke">Michael Haneke</a>) and Georgia (<a href="/wiki/G%C3%A9la_Babluani" title="Géla Babluani">Géla Babluani</a>, <a href="/wiki/Otar_Iosseliani" title="Otar Iosseliani">Otar Iosseliani</a>) are prominent in the ranks of French cinema. Conversely, French directors have had prolific and influential careers in other countries, such as <a href="/wiki/Luc_Besson" title="Luc Besson">Luc Besson</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jacques_Tourneur" title="Jacques Tourneur">Jacques Tourneur</a> or <a href="/wiki/Francis_Veber" title="Francis Veber">Francis Veber</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_the_United_States" title="Cinema of the United States">United States</a>.
</p><p>Although the French film market is dominated by Hollywood, France is the only nation in the world where American films make up the smallest share of total film revenues, at 50%, compared with 77% in Germany and 69% in Japan.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-erudit_432-0"><a href="#cite_note-erudit-432">[418]</a></sup> French films account for 35% of the total film revenues of France, which is the highest percentage of national film revenues in the developed world outside the United States, compared to 14% in Spain and 8% in the UK.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-erudit_432-1"><a href="#cite_note-erudit-432">[418]</a></sup> France is in 2013 the 2nd exporter of films in the world after the United States.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-unifrance.org_433-0"><a href="#cite_note-unifrance.org-433">[419]</a></sup>
</p><p>France historically was the cultural centre of the world,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-exception_322-1"><a href="#cite_note-exception-322">[309]</a></sup> although its dominant position has been surpassed by the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/American_culture" title="American culture">United States</a>. Today, France takes steps in protecting and promoting its culture, becoming a leading advocate of the <a href="/wiki/Cultural_exception" title="Cultural exception">cultural exception</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-434"><a href="#cite_note-434">[420]</a></sup> The nation succeeded in convincing all EU members to refuse to include culture and audiovisuals in the list of liberalised sectors of the WTO in 1993.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-435"><a href="#cite_note-435">[421]</a></sup> Moreover, this decision was confirmed in a voting in the <a href="/wiki/UNESCO" title="UNESCO">UNESCO</a> in 2005: the principle of "cultural exception" won an overwhelming victory with 198 countries voting for it and only 2 countries, the United States and Israel, voting against.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-436"><a href="#cite_note-436">[422]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Fashion">Fashion</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/French_fashion" title="French fashion">French fashion</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Channel_headquarters_bordercropped.jpg"><img alt="Chanel's headquarters storefront window at the Place Vendôme Paris with awning" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1020" data-file-width="764" decoding="async" height="240" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Channel_headquarters_bordercropped.jpg/180px-Channel_headquarters_bordercropped.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Channel_headquarters_bordercropped.jpg/270px-Channel_headquarters_bordercropped.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Channel_headquarters_bordercropped.jpg/360px-Channel_headquarters_bordercropped.jpg 2x" width="180"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Channel_headquarters_bordercropped.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Chanel" title="Chanel">Chanel</a>'s headquarters on <a href="/wiki/Place_Vend%C3%B4me" title="Place Vendôme">Place Vendôme</a>, Paris</div></div></div>
<p>Fashion has been an important industry and cultural export of France since the 17th century, and modern "haute couture" originated in Paris in the 1860s. Today, Paris, along with London, Milan, and New York City, is considered one of the world's <a href="/wiki/Fashion_capital" title="Fashion capital">fashion capitals</a>, and the city is home or headquarters to many of the premier fashion houses. The expression <a href="/wiki/Haute_couture" title="Haute couture">Haute couture</a> is, in France, a legally protected name, guaranteeing certain quality standards.
</p><p>The association of France with fashion and style (French: <i lang="fr">la mode</i>) dates largely to the reign of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Louis_XIV_of_France" title="Louis XIV of France">Louis XIV</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-437"><a href="#cite_note-437">[423]</a></sup> when the luxury goods industries in France came increasingly under royal control and the French royal court became, arguably, the arbiter of taste and style in Europe. But France renewed its dominance of the high fashion (French: <i lang="fr">couture <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r886049405">.mw-parser-output .noitalic{font-style:normal}</style><span class="noitalic">or</span> haute couture</i>) industry in the years 1860–1960 through the establishing of the great <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Couturier" title="Couturier">couturier</a> houses such as <a href="/wiki/Chanel" title="Chanel">Chanel</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Christian_Dior_S.A." title="Christian Dior S.A.">Dior</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Givenchy" title="Givenchy">Givenchy</a>. The French perfume industry is world leader in its sector and is centred on the town of <a href="/wiki/Grasse" title="Grasse">Grasse</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-438"><a href="#cite_note-438">[424]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the 1960s, the elitist "Haute couture" came under criticism from France's <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/May_1968_in_France" title="May 1968 in France">youth culture</a>. In 1966, the designer <a href="/wiki/Yves_Saint_Laurent_(designer)" title="Yves Saint Laurent (designer)">Yves Saint Laurent</a> broke with established Haute Couture norms by launching a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pr%C3%AAt-%C3%A0-porter" title="Prêt-à-porter">prêt-à-porter</a> ("ready to wear") line and expanding French fashion into mass manufacturing. With a greater focus on marketing and manufacturing, new trends were established by <a href="/wiki/Sonia_Rykiel" title="Sonia Rykiel">Sonia Rykiel</a>, <a href="/wiki/Thierry_Mugler" title="Thierry Mugler">Thierry Mugler</a>, <a href="/wiki/Claude_Montana" title="Claude Montana">Claude Montana</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jean-Paul_Gaultier" title="Jean-Paul Gaultier">Jean-Paul Gaultier</a> and <a href="/wiki/Christian_Lacroix" title="Christian Lacroix">Christian Lacroix</a> in the 1970s and 1980s. The 1990s saw a conglomeration of many French couture houses under luxury giants and multinationals such as <a href="/wiki/LVMH" title="LVMH">LVMH</a>.
</p><p>According to 2017 data compiled by <a href="/wiki/Deloitte" title="Deloitte">Deloitte</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Louis_Vuitton_Moet_Hennessey" title="Louis Vuitton Moet Hennessey">Louis Vuitton Moet Hennessey</a> (LVMH), a French brand, is the largest luxury company in the world by sales, selling more than twice the amount of its nearest competitor.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mode_439-0"><a href="#cite_note-mode-439">[425]</a></sup> Moreover, France also possesses 3 of the top 10 luxury goods companies by sales (<a href="/wiki/LVMH" title="LVMH">LVMH</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kering_SA" title="Kering SA">Kering SA</a>, <a href="/wiki/L%27Or%C3%A9al" title="L'Oréal">L'Oréal</a>), more than any other country in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mode_439-1"><a href="#cite_note-mode-439">[425]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Media">Media</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Telecommunications_in_France" title="Telecommunications in France">Telecommunications in France</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Si%C3%A8ge_de_l%27AFP_13_place_de_la_Bourse_Paris.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1600" data-file-width="2400" decoding="async" height="120" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2b/Si%C3%A8ge_de_l%27AFP_13_place_de_la_Bourse_Paris.jpg/180px-Si%C3%A8ge_de_l%27AFP_13_place_de_la_Bourse_Paris.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2b/Si%C3%A8ge_de_l%27AFP_13_place_de_la_Bourse_Paris.jpg/270px-Si%C3%A8ge_de_l%27AFP_13_place_de_la_Bourse_Paris.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2b/Si%C3%A8ge_de_l%27AFP_13_place_de_la_Bourse_Paris.jpg/360px-Si%C3%A8ge_de_l%27AFP_13_place_de_la_Bourse_Paris.jpg 2x" width="180"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Si%C3%A8ge_de_l%27AFP_13_place_de_la_Bourse_Paris.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The Parisian headquarters of <a href="/wiki/Agence_France-Presse" title="Agence France-Presse">Agence France-Presse</a>, one of the world's oldest and leading <a href="/wiki/News_agency" title="News agency">news agencies</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-440"><a href="#cite_note-440">[426]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Best-selling daily national newspapers in France are <i><a href="/wiki/Le_Parisien" title="Le Parisien">Le Parisien</a> Aujourd'hui en France</i> (with 460,000 sold daily), <i><a href="/wiki/Le_Monde" title="Le Monde">Le Monde</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Le_Figaro" title="Le Figaro">Le Figaro</a></i>, with around 300,000 copies sold daily, but also <i><a href="/wiki/L%27%C3%89quipe" title="L'Équipe">L'Équipe</a></i>, dedicated to sports coverage.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-441"><a href="#cite_note-441">[427]</a></sup> In the past years, free dailies made a breakthrough, with <i><a href="/wiki/Metro_International" title="Metro International">Metro</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/20_minutes_(France)" title="20 minutes (France)">20 Minutes</a></i> and <i>Direct Plus</i> distributed at more than 650,000 copies respectively.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-442"><a href="#cite_note-442">[428]</a></sup> However, the widest circulations are reached by regional daily <i><a href="/wiki/Ouest-France" title="Ouest-France">Ouest-France</a></i> with more than 750,000 copies sold, and the 50 other regional papers have also high sales.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-443"><a href="#cite_note-443">[429]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-444"><a href="#cite_note-444">[430]</a></sup> The sector of weekly magazines is stronger and diversified with more than 400 specialised weekly magazines published in the country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-445"><a href="#cite_note-445">[431]</a></sup>
</p><p>The most influential news magazines are the left-wing <i><a href="/wiki/L%27Obs" title="L'Obs">Le Nouvel Observateur</a></i>, centrist <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/L%27Express_(France)" title="L'Express (France)">L'Express</a></i> and right-wing <i><a href="/wiki/Le_Point" title="Le Point">Le Point</a></i> (more than 400,000 copies),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-446"><a href="#cite_note-446">[432]</a></sup> but the highest circulation for weeklies is reached by TV magazines and by women's magazines, among them <i><a href="/wiki/Marie_Claire" title="Marie Claire">Marie Claire</a></i> and <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ELLE" title="ELLE">ELLE</a></i>, which have foreign versions. Influential weeklies also include investigative and satirical papers <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Le_Canard_Encha%C3%AEn%C3%A9" title="Le Canard Enchaîné">Le Canard Enchaîné</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Charlie_Hebdo" title="Charlie Hebdo">Charlie Hebdo</a></i>, as well as <i><a href="/wiki/Paris_Match" title="Paris Match">Paris Match</a></i>. Like in most industrialised nations, the print media have been affected by a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Newspaper_crisis" title="Newspaper crisis">severe crisis</a> in the past decade. In 2008, the government launched a major initiative to help the sector reform and become financially independent,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-447"><a href="#cite_note-447">[433]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-448"><a href="#cite_note-448">[434]</a></sup> but in 2009 it had to give 600,000 euros to help the print media cope with the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Global_financial_crisis_of_2008%E2%80%932009" title="Global financial crisis of 2008–2009">economic crisis</a>, in addition to existing subsidies.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-449"><a href="#cite_note-449">[435]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Le_Figaro_logo.png"><img alt="masthead of Le Figaro newspaper" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="120" data-file-width="734" decoding="async" height="36" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/Le_Figaro_logo.png/220px-Le_Figaro_logo.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/Le_Figaro_logo.png/330px-Le_Figaro_logo.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/Le_Figaro_logo.png/440px-Le_Figaro_logo.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Le_Figaro_logo.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div><i><a href="/wiki/Le_Figaro" title="Le Figaro">Le Figaro</a></i> was founded in 1826; many of France's most prominent authors have written in its columns over the decades, and it is still considered a <a href="/wiki/Newspaper_of_record" title="Newspaper of record">newspaper of record</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-450"><a href="#cite_note-450">[436]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>In 1974, after years of centralised monopoly on radio and television, the governmental agency <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ORTF" title="ORTF">ORTF</a> was split into several national institutions, but the three already-existing TV channels and four national radio stations<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-451"><a href="#cite_note-451">[437]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mediapol_452-0"><a href="#cite_note-mediapol-452">[438]</a></sup> remained under state-control. It was only in 1981 that the government allowed free broadcasting in the territory, ending the state monopoly on radio.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mediapol_452-1"><a href="#cite_note-mediapol-452">[438]</a></sup> French television was partly liberalised in the next two-decade with the creation of several commercial channels, mainly thanks to cable and satellite television. In 2005 the national service <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/T%C3%A9l%C3%A9vision_Num%C3%A9rique_Terrestre" title="Télévision Numérique Terrestre">Télévision Numérique Terrestre</a> introduced digital television all over the territory, allowing the creation of other channels.
</p><p>The four existing national channels are owned by state-owned consortium <a href="/wiki/France_T%C3%A9l%C3%A9visions" title="France Télévisions">France Télévisions</a>, funded by advertising revenue and TV licence fees. Public broadcasting group <a href="/wiki/Radio_France" title="Radio France">Radio France</a> runs five national radio stations. Among these public media are <a href="/wiki/Radio_France_Internationale" title="Radio France Internationale">Radio France Internationale</a>, which broadcasts programmes in French all over the world, as well as Franco-German TV channel <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/TV5_Monde" title="TV5 Monde">TV5 Monde</a>. In 2006, the government created global news channel <a href="/wiki/France_24" title="France 24">France 24</a>. Long-established TV channels <a href="/wiki/TF1" title="TF1">TF1</a> (privatised in 1987), <a href="/wiki/France_2" title="France 2">France 2</a> and <a href="/wiki/France_3" title="France 3">France 3</a> have the highest shares, whilst radio stations <a href="/wiki/RTL_(French_radio)" title="RTL (French radio)">RTL</a>, <a href="/wiki/Europe_1" title="Europe 1">Europe 1</a> and state-owned <a href="/wiki/France_Inter" title="France Inter">France Inter</a> are some of the least listened to.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Society">Society</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Human_rights_in_France" title="Human rights in France">Human rights in France</a> and <a href="/wiki/LGBT_rights_in_France" title="LGBT rights in France">LGBT rights in France</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Germaine_Tillion,_Genevi%C3%A8ve_de_Gaulle-Anthonioz,_Pierre_Brossolette_et_Jean_Zay_rentrent_au_Panth%C3%A9on_15.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3424" data-file-width="4560" decoding="async" height="128" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6c/Germaine_Tillion%2C_Genevi%C3%A8ve_de_Gaulle-Anthonioz%2C_Pierre_Brossolette_et_Jean_Zay_rentrent_au_Panth%C3%A9on_15.jpg/170px-Germaine_Tillion%2C_Genevi%C3%A8ve_de_Gaulle-Anthonioz%2C_Pierre_Brossolette_et_Jean_Zay_rentrent_au_Panth%C3%A9on_15.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6c/Germaine_Tillion%2C_Genevi%C3%A8ve_de_Gaulle-Anthonioz%2C_Pierre_Brossolette_et_Jean_Zay_rentrent_au_Panth%C3%A9on_15.jpg/255px-Germaine_Tillion%2C_Genevi%C3%A8ve_de_Gaulle-Anthonioz%2C_Pierre_Brossolette_et_Jean_Zay_rentrent_au_Panth%C3%A9on_15.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6c/Germaine_Tillion%2C_Genevi%C3%A8ve_de_Gaulle-Anthonioz%2C_Pierre_Brossolette_et_Jean_Zay_rentrent_au_Panth%C3%A9on_15.jpg/340px-Germaine_Tillion%2C_Genevi%C3%A8ve_de_Gaulle-Anthonioz%2C_Pierre_Brossolette_et_Jean_Zay_rentrent_au_Panth%C3%A9on_15.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Germaine_Tillion,_Genevi%C3%A8ve_de_Gaulle-Anthonioz,_Pierre_Brossolette_et_Jean_Zay_rentrent_au_Panth%C3%A9on_15.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Admittance of <a href="/wiki/Germaine_Tillion" title="Germaine Tillion">Germaine Tillion</a>, <a href="/wiki/Genevi%C3%A8ve_de_Gaulle-Anthonioz" title="Geneviève de Gaulle-Anthonioz">Geneviève de Gaulle-Anthonioz</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pierre_Brossolette" title="Pierre Brossolette">Pierre Brossolette</a> and <a href="/wiki/Jean_Zay" title="Jean Zay">Jean Zay</a> at the <a href="/wiki/Panth%C3%A9on" title="Panthéon">Pantheon</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Mausoleum" title="Mausoleum">mausoleum</a> for distinguished French people, in 2015</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:MariannedeTheodoreDoriot.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2816" data-file-width="1964" decoding="async" height="244" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2a/MariannedeTheodoreDoriot.JPG/170px-MariannedeTheodoreDoriot.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2a/MariannedeTheodoreDoriot.JPG/255px-MariannedeTheodoreDoriot.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2a/MariannedeTheodoreDoriot.JPG/340px-MariannedeTheodoreDoriot.JPG 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:MariannedeTheodoreDoriot.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Sculpture of <a href="/wiki/Marianne" title="Marianne">Marianne</a>, a common national personification of the French Republic</div></div></div>
<p>According to a <a href="/wiki/BBC" title="BBC">BBC</a> poll in 2010, based on 29,977 responses in 28 countries, France is globally seen as a positive influence in the world's affairs: 49% have a positive view of the country's influence, whereas 19% have a negative view.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-453"><a href="#cite_note-453">[439]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-454"><a href="#cite_note-454">[440]</a></sup> The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nation_Brands_Index" title="Nation Brands Index">Nation Brand Index</a> of 2008 suggested that France has the second best international reputation, only behind <a href="/wiki/Germany" title="Germany">Germany</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-455"><a href="#cite_note-455">[441]</a></sup> A global opinion poll for the BBC saw France ranked the fourth most positively viewed nation in the world (behind Germany, Canada and the United Kingdom) in 2014.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-456"><a href="#cite_note-456">[442]</a></sup>
</p><p>According to a poll in 2011, the French were found to have the highest level of <a href="/wiki/Religious_tolerance" title="Religious tolerance">religious tolerance</a> and to be the country where the highest proportion of the population defines its identity primarily in term of nationality and not religion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pewmwtp_457-0"><a href="#cite_note-pewmwtp-457">[443]</a></sup> As of 2011<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=France&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, 75% of French had a favourable view of the United States, making France one of the most pro-American countries in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-458"><a href="#cite_note-458">[444]</a></sup> As of 2017<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=France&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, the favourable view of the United States had dropped to 46%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-459"><a href="#cite_note-459">[445]</a></sup> In January 2010, the magazine <i>International Living</i> ranked France as "best country to live in", ahead of 193 other countries, for the fifth year running.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-quality_460-0"><a href="#cite_note-quality-460">[446]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/OECD_Better_Life_Index" title="OECD Better Life Index">OECD Better Life Index</a> states that "France performs well in many measures of well-being relative to most other countries in the Better Life Index".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-461"><a href="#cite_note-461">[447]</a></sup>
</p><p>The French Revolution continues to permeate the country's <a href="/wiki/Collective_memory" title="Collective memory">collective memory</a>. The tricolour <a href="/wiki/Flag_of_France" title="Flag of France">flag of France</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-462"><a href="#cite_note-462">[448]</a></sup> the anthem "<a href="/wiki/La_Marseillaise" title="La Marseillaise">La Marseillaise</a>", and the motto <i><a href="/wiki/Libert%C3%A9,_%C3%A9galit%C3%A9,_fraternit%C3%A9" title="Liberté, égalité, fraternité">Liberté, égalité, fraternité</a></i>, defined in Title 1 of the <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_France" title="Constitution of France">Constitution</a> as national symbols, all emerged during the cultural ferment of the early revolution, along with <a href="/wiki/Marianne" title="Marianne">Marianne</a>, a common <a href="/wiki/National_personification" title="National personification">national personification</a>. In addition, <a href="/wiki/Bastille_Day" title="Bastille Day">Bastille Day</a>, the national holiday, commemorates the <a href="/wiki/Storming_of_the_Bastille" title="Storming of the Bastille">storming of the Bastille</a> on 14 July 1789.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-463"><a href="#cite_note-463">[449]</a></sup>
</p><p>A common and traditional symbol of the French people is the <a href="/wiki/Gallic_rooster" title="Gallic rooster">Gallic rooster</a>. Its origins date back to Antiquity since the Latin word Gallus meant both "<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rooster" title="Rooster">rooster</a>" and "inhabitant of Gaul". Then this figure gradually became the most widely shared representation of the French, used by French monarchs, then by the Revolution and under the successive republican regimes as representation of the national identity, used for some stamps and coins.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-464"><a href="#cite_note-464">[450]</a></sup>
</p><p>France is one of the world leaders of <a href="/wiki/Gender_equality" title="Gender equality">gender equality</a> in the workplace: as of 2017, it has 36.8% of its corporate board seats held by women, which makes it the leader of the <a href="/wiki/G20" title="G20">G20</a> for that metric.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-465"><a href="#cite_note-465">[451]</a></sup> It was ranked in 2019 by the <a href="/wiki/World_Bank" title="World Bank">World Bank</a> as one of the only six countries in the world where women have the same work rights as men.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-466"><a href="#cite_note-466">[452]</a></sup>
</p><p>France is one of the most liberal countries in the world when it comes to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/LGBT_rights" title="LGBT rights">LGBT rights</a>: a 2020 <a href="/wiki/Pew_Research_Center" title="Pew Research Center">Pew Research Center</a> poll found that 86% of the French think that <a href="/wiki/Same-sex_relationship" title="Same-sex relationship">same-sex relationships</a> should be accepted by society, one of the highest acceptance rates in the world (comparable to that of other <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Western_European" title="Western European">Western European</a> nations).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-467"><a href="#cite_note-467">[453]</a></sup> France legalised <a href="/wiki/Same-sex_marriage" title="Same-sex marriage">same-sex marriage</a> and adoption in 2013.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-468"><a href="#cite_note-468">[454]</a></sup> The government has used its diplomatic clout to support <a href="/wiki/LGBT_rights_by_country_or_territory" title="LGBT rights by country or territory">LGBT rights throughout the world</a>, notably in <a href="/wiki/LGBT_rights_at_the_United_Nations" title="LGBT rights at the United Nations">the United Nations</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-469"><a href="#cite_note-469">[455]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2020, France was ranked fifth in the <a href="/wiki/Environmental_Performance_Index" title="Environmental Performance Index">Environmental Performance Index</a> (behind the United Kingdom), out of 180 countries ranked by <a href="/wiki/Yale_University" title="Yale University">Yale University</a> in that study.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-470"><a href="#cite_note-470">[456]</a></sup> Being the host country of the <a href="/wiki/2015_United_Nations_Climate_Change_Conference" title="2015 United Nations Climate Change Conference">2015 Paris Climate Change Conference</a>, the French Government was instrumental in securing the 2015 <a href="/wiki/Paris_Agreement" title="Paris Agreement">Paris Agreement</a>, a success that has been credited to its "openness and experience in diplomacy".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-471"><a href="#cite_note-471">[457]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cuisine">Cuisine</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/French_cuisine" title="French cuisine">French cuisine</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:French_taste_of_wines.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1200" data-file-width="1600" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/French_taste_of_wines.JPG/220px-French_taste_of_wines.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/French_taste_of_wines.JPG/330px-French_taste_of_wines.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/French_taste_of_wines.JPG/440px-French_taste_of_wines.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:French_taste_of_wines.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/French_wines" title="French wines">French wines</a> are usually made to accompany French cuisine.</div></div></div>
<p>French cuisine is renowned for being one of the finest in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-472"><a href="#cite_note-472">[458]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-473"><a href="#cite_note-473">[459]</a></sup> According to the regions, traditional recipes are different, the North of the country prefers to use butter as the preferred fat for cooking, whereas <a href="/wiki/Olive_oil" title="Olive oil">olive oil</a> is more commonly used in the South.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-474"><a href="#cite_note-474">[460]</a></sup> Moreover, each region of France has iconic traditional specialties: <a href="/wiki/Cassoulet" title="Cassoulet">Cassoulet</a> in the Southwest, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Choucroute" title="Choucroute">Choucroute</a> in Alsace, <a href="/wiki/Quiche" title="Quiche">Quiche</a> in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lorraine_(region)" title="Lorraine (region)">Lorraine region</a>, <a href="/wiki/Beef_bourguignon" title="Beef bourguignon">Beef bourguignon</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Burgundy" title="Burgundy">Bourgogne</a>, <a href="/wiki/Provence" title="Provence">provençal</a> <a href="/wiki/Tapenade" title="Tapenade">Tapenade</a>, etc. France's most renowned products are <a href="/wiki/French_wine" title="French wine">wines</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-475"><a href="#cite_note-475">[461]</a></sup> including Champagne, <a href="/wiki/Bordeaux_wine" title="Bordeaux wine">Bordeaux</a>, <a href="/wiki/Burgundy_wine" title="Burgundy wine">Bourgogne</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Beaujolais" title="Beaujolais">Beaujolais</a> as well as a large variety of different <a href="/wiki/List_of_French_cheeses" title="List of French cheeses">cheeses</a>, such as <a href="/wiki/Camembert" title="Camembert">Camembert</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Roquefort_(cheese)" title="Roquefort (cheese)">Roquefort</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Brie_cheese" title="Brie cheese">Brie</a>. There are more than 400 different varieties.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-476"><a href="#cite_note-476">[462]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-477"><a href="#cite_note-477">[463]</a></sup>
</p><p>A meal often consists of three courses, <i>hors d'œuvre</i> or <i>entrée</i> (introductory course, sometimes soup), <i>plat principal</i> (main course), <i>fromage</i> (cheese course) or <i>dessert</i>, sometimes with a salad offered before the cheese or dessert. Hors d'œuvres could include terrine de saumon au basilic, lobster bisque, <a href="/wiki/Foie_gras" title="Foie gras">foie gras</a>, <a href="/wiki/French_onion_soup" title="French onion soup">French onion soup</a> or a <a href="/wiki/Croque_monsieur" title="Croque monsieur">croque monsieur</a>. The plat principal could include a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pot_au_feu" title="Pot au feu">pot au feu</a>, <a href="/wiki/Souffl%C3%A9" title="Soufflé">soufflé</a> or <a href="/wiki/Steak_frites" title="Steak frites">steak frites</a>. The dessert could be <a href="/wiki/Mille-feuille" title="Mille-feuille">mille-feuille</a> pastry, a <a href="/wiki/Macaron" title="Macaron">macaron</a>, an <a href="/wiki/%C3%89clair" title="Éclair">éclair</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cr%C3%A8me_br%C3%BBl%C3%A9e" title="Crème brûlée">crème brûlée</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chocolate_mousse" title="Chocolate mousse">mousse au chocolat</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cr%C3%AApe" title="Crêpe">crêpes</a>, <a href="/wiki/Far_Breton" title="Far Breton">far Breton</a> or <a href="/wiki/Caf%C3%A9_li%C3%A9geois" title="Café liégeois">café liégeois</a>.
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:142px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Fromages_fran%C3%A7ais_(19387655209).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2832" data-file-width="4256" decoding="async" height="93" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/63/Fromages_fran%C3%A7ais_%2819387655209%29.jpg/140px-Fromages_fran%C3%A7ais_%2819387655209%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/63/Fromages_fran%C3%A7ais_%2819387655209%29.jpg/210px-Fromages_fran%C3%A7ais_%2819387655209%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/63/Fromages_fran%C3%A7ais_%2819387655209%29.jpg/280px-Fromages_fran%C3%A7ais_%2819387655209%29.jpg 2x" width="140"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Fromages_fran%C3%A7ais_(19387655209).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Some <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/French_cheese" title="French cheese">French cheeses</a> with fruits</div></div></div>
<p>French cuisine is also regarded as a key element of the <a href="/wiki/Quality_of_life" title="Quality of life">quality of life</a> and the attractiveness of France.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-quality_460-1"><a href="#cite_note-quality-460">[446]</a></sup> A French publication, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Michelin_guide" title="Michelin guide">Michelin guide</a>, awards <i>Michelin stars</i> for excellence to a select few establishments.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-478"><a href="#cite_note-478">[464]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-479"><a href="#cite_note-479">[465]</a></sup> The acquisition or loss of a star can have dramatic effects on the success of a restaurant. By 2006, the Michelin Guide had awarded 620 stars to French restaurants, at that time more than any other country, although the guide also inspects more restaurants in France than in any other country (by 2010, Japan was awarded as many Michelin stars as France, despite having half the number of Michelin inspectors working there).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-480"><a href="#cite_note-480">[466]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-481"><a href="#cite_note-481">[467]</a></sup>
</p><p>In addition to its wine tradition, France is also a major producer of beer and rum. The three main French brewing regions are Alsace (60% of national production), Nord-Pas-de-Calais and Lorraine. <a href="/wiki/List_of_French_rums" title="List of French rums">France produces rum</a> via distilleries located on islands such as <a href="/wiki/R%C3%A9union" title="Réunion">Reunion Island</a> in the southern Indian Ocean.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sports">Sports</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Sport_in_France" title="Sport in France">Sport in France</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:2020_Tour_de_France,_2nd_stage,_before_km_zero.jpg"><img alt="The peloton in the streets of Nice during the 2nd stage of the Tour de France on 30 August 2020" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3654" data-file-width="5481" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/2020_Tour_de_France%2C_2nd_stage%2C_before_km_zero.jpg/220px-2020_Tour_de_France%2C_2nd_stage%2C_before_km_zero.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/2020_Tour_de_France%2C_2nd_stage%2C_before_km_zero.jpg/330px-2020_Tour_de_France%2C_2nd_stage%2C_before_km_zero.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/2020_Tour_de_France%2C_2nd_stage%2C_before_km_zero.jpg/440px-2020_Tour_de_France%2C_2nd_stage%2C_before_km_zero.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:2020_Tour_de_France,_2nd_stage,_before_km_zero.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Starting in 1903, the <a href="/wiki/Tour_de_France" title="Tour de France">Tour de France</a> is the oldest and most prestigious of <a href="/wiki/Grand_Tour_(cycling)" title="Grand Tour (cycling)">Grands Tours</a>, and the world's most famous cycling race.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-482"><a href="#cite_note-482">[468]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>France hosts "the world's biggest annual sporting event", the <a href="/wiki/Tour_de_France" title="Tour de France">Tour de France</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-483"><a href="#cite_note-483">[469]</a></sup> Other popular sports played in France include: <a href="/wiki/Association_football" title="Association football">football</a>, <a href="/wiki/Judo" title="Judo">judo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tennis" title="Tennis">tennis</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-484"><a href="#cite_note-484">[470]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Rugby_union" title="Rugby union">rugby union</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-485"><a href="#cite_note-485">[471]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/P%C3%A9tanque" title="Pétanque">pétanque</a>. France has hosted events such as the <a href="/wiki/1938_FIFA_World_Cup" title="1938 FIFA World Cup">1938</a> and <a href="/wiki/1998_FIFA_World_Cup" title="1998 FIFA World Cup">1998 FIFA World Cups</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-486"><a href="#cite_note-486">[472]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/2007_Rugby_World_Cup" title="2007 Rugby World Cup">2007 Rugby World Cup</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-487"><a href="#cite_note-487">[473]</a></sup> and will host the <a href="/wiki/2023_Rugby_World_Cup" title="2023 Rugby World Cup">2023 Rugby World Cup</a>. The country also hosted the <a href="/wiki/1960_European_Nations%27_Cup" title="1960 European Nations' Cup">1960 European Nations' Cup</a>, <a href="/wiki/UEFA_Euro_1984" title="UEFA Euro 1984">UEFA Euro 1984</a>, <a href="/wiki/UEFA_Euro_2016" title="UEFA Euro 2016">UEFA Euro 2016</a> and <a href="/wiki/2019_FIFA_Women%27s_World_Cup" title="2019 FIFA Women's World Cup">2019 FIFA Women's World Cup</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Stade_de_France" title="Stade de France">Stade de France</a> in <a href="/wiki/Saint-Denis,_Seine-Saint-Denis" title="Saint-Denis, Seine-Saint-Denis">Saint-Denis</a> is France's largest stadium and was the venue for the 1998 FIFA World Cup and 2007 Rugby World Cup finals. Since 1923, France is famous for its <a href="/wiki/24_Hours_of_Le_Mans" title="24 Hours of Le Mans">24 Hours of Le Mans</a> <a href="/wiki/Sports_car_racing" title="Sports car racing">sports car</a> <a href="/wiki/Endurance_racing_(motorsport)" title="Endurance racing (motorsport)">endurance race</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-488"><a href="#cite_note-488">[474]</a></sup> Several major tennis tournaments take place in France, including the <a href="/wiki/Paris_Masters" title="Paris Masters">Paris Masters</a> and the <a href="/wiki/French_Open" title="French Open">French Open</a>, one of the four <a href="/wiki/Grand_Slam_(tennis)" title="Grand Slam (tennis)">Grand Slam</a> tournaments. French <a href="/wiki/Martial_arts" title="Martial arts">martial arts</a> include <a href="/wiki/Savate" title="Savate">Savate</a> and <a href="/wiki/Fencing" title="Fencing">Fencing</a>.
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Pierre_de_Coubertin_Anefo2.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1024" data-file-width="718" decoding="async" height="242" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/Pierre_de_Coubertin_Anefo2.jpg/170px-Pierre_de_Coubertin_Anefo2.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/Pierre_de_Coubertin_Anefo2.jpg/255px-Pierre_de_Coubertin_Anefo2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/Pierre_de_Coubertin_Anefo2.jpg/340px-Pierre_de_Coubertin_Anefo2.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Pierre_de_Coubertin_Anefo2.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Pierre_de_Coubertin" title="Pierre de Coubertin">Pierre de Coubertin</a>, father of the modern Olympic Games</div></div></div>
<p>France has a close association with the Modern Olympic Games; it was a French aristocrat, Baron <a href="/wiki/Pierre_de_Coubertin" title="Pierre de Coubertin">Pierre de Coubertin</a>, who suggested the Games' revival, at the end of the 19th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-489"><a href="#cite_note-489">[475]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Olympic_490-0"><a href="#cite_note-Olympic-490">[476]</a></sup> After <a href="/wiki/Athens" title="Athens">Athens</a> was awarded the first Games, in reference to the Olympics' Greek origins, Paris hosted the second Games <a href="/wiki/1900_Summer_Olympics" title="1900 Summer Olympics">in 1900</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-491"><a href="#cite_note-491">[477]</a></sup> Paris was the first home of the <a href="/wiki/International_Olympic_Committee" title="International Olympic Committee">International Olympic Committee</a>, before it moved to <a href="/wiki/Lausanne" title="Lausanne">Lausanne</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-492"><a href="#cite_note-492">[478]</a></sup> Since 1900, France has hosted the Olympics on 4 further occasions: the <a href="/wiki/1924_Summer_Olympics" title="1924 Summer Olympics">1924 Summer Olympics</a>, again in Paris<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Olympic_490-1"><a href="#cite_note-Olympic-490">[476]</a></sup> and three <a href="/wiki/Winter_Olympic_Games" title="Winter Olympic Games">Winter Games</a> (<a href="/wiki/1924_Winter_Olympics" title="1924 Winter Olympics">1924</a> in <a href="/wiki/Chamonix" title="Chamonix">Chamonix</a>, <a href="/wiki/1968_Winter_Olympics" title="1968 Winter Olympics">1968</a> in <a href="/wiki/Grenoble" title="Grenoble">Grenoble</a> and <a href="/wiki/1992_Winter_Olympics" title="1992 Winter Olympics">1992</a> in <a href="/wiki/Albertville" title="Albertville">Albertville</a>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Olympic_490-2"><a href="#cite_note-Olympic-490">[476]</a></sup>
</p><p>Similar to the Olympics, France introduced Olympics for the deaf people (Deaflympics) in <a href="/wiki/1924_Summer_Deaflympics" title="1924 Summer Deaflympics">1924</a> with the idea of a French deaf car mechanic, <a href="/wiki/Eug%C3%A8ne_Rubens-Alcais" title="Eugène Rubens-Alcais">Eugène Rubens-Alcais</a> who paved the way to organise the inaugural edition of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Summer_Deaflympics" title="Summer Deaflympics">Summer Deaflympics</a> in Paris.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-493"><a href="#cite_note-493">[479]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:92px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Zinedine_Zidane_by_Tasnim_03.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="544" data-file-width="410" decoding="async" height="119" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Zinedine_Zidane_by_Tasnim_03.jpg/90px-Zinedine_Zidane_by_Tasnim_03.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Zinedine_Zidane_by_Tasnim_03.jpg/135px-Zinedine_Zidane_by_Tasnim_03.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Zinedine_Zidane_by_Tasnim_03.jpg/180px-Zinedine_Zidane_by_Tasnim_03.jpg 2x" width="90"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Zinedine_Zidane_by_Tasnim_03.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Zinedine_Zidane" title="Zinedine Zidane">Zidane</a> was named the best European footballer of the past 50 years in a 2004 <a href="/wiki/UEFA" title="UEFA">UEFA</a> poll.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-494"><a href="#cite_note-494">[480]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Both the <a href="/wiki/France_national_football_team" title="France national football team">national football team</a> and the <a href="/wiki/France_national_rugby_union_team" title="France national rugby union team">national rugby union team</a> are nicknamed "<i>Les Bleus</i>" in reference to the team's shirt colour as well as the national <a href="/wiki/Flag_of_France" title="Flag of France">French tricolour flag</a>.
